en: Margo Roth Spiegelman, who got into that concert by telling the bouncer she was the bassist’s girlfriend, and didn’t they recognize her, and come on guys seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman and if you go back there and ask the bassist to take one look at me, he will tell you that I either am his girlfriend or he wishes I was, and then the bouncer did so, and then the bassist said “yeah that’s my girlfriend let her in the show,” and then later the bassist wanted to hook up with her and she rejected the bassist from the Mallionaires.

Come on man, seriously, I’m Margo Roth Spiegelman, now if you go inside and tell the bass guitarist to take one look at me, he’ll immediately tell you that I’m his girlfriend, or that he wants me to be his girlfriend. The ticket checker did just that, and the bassist said, “Yeah, that’s my girlfriend, let her in.” After that, the guy wanted to date Margo seriously, and she turned down the bassist of The Mallionaires.

Come on guys, seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman, if you go and ask the bassist to take a look at me, he will either tell you that I am his girlfriend or that he wants me to be.” When the guard did exactly that, the bassist said, “Yes, she is my girlfriend, let her into the show,” later he tried to hit on Margo, and Margo rejected The Mallionaires' bassist.
es: Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had sneaked into that concert by telling the security guard that she was the bassist's girlfriend, didn't they recognize her?, come on, guys, seriously, I'm Margo Roth Spiegelman, and if you're going to ask the bassist to come see who I am, he'll either say I'm his girlfriend or that he wishes I were, and then the security guard went to ask him, and the bassist said: "Yes, she's my girlfriend, let her in," and then the bassist wanted to make out with her, but she rejected the bassist of the Mallionaires!

en: Oh, we’re just scattering some dead fish about town, breaking some windows, photographing naked guys, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-fifteen in the morning, that kind of thing.
vi: Oh, we just scattered dead fish around the city, smashed a few windows, took photos of naked guys, and now we're going to have some fun in the hallway of a skyscraper at three fifteen in the morning, something like that.
tr: Ah, we're just wandering around the city distributing dead fish, breaking windows, taking photos of naked men, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-thirty in the morning, things like that.
es: "Well, nothing much, we're distributing a few dead fish around the city, breaking some windows, taking photos of naked guys, wandering around private skyscrapers at a quarter past three in the morning... you know, those kinds of things."

en: “Not much,” I answered.
vi: "Nothing significant," I replied.
tr: "Not much," I replied.
es: —Not too much —I replied to him.

en: “Elevators are down for the night,” Gus said.
vi: "The elevator doesn't go up at night," Gus said.
tr: “The elevators are not working tonight,” said Gus.
es: —The elevators don't work at night —said Gus—.

en: “Had to shut ’em off at three.
vi: "It has to be turned off at three o'clock.
tr: “I had to shut them down at three o'clock.
es: I have to turn them off at three.

en: You’re welcome to take the stairs, though.”
vi: You two can just use the stairs."
tr: Still, please go ahead and use the stairs.”
es: But you can use the stairs.

en: “Cool.
vi: "Alright, see you later, Gus."
tr: “Very well.
es: —Great.

en: See ya, Gus.”
vi: "Alright, see you later, Gus."
tr: See you, Gus.”
es: See you later, Gus.

en: “See ya, Margo.”
vi: "Yes, Margo."
tr: "See you, Margo.""
es: —See you later, Margo.

en: “How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building?”
vi: “How on earth do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?”
tr: “For God's sake, how do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?”
es: —How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building?

en: I asked once we were safely in the stairwell.
vi: I asked as we both safely climbed the stairs.
tr: I asked as soon as we reached the stairs.
es: —I asked him as soon as we were safe on the stairs.

en: “He was a senior when we were freshmen,” she answered.
vi: “When we entered high school, he was in his final year,” Margo replied.
tr: “When we were in the first grade, he was in the final grade,” she replied.
es: —He was in the last year of high school when we were in the first year —he answered me—.

en: “We gotta hustle, okay?
vi: “We need to hurry up.”
tr: “We need to hurry, okay?
es: We have to hurry up, okay?

en: Time’s a-wastin’.”
vi: “Time is wasting away.”
tr: Time is passing.”
es: We're running out of time.

en: Margo started taking the stairs two at a time, flying up, one arm on the rail, and I tried to keep pace with her, but couldn’t.
vi: She started taking the stairs two at a time, rushing up, one hand gripping the stair railing, and I struggled to keep up.
tr: Margo started climbing the stairs two at a time, one arm flying up the banister, and I tried to keep up with her but couldn't.
es: Margo started climbing the steps two at a time, at full speed and with one hand on the railing, and I tried to keep up with her, but I couldn't.

en: Margo didn’t play any sports, but she liked to run—I sometimes saw her running by herself listening to music in Jefferson Park.
vi: Margo didn’t play any sports but liked to jog–I occasionally saw her running alone while listening to music in Jefferson Park.
tr: Margo didn't do any sports, but she loved to run... Her I had seen him a few times running in Jefferson Park, listening to music alone.
es: Margo didn't play sports, but she liked to run. From time to time, I saw her in Jefferson Park running alone with her headphones on.

en: I, however, did not like to run.
vi: But I didn’t like running.
tr: However, I did not like running or even engaging in any physical effort.
es: But I didn't like running.

en: Or, for that matter, engage in any kind of physical exertion.
vi: Or maybe that’s why I didn’t participate in any strenuous physical activities.
tr: However, I did not like running or even engaging in any physical effort.
es: In fact, I didn't like making the slightest physical effort.

en: But now I tried to keep up a steady pace, wiping the sweat off my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs.
vi: Now I tried to maintain a steady pace, wiping the sweat pouring down my forehead and ignoring the throbbing pain in my calves.
tr: But now, I was trying to keep up with him steadily, wiping the sweat from my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs.
es: But I tried to keep a steady pace, wipe the sweat from my forehead, and ignore the burning in my legs.

en: When I got to the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
vi: When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was already standing at the landing, waiting for me.
tr: When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
es: When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was waiting for me on the landing.

en: “Check it out,” she said.
vi: “Look at this,” she said, opening the door next to the stairs, and we walked into a spacious room with an oak table as long as two cars and walls with windows stretching from floor to ceiling.
tr: “Take a look at this,” he said.
es: —Take a look —he told me.

en: She opened the stairwell door and we were inside a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars, and a long bank of floor-to-ceiling windows.
vi: “Look at this,” she said, opening the door next to the stairs, and we walked into a spacious room with an oak table as long as two cars and walls with windows stretching from floor to ceiling.
tr: He opened the door next to the stairs and we entered a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars and a long side surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows.
es: He opened the stairway door and we entered a huge room with an oak table the size of two cars and some large windows that went from the floor to the ceiling.

en: “Conference room,” she said.
vi: “Conference room,” Margo said.
tr: “Conference room,” he said.
es: —The conference room —he explained to me—.

en: “It’s got the best view in the whole building.”
vi: “In the whole building, this is the place with the best view.”
tr: “It has the best view in the entire building.”
es: It has the best views in the entire building.

en: I followed her as she walked along the windows.
vi: I followed her as she walked along the row of windows.
tr: I followed him as he walked by the windows.
es: —I followed her as she walked through the room—.

en: “Okay, so there,” she said pointing, “is Jefferson Park.
vi: “There, that spot,” she said, pointing, “is Jefferson Park.
tr: “Alright, there it is,” he said, pointing with his hand. “Jefferson Park.
es: Well, there's Jefferson Park —she said, pointing—.

en: See our houses?
vi: Can you see our house?
tr: Do you see our houses?
es: Do you see our houses?

en: Lights still off, so that’s good.”
vi: The lights are still off, so that's good.”
tr: The lights are still off, that's good.”
es: The lights are still off, so that's perfect.

en: She moved over a few panes.
vi: She moved a few more windows down.
tr: He took a few steps to the side.
es: —She moved forward a couple of windows—.

en: “Jase’s house.
vi: “That's Jase's house.
tr: “Jase’s house.
es: Jase's house.

en: Lights off, no more cop cars.
vi: The lights are off, no more police cars.
tr: The lights are off, no more police cars.
es: The lights are off and no police cars.

en: Excellent, although it might mean he’s made it home, which is unfortunate.”
vi: Great, although that could mean he's already sneaked back home, which is a bit boring.”
tr: Perfect, but unfortunately, this might also mean that Jase has arrived home.”
es: Excellent, although that could mean he's already home. Bad luck.

en: Becca’s house was too far away to see, even from up here.
vi: Becca's house is too far away to see, even from here.
tr: Becca’s house was too far to be seen, even from here.
es: Becca's house was too far away, even from that height.

en: She was quiet for a moment, and then she walked right up to the glass and leaned her forehead against it.
vi: Margo was silent for a moment, then walked towards the glass door and pressed her forehead against it.
tr: Margo remained silent for a short while, then approached the very edge of the window and rested her forehead against it.
es: She stayed silent for a moment and then went to the window and pressed her forehead against the glass.

en: I hung back, but then she grabbed my T-shirt and pulled me forward.
vi: I lingered behind, but she tugged at my t-shirt and pulled me forward.
tr: I stayed behind, but she grabbed my t-shirt and pulled me forward.
es: I stayed behind, but she grabbed me by the shirt and pulled me.

en: I didn’t want our collective weight against a single pane of glass, but she kept pulling me forward, and I could feel her balled fist in my side, and finally I put my head against the glass as gently as possible and looked around.
vi: I didn't want to put the weight of both of us on a single pane of glass, but Margo kept pulling me, and I could feel her hand right next to mine. So, in the end, I rested my head against the glass, as cautiously as possible, and looked outside.
tr: I didn't want to put our combined weight on a single window, but she kept pulling me, and I could feel her clenched fist beside me. Finally, I slowly placed my head against the window and looked around.
es: I didn't want the glass to have to bear the weight of both of us, but she kept pulling me, I felt her fist at my side, so in the end, I also pressed my head against the glass as gently as possible and took a look.

en: From above, Orlando was pretty well lit.
vi: From above, Orlando shines brightly.
tr: From above, Orlando appeared to be quite well-lit.
es: From above, Orlando seemed quite illuminated.

en: Beneath us I could see the flashing DON’T WALK signs at intersections, and the streetlights running up and down the city in a perfect grid until downtown ended and the winding streets and cul-de-sacs of Orlando’s infinite suburb started.
vi: Below, I can see the NO PEDESTRIAN sign flashing at the traffic roundabout, the streetlights forming a perfect network, spreading out to the edge of the downtown area, where the winding streets of Orlando's endless suburbs begin.
tr: Below us, I could see the flashing DO NOT CROSS signs at the intersections, the streetlights enveloping the entire city like a perfect mesh, until the city center ended and the winding and dead-end streets of Orlando's vast suburbs began.
es: I could see the blinking traffic lights at the intersections and the streetlights lined up throughout the city, like a perfect grid, until the center ended and the winding streets and alleys of Orlando's endless outskirts began.

en: “It’s beautiful,” I said.
vi: “Beautiful,” I said.
tr: "Very beautiful," I said.
es: —How beautiful —I said.

en: Margo scoffed.
vi: Margo sniffled.
tr: Margo pursed her lips.
es: —How beautiful —I said.

en: “Really?
vi: "Really?
tr: "Really?
es: —Really? —Margo mocked—.

en: You seriously think so?”
vi: Do you really think so?"
tr: Do you seriously think that way?"
es: Are you serious?

en: “I mean, well, maybe not,” I said, although it was.
vi: “Well, maybe it's not that beautiful,” I replied, even though I actually found it beautiful.
tr: "Well, okay, maybe it's not like that," I said, even though it actually was.
es: —Well, I don't know, maybe not —I replied, although it seemed nice to me.

en: When I saw Orlando from an airplane, it looked like a LEGO set sunk into an ocean of green.
vi: When I looked at Orlando from the plane, the city looked like a LEGO toy set dropped into a green ocean.
tr: When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a green ocean to me. It looked like a sunken LEGO set.
es: When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a Lego piece submerged in a green sea.

tr: From here, at night, it looked like a real place but one I was seeing for the first time.
es: There, at night, it seemed like a real city, but a real city that I was seeing for the first time.

en: As I walked around the conference room, and then through the other offices on the floor, I could see it all: there was school.
vi: As I walked around the conference room, then to other offices on the same floor, I could see it all: a whole picture. The school.
tr: While walking in the conference room and the other offices on that floor, I could see everything. The school was there.
es: I walked through the conference room, and then the other offices on the floor. The whole city could be seen.

en: There was Jefferson Park.
vi: There was Jefferson Park.

es: There was the institute. There, Jefferson Park.

en: There, in the distance, Disney World.
vi: In the distance was Disney World.

es: There, in the distance, Disney World.

en: There was Wet ’n Wild.
vi: Wet ’n Wild water park.

vi: There was the 7-Eleven store where Margo painted her nails while I struggled to catch my breath.
tr: The 7Eleven where Margo painted her nails and I struggled to breathe was there.
es: There, the 7-Eleven where Margo had painted her nails and I struggled to breathe.

en: It was all here—my whole world, and I could see it just by walking around a building.
vi: It was all here–my entire world, and I could see it completely, just by leisurely walking around a building.
tr: Here they all were... my whole world. And I could see it just by walking inside a building.
es: There was my entire world, and I could see it just by walking through a building.

en: “It’s more impressive,” I said out loud.
vi: “Impressive,” I said aloud.
tr: “More impressive,” I said out loud.
es: —It's more impressive —I said out loud—.

en: “From a distance, I mean.
vi: “I mean, from a distance.
tr: “From a distance, I mean.
es: From a distance, I mean.

en: You can’t see the wear on things, you know?
vi: You don't see any flaws, you know what I mean?
tr: You can't see the wear and tear on them, if you know what I mean.

en: You can’t see the rust or the weeds or the paint cracking.
vi: You can't see the rust, the overgrown weeds, or the peeling paint.
tr: You can't see the rust, the weeds, or the paint cracking.
es: You don't see the rust, the weeds, and the peeling paint.

en: You see the place as someone once imagined it.”
vi: You see the city just as someone once imagined it.”
tr: You see this place as someone once imagined it.”
es: You see places as someone once imagined them.

en: “Everything’s uglier close up,” she said.
vi: “Everything looks worse up close,” Margo said.
tr: “Everything is uglier up close,” he said.
es: —Everything is uglier up close —explained Margo.

en: “Not you,” I answered before thinking better of it.
vi: "Except for you," I replied without having time to think of anything better.
tr: "It's not you," I said, without thinking properly.
es: —Not you —I replied without thinking twice.

en: Her forehead still against the glass, she turned to me and smiled.
vi: Margo still had her forehead pressed against the glass door, she turned back and smiled at me.
tr: With her forehead still pressed against the window, she turned to me and smiled.
es: She turned, without lifting her forehead from the glass, and smiled at me.

en: “Here’s a tip: you’re cute when you’re confident.
vi: "Here's the thing: you're adorable when you're confident.
tr: "Here's a piece of advice: You're charming when you're confident.
es: —I give you your reward: you are cute when you trust yourself.

en: And less when you’re not.”
vi: And less adorable when you're not."
tr: When you're not confident, you're less charming."
es: And less cute when you don't.

en: Before I had a chance to say anything, her eyes went back to the view and she started talking.
vi: Before I could react, she had already turned her gaze back outside and started talking.
tr: Before I could say anything, she turned back to the view and started talking: "The thing that's not beautiful here is this:
es: Before he had time to say anything, he turned his eyes to the city and continued speaking.

en: “Here’s what’s not beautiful about it: from here, you can’t see the rust or the cracked paint or whatever, but you can tell what the place really is.
vi: "The ugly part is this: from here, you can't see the rust and decay, but you can tell what this place really is.
tr: You can't see the rust, the cracked paint from here, but you understand what this place really is.
es: —I'll tell you what I don't like: from here you can't see the rust, the peeling paint, and all that, but you see what it really is.

en: You see how fake it all is.
vi: You see that everything is just a facade.

en: It’s not even hard enough to be made out of plastic.

vi: Look at it, Q: look at all those dead-end streets, those roads that loop back onto themselves, all those houses built just to be torn down.

es: Look at it, Q, look at all those alleys, those streets that turn back on themselves, all the houses they built just to fall apart.

en: All those paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to stay warm.
vi: All those paper people living in those paper houses, burning their futures to keep warm.
tr: All these paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to keep themselves warm.
es: All those paper people living in their paper houses and burning the future to keep warm.

tr: All the paper children drinking the beer that some thug got for them from a paper kiosk.
es: All the paper kids drinking beer that some idiot bought for them at the paper store.

en: Everyone demented with the mania of owning things.
vi: Everyone is going crazy in this frenzy of property ownership.
tr: Everyone is losing themselves in the madness of owning things.
es: Everyone going crazy with the obsession of owning things.

en: All the things paper-thin and paper-frail.
vi: All that fragile, paper-thin property.
tr: All these things are paper-thin and paper-fragile.
es: All the things weak and fragile like paper.

en: And all the people, too.
vi: And all those people are just like paper.
tr: And so are all the people.
es: And all the people too.

en: I’ve lived here for eighteen years and I have never once in my life come across anyone who cares about anything that matters.”
vi: I've lived here for eighteen years, and I've never once in my life met anyone who cared about the things that really matter."
tr: I've been living here for eighteen years and I've never once met a single person who cared about something truly important in my life."
es: I've lived here for eighteen years and not once in my life have I met someone who cares about what really matters.

en: “I’ll try not to take that personally,” I said.
vi: “I'll try not to think that you're talking about any specific person,” I said.
tr: “I will try not to take it personally,” I said, as we both stared into the ink-like darkness, dead-end streets, and quarter-acre gardens.
es: —I will try not to take it personally —I said to him.

vi: We both looked at the ink-colored void, the dead-end streets, and the plots of land for houses.

es: We both stayed watching the dark distance, the dead-end streets, and the thousand-square-meter plots.

en: “Sorry,” she said.

es: Maybe things would have been different for me if I had gone out with you instead of... ugh.

vi: It's just that, gosh, I just hate myself so much, because I still care about my so-called friends.

es: Shit.

en: Or Becca.

es: —You can sit and eat with us tomorrow.

en: I smiled.
vi: I smiled.

en: She smiled.
vi: She smiled.

tr: I was mistaken.

es: Sitting in the car, with the keys in the ignition, although without having started the engine, Margo asked me: —By the way, what time do your parents get up?

es: Later, after my last class, I translated Ovid while leaning against the exterior cement wall of the rehearsal room, trying to ignore the dissonances coming from inside.

en: “I know.

vi: “It's okay,” I replied, starting to massage my shoulders.

en: I laughed.

vi: Someone nodded towards the parking lot, I looked over and saw two ninth graders walking around, their baggy t-shirts wet on their skinny frames.

en: How do you know?

es: "How do you know?"

vi: And there was something in telling him, in the brief notes on the page, in the weariness of Margo's parents—something in all of it made me feel for the first time a gnawing sensation that Margo might be missing for a long time.

es: But in telling him, and seeing him scribbling in the notebook, and realizing the stupidity of Margo's parents... for the first time, I considered the possibility that she might have disappeared for a long time.

en: I felt the worry start to snatch at my breath when I finished talking.
vi: Anxiety seemed to choke my breath as I stopped speaking.
tr: When I finished talking, I felt my breath starting to catch from worry.
es: When I finished talking, I was so worried that I started to run out of breath.

en: The detective didn’t say anything for a while.
vi: The detective was silent for a moment.
tr: The detective didn't say anything for a while.
es: The detective didn't say anything for a while.

en: He just leaned forward in the chair and stared past me until he’d seen whatever he was waiting to see, and then he started talking.
vi: He just leaned out of his chair, staring intently over my shoulder until he saw something he had been waiting to see, then he began to speak.
tr: He just leaned forward in the chair and looked past me until he saw whatever he was expecting to see, then he started to speak.
es: He leaned forward and looked into the distance until he found what he was looking for, and then he started to speak.

en: “Listen, kid.
vi: “Listen, son.
tr: “Listen, kid.
es: —Look, kid.

en: This is what happens: somebody—girl usually— got a free spirit, doesn’t get on too good with her parents.
vi: This is how it goes: someone—usually a girl—has a free spirit and doesn't really get along with her parents.
tr: It usually goes like this: Typically, a girl is a free spirit and doesn't get along too well with her parents.
es: Here's the thing: someone with a free spirit, usually a girl, doesn't get along too well with her parents.

en: These kids, they’re like tied-down helium balloons.
vi: Those kids, they're like helium-filled balloons tied down.
tr: These kids are like helium-filled balloons tied down.
es: These kids are like helium balloons tied down.

en: They strain against the string and strain against it, and then something happens, and that string gets cut, and they just float away.
vi: They rise up and want to break free from the string, and then something happens, the string snaps, and they drift away.
tr: They struggle against the string, struggle and struggle, then something happens, the string breaks, and at that moment, they fly away.
es: They pull on the string over and over again, until finally the string breaks and they fly away.

en: And maybe you never see the balloon again.
vi: You might never see that balloon again.
tr: Maybe you'll never see the balloon again.
es: And maybe you'll never see that balloon again, because it lands in Canada or wherever, finds a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon realizes it, it's been thirty years in the same café serving coffee to the same sons of bitches.

en: It lands in Canada or somethin’, gets work at a restaurant, and before the balloon even notices, it’s been pouring coffee in that same diner to the same sad bastards for thirty years.
vi: It lands in Canada or somewhere, gets a job in a restaurant. And before the balloon realizes it, it's been serving coffee in that dingy café to those boring customers for thirty years.
tr: It might land in Canada or somewhere, find a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon even realizes it, it's been serving coffee to the same gloomy drifters in the same diner for thirty years.
es: And maybe you'll never see that balloon again, because it lands in Canada or wherever, finds a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon realizes it, it's been thirty years in the same café serving coffee to the same sons of bitches.

en: Or maybe three or four years from now, or three or four days from now, the prevailing winds take the balloon back home, because it needs money, or it sobered up, or it misses its kid brother.
vi: Or maybe in a few years, or a few days, strong winds bring the balloon back home because it needs money, or because it aches, it misses its little brother at home.
tr: Or maybe three or four years later, or three or four days later, the wind brings the balloon back home because either it needs money, has come to its senses, or misses its brother.
es: Or maybe in three or four years, or in three or four days, the prevailing winds bring the balloon back home, because it needs money, or because it has changed its mind, or because it misses its little brother.

en: But listen, kid, that string gets cut all the time.”
vi: But listen, the string keeps snapping all the time.”
tr: But listen, kid, that string always breaks.”
es: But, look, kid, the string keeps breaking.

en: “Yeah, bu—”
vi: “Yes, like–”
tr: “Yes, but...”
es: —Yes, bu…

en: “I’m not finished, kid.
vi: "I haven't finished speaking yet, son.
tr: “I'm not done yet, kid.
es: —I'm not finished, kid.

en: The thing about these balloons is that there are so goddamned many of them.
vi: The problem with balloons is that there are too many of them.
tr: The thing about these balloons is that there are really a lot of them.
es: The problem with these damn balloons is that there are so many of them.

en: The sky is choked full of them, rubbing up against one another as they float to here or from there, and every one of those damned balloons ends up on my desk one way or another, and after a while a man can get discouraged.
vi: The sky is crowded with balloons, they rub against each other as they drift from place to place, and each one of those damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and if this keeps happening, a man can get discouraged.
tr: The sky is crammed full of them, they bump into each other as they float around, and every single one of these damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and after a while, you get tired of it.
es: The sky is full of balloons flying from one side to the other and colliding with each other, and each and every one of these damn balloons ends up on my desk for one reason or another, and over time you get discouraged.

en: Everywhere the balloons, and each of them with a mother or a father, or God forbid both, and after a while, you can’t even see ’em individually.
vi: Balloons everywhere, each with a mother or a father, or heaven forbid, both, and it keeps happening until you can't see each one anymore.
tr: Balloons everywhere, each one has a mother or a father or, God forbid, both, and after a while, you can't see them individually anymore.
es: Balloons everywhere, each one with a father or a mother, or if you're lucky, with both, and in the end, you can't even see them individually.

en: You look up at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of the balloons, but you cannot see any one balloon.”
vi: You look up at the balloons in the sky, you see all those balloons, but you can't see each one clearly."
tr: You look at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of them, but you can never see just one balloon.”
es: You look up at the balloons in the sky and see them as a whole, but you no longer see them one by one.

en: He paused then, and inhaled sharply, as if he was realizing something.
vi: He paused, taking a deep breath, as if realizing something.
tr: He paused then and took a deep breath, as if he had realized something.
es: —He fell silent and took a deep breath, as if he had just realized something—.

en: “But then every now and again you talk to some big-eyed kid with too much hair for his head and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid.
vi: "But then, from there, anytime, when talking to some wide-eyed, tousle-haired kid, you don't want to tell him the truth because he looks like a good kid.
tr: “But then, once in a while, you talk to a kid with too much hair for his head and big eyes, and you want to lie to him, because he looks like a good kid.
es: But every now and then you talk to a kid with big eyes and too much hair on his head, and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid.

en: And you feel bad for this kid, because the only thing worse than the skyful of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day interrupted by just the one balloon.
vi: And you suddenly feel sorry for the boy, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what the boy sees: a clear day broken by a single balloon.
tr: Then you feel bad for that kid because the only thing worse than the balloon-filled sky you see is what he sees: A clear, blue sky interrupted by just one balloon.
es: And you feel sorry for him, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day with a single balloon.

en: But once that string gets cut, kid, you can’t uncut it.
vi: But son, once the string is cut, you can't reverse that.
tr: But once the string is broken, you can't take it back, kid.
es: But when the string breaks, kid, you can't glue it back together.

en: Do you get what I’m saying?”
vi: Do you understand what I've just said?"
tr: Do you understand what I'm saying?”
es: Do you understand what I'm trying to tell you?

en: I nodded, although I wasn’t sure I did understand.
vi: I nodded, though I wasn't sure I understood.
tr: I nodded my head up and down, though I wasn't quite sure I understood.
es: I nodded, although I wasn't sure I had understood.

en: He stood up.
vi: He stood up.
tr: He stood up.
es: He stood up.

en: “I do think she’ll be back soon, kid.
vi: “I think the girl will be back soon, son.
tr: "I think he'll be back soon, son.
es: —I think he will return soon, boy.

en: If that helps.”
vi: If saying it like that makes you feel better.”
tr: If it will help.""
es: For what it's worth.

en: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I figured that in his urge for the poetic, the detective had seen more worry in me than the pang I’d actually felt.
vi: I like to imagine Margo as a balloon, but it seems that in the midst of the poetic surge just now, the detective saw through to a lot of worries within me, even more than the impulses I was actually feeling.
tr: I liked imagining Margo as a balloon, but while the detective approached the matter poetically, I thought he saw worry in me rather than the sudden pang I actually felt.
es: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I thought that, in his desire to be poetic, the detective had seen me as much more worried than I actually was.

en: I knew she’d be back.
vi: I know Margo will come back.
tr: I knew Margo would come back.
es: I knew she would come back.

en: She’d deflate and float back to Jefferson Park.
vi: She will deflate and drift back to Jefferson Park.
tr: She would deflate and float back towards Jefferson Park.
es: She would deflate and fly back to Jefferson Park.

en: She always had.
vi: She always does.
tr: She had always done so.
es: She had always come back.

en: I followed the detective back to the dining room, and then he said he wanted to go back over to the Spiegelmans’ house and pick through her room a little.
vi: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to go to the Spiegelman house and take a look at Margo's room.
tr: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to return to the Spiegelmans' house and examine Margo's room a bit.
es: I returned to the dining room with the detective, who said he wanted to go back to the Spiegelman house to take a look in Margo's room.

en: ms Spiegelman gave me a hug and said, “You’ve always been such a good boy; I’m sorry she ever got you caught up in this ridiculousness.” mr Spiegelman shook my hand, and they left.
vi: Ms. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You've always been a serious young man, I'm sorry that Margo dragged you into this ridiculous game." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand, then they left.
tr: Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You have always been a very good child; I'm sorry if he dragged you into this nonsense." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left.
es: Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me. "You have always been a good boy," he told me. "I'm sorry that you have to get mixed up in these ridiculous things." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left.

en: As soon as the door closed, my dad said, “Wow.”
vi: As soon as the door closed, my dad exclaimed, "Oh!"
tr: As soon as the door closed, my father said, "Wow."
es: As soon as the door was closed, my father said:

en: “Wow,” agreed Mom.
vi: "Oh!" my mother responded.
tr: “Wow,” my mom chimed in.
es: —Wow. —Wow —confirmed my mother.

en: My dad put his arm around me.
vi: Dad put his arm around my shoulder.
tr: My father wrapped his arm around me.
es: My father put his arm around my shoulders.

en: “Those are some very troubling dynamics, eh, bud?”

tr: “These are very disturbing actions, aren't they buddy?”
es: —They have opted for a dynamic that only creates problems, haven't they?

en: “They’re kind of assholes,” I said.
vi: "That couple stinks to high heaven," I said.

es: —They are idiots —I told him.

en: My parents always liked it when I cursed in front of them.

tr: My parents liked it when I swore in front of them.
es: My parents liked it when I said swear words in front of them.

en: I could see the pleasure of it in their faces.
vi: I immediately saw the look of satisfaction on the faces of my creators.
tr: I could see from their expressions that they were pleased by this.
es: I saw the pleasure on their faces.

en: It signified that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them.
vi: Openly cursing like that was a signal that I trusted my parents, that I was revealing myself in front of them.
tr: This showed that I trusted them, that I was being myself in front of them.
es: It meant that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them.

en: But even so, they seemed sad.
vi: Even though that was indeed the case, my parents still looked somewhat sad.
tr: But despite this, they looked sad.
es: But, even so, they seemed sad.

en: “Margo’s parents suffer a severe narcissistic injury whenever she acts out,” Dad said to me.
vi: "Margo's parents must have been deeply hurt in their pride when she behaved like that," Dad told me.
tr: “Whenever Margo does something mischievous, her mother and father suffer the pain of a serious narcissistic wound,” said my father.
es: —Margo's parents suffer a serious blow to their narcissism every time their daughter misbehaves —my father told me.

en: “It prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mom added.
vi: "That makes them unable to be effective parents," my mother added.
tr: “This also prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mother added.
es: —And that prevents them from behaving as effective parents —added my mother.

en: “They’re assholes,” I repeated.
vi: “They stink,” I repeated.
tr: “They are really assholes,” I repeated.
es: —They are idiots —I repeated.

en: “Honestly,” my dad said, “they’re probably right.
vi: “To be honest,” Dad continued, “maybe they have a point.
tr: “If you ask me,” said my father, “they're probably right.
es: —To be honest —said my father—, they are probably right.

en: She probably is in need of attention.
vi: Maybe Margo needs everyone to pay attention to her.

es: Margo probably needs attention.

en: And God knows, I would need attention, too, if I had those two for parents.”

es: And God knows I would need attention too if those two were my parents.

es: —When she comes back, she will be devastated —commented my mother—.

en: To be abandoned like that!
vi: Being abandoned like that!
tr: To be abandoned like this!..
es: To be abandoned like that…

en: Shut out when you most need to be loved.”

tr: To be left out when she needs to be loved the most...”
es: Rejected when you need affection the most.

en: “Maybe she could live here when she comes back,” I said, and in saying it I realized what a fantastically great idea it was.
vi: "When you come back, maybe Margo should just stay here," I said, and as I uttered those words, I realized it was indeed a brilliant idea.
tr: “Maybe she can live here when she arrives,” I said, and as I spoke, I realized what a wonderful idea it was.
es: —Maybe I could live here when I come back —I said. And when I said it, I realized that it was an absolutely brilliant idea.

en: My mom’s eyes lit up, too, but then she saw something in my dad’s expression and answered me in her usual measured way.
vi: My mother raised her eyebrows slightly, but she immediately read something on my father's face, so she responded to me in her usual measured tone.
tr: My mother's eyes lit up too, but then she saw something in my father's expression and responded to me with her usual measured demeanor.
es: My mother's eyes also sparkled, but then she saw something in my father's expression and replied to me with her usual restraint.

es: —Well, it would certainly be welcome, although it would have its inconveniences…: living next to the Spiegelmans.

vi: But when Margo returns to school, tell her that we welcome her to come here. If Margo doesn't want to stay at our house, there are still plenty of other suitable places we can comfortably consider.”

es: But when she returns to the institute, please tell her that she is welcome here, and if she doesn't want to stay with us, there are many other solutions we would love to discuss with her.

en: “What’s wrong?”

es: I told Ben about the detective, the Spiegelmans, and Margo, who was technically a missing adult.

es: When I finished, he nodded and said: —Surely we would have to discuss it over a steaming plate of Resurrection.

es: I smiled and went back with him to my room.

es: Radar came by my house shortly after, and as soon as he arrived, they kicked me off the team because we were facing a difficult mission and, although I was the only one of the three who had the game, I wasn't very good at Resurrection.

tr: As I watched them navigate a zombie-infested space station, Ben said, "Goblin, Radar, goblin." "I see."

en: “I see him.”

tr: As I watched them navigate a zombie-infested space station, Ben said, "Goblin, Radar, goblin." "I see."
