vi: But I needed to get inside.
tr: But I need to get inside.
es: But I have to get in.

en: Ben and Radar try to peel the slabs of particleboard from the windows, but they’re all nailed shut.
vi: Ben and Radar tried to pry the plywood off the windows, but everything was nailed down tight.
tr: Ben and Radar are trying to remove the boards from the window, but they are all nailed down.
es: Ben and Radar try to pull the plywood sheets off the storefronts, but they are nailed down.

en: Radar kicks at the board, but it doesn’t give.
vi: Radar kicked the plywood to no avail.
tr: Radar kicks the board, but it doesn't give way.
es: Radar kicks them, but they don't budge.

en: Ben turns back to me.
vi: Ben turned back to me and said, "There's no glass behind the plywood," and he started to back up, his sneakers kicking up sand with each step.
tr: Ben turns to me.
es: Ben comes back to my side.

en: “There’s no glass behind one of these boards,” he says, and then he starts jogging away from the building, his sneakers splashing sand as he goes.
vi: Ben turned back to me and said, "There's no glass behind the plywood," and he started to back up, his sneakers kicking up sand with each step.
tr: "There is no glass behind any of these panels," he says, then starts running away from the building, his sneakers kicking up sand as he goes.
es: —Behind one of those panels, there is no glass —he tells me. And he runs off. As he runs, his shoes scatter the sand.

en: I give him a confused look.
vi: I didn't understand anything, looking at Ben questioningly.
tr: I give her a look that shows my confusion.
es: I look at him confused.

en: “I’m going to bust through the particleboard,” he explains.
vi: "I will break through that plywood," he explained.
tr: “I will break the board,” she explains.
es: —I am going to cross the plates —he explains to me.

en: “You can’t do that.”
vi: “You can't do it.”
tr: "You can't do it."
es: —You won't be able to.

en: He is the smallest of our light trio.
vi: Ben was the smallest of the three.
tr: I, the smallest of our light trio.
es: He is the least corpulent of the three, which is saying something.

en: If anyone tries to smash through the boarded-up windows, it should be me.
vi: If someone was needed to break through those boarded-up windows, it should be me.
tr: If someone is going to try to break the boards, it should be me.
es: If anyone has to try to get through the display window panels, it should be me.

en: He balls his hands into fists and then extends his fingers out.
vi: Ben clenched his hand into a fist and then stretched out his fingers.
tr: I clench my hands into fists, then extend my fingers.
es: Clench your fists and then extend your fingers.

en: As I walk toward him, he starts talking to me.
vi: As I approached, he began to tell.
tr: As I walk towards him, he starts talking to me.
es: As I walk towards him, he starts to say to me:

en: “When my mom was trying to keep me from getting beat up in third grade, she put me in tae kwon do.
vi: "When I was in third grade, my mom tried to prevent me from being bullied by enrolling me in a taekwondo class.
tr: “When my mom tried to protect me from being beaten up in third grade, she enrolled me in taekwondo.
es: —In third grade, my mother tried to stop them from hitting me by signing me up for taekwondo.

en: I only went to like three classes, and I only learned one thing, but the thing comes in handy sometimes: we watched this tae kwon do master punch through a thick wooden block, and we were all like, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you move as though your hand will go through the block, and if you believe that your hand will go through the block, then it will.”
vi: I think I only attended three sessions and learned just one move, but it was occasionally quite effective: the kids watched the taekwondo master punch through a thick wooden board, and they all marveled, asking how he did it. The master told the class that if we moved as if our hand would go through the board, and if we believed that our hand would go through, then it surely would."
tr: I only went to about three lessons and learned just one thing, but sometimes that one thing works: We would watch the taekwondo master punch through a thick board, and we would all look like, dude, how did he do that, and the master told us if you move your hand as if it’s going through the board and believe that your hand will go through, then it will happen.”
es: I only went to three classes, and I only learned one thing, but every now and then it's useful. We saw the taekwondo master break a thick block of wood and we all thought, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you act as if your hand is going to go through the block of wood, and if you believe that your hand is going to go through that block, then it goes through.

en: I’m about to refute this idiotic logic when he takes off, running past me in a blur.
vi: I was about to refute that childish logic, when Ben took off, zooming past me like a blur.
tr: As he springs into action and runs past me in a blur, I am about to dismiss his foolish logic.
es: I am about to refute that absurd logic when he starts running and passes in front of me like an arrow.

en: His acceleration continues as he approaches the board, and then utterly without fear, he leaps up at the last possible second, twists his body sideways—his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the force—and slams into the wood.
vi: The closer he got to the wooden plank, the faster he accelerated, and finally, without any hesitation, he jumped at the last second, twisting his body—shoulder first to absorb the impact—and crashed into the wood.
tr: He continues to accelerate as he approaches the board and then, completely fearlessly, at the very last possible second, he leaps into the air, twists his body sideways with his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the impact, and crashes into the board.
es: He keeps accelerating as he approaches the plank and then, fearlessly, at the last second, he jumps, twists his body, throws out his shoulder to bear the brunt of the impact, and lands on the wood.

en: I half-expect him to burst through and leave a Ben-shaped cutout, like a cartoon.
vi: I half-expected him to break through the plank and leave a Ben-shaped hole, just like in a cartoon.
tr: Part of me expects Ben to smash through the board and leave a Ben-shaped hole in it like a cartoon character.
es: I almost expect him to go through it and leave his silhouette cut out, like in cartoons.

en: Instead, he bounces off the board and falls onto his ass in a patch of bright grass amid the sea of sandy dirt.
vi: But he bounced off the wood, landing flat on the bright patch of grass, in a cloud of dust.
tr: Instead, he bounces off the board and lands on his backside on a bright patch of grass in the middle of the sandy soil sea.
es: But he bounces off the plank and lands on his butt in a grassy area in the middle of the sand.

en: Ben rolls onto his side, rubbing his shoulder.
vi: Ben rolled over, rubbing his shoulder.
tr: Ben rolls to the side, rubbing his shoulder.
es: Ben turns to one side, rubbing his shoulder.

en: “It broke,” he announces.
vi: "It's broken," he declared.
tr: “It broke,” he declares.
es: —It has broken —he says.

en: I assume he means his shoulder as I race toward him, but then he stands up, and I’m looking at a Ben-high crack in the particle-board.
vi: I think Ben meant to say his shoulder was broken and rushed over, but then he stood up, and I saw a Ben-height crack on the plywood.
tr: As I run towards her, I assume she means her shoulder, but then she stands up and I look at the crack in the particle board at Ben's height.
es: I take for granted that he is talking about the shoulder and run towards him, but he gets up and I see a crack in the particle board at his height.

en: I start kicking at it, and the crack spreads horizontally, and then Radar and I get our fingers inside the crack and start tugging.
vi: I started kicking at it, the crack split open, then Radar and I managed to wedge our fingers into the crack and began pulling hard.
tr: I start kicking, and the crack widens horizontally, then Radar and I start pulling ourselves up by sticking our fingers into the crack.
es: I start kicking it and the crack expands horizontally. Then Radar and I stick our fingers into the crack and pull.

en: I squint to keep the sweat from burning my eyes, and pull with all my force back and forth until the crack starts to make a jagged opening.
vi: I squinted to keep the sweat from running into my eyes and stinging them, pulling and pushing to widen the crack.
tr: Squinting to prevent the sweat from stinging my eyes, I look and swing back and forth with all my strength until I start creating a jagged opening.
es: I squint to avoid getting sweat in my eyes and pull with all my strength until the crack starts to form a jagged opening.

en: Radar and I urge it on with silent work, until eventually he has to take a break and Ben replaces him.
vi: Radar and I gritted our teeth and kept at it until Radar had to take a break to catch his breath and Ben took over.
tr: With silent effort, Radar and I press against the opening until he finally needs a break, then Ben takes his place.
es: We continue in silence until Radar needs to rest and Ben takes his place.

en: Finally we are able to punch a big chunk of the board into the minimall.
vi: Finally, the three of us managed to make a sizable hole in the plywood to get inside this mini shopping area.
tr: At last, we manage to punch a large, hefty piece of the board into the store.
es: In the end, we manage to throw a large piece of the board inside the place.

en: I climb in feetfirst, landing blindly onto what feels like a stack of papers.
vi: I climbed in, blindly stepping onto something that felt like a pile of papers.
tr: My feet climb first, and I blindly land on something that feels like a pile of paper.
es: I stick my feet in and land blindly on what seems to be a pile of papers.

en: The hole we’ve carved into this building gives a little light, but I can’t even make out the dimensions of the room, or whether there is a ceiling.
vi: A bit of light seeped inside through the hole we had just made, but I still couldn't make out the direction, nor could I tell if there was a ceiling above.
tr: The hole we carved into the building lets in a bit of light, but I can't even make out the dimensions of the space or whether there is a ceiling.
es: Through the hole we have opened, some light enters, but I cannot see the dimensions of the room, nor if there is a ceiling.

en: The air in here is so stale and hot that inhaling and exhaling feel identical.
vi: The air in here was so stifling and oppressive that inhaling and exhaling felt almost the same.
tr: The air inside is so stale and hot that breathing in or out feels the same.
es: The air is so warm and stale that inhaling produces the same sensation as exhaling.

en: I turn around and my chin hits Ben’s forehead.
vi: I turned around and my chin hit Ben's forehead.
tr: I turn around and my chin hits Ben's forehead.
es: I turn and bump my chin against Ben's forehead.

en: I find myself whispering, even though there’s no reason to.
vi: I whispered, even though there was no reason to whisper like that.
tr: Even though there is no reason, I find myself whispering.
es: I find myself speaking in whispers, even though there's no reason for it.

en: “Do you have a—”
vi: "You have a–"
tr: "Is there something..."
es: —Do you have a…?

en: “No,” he whispers back before I can finish.
vi: "No," Ben whispered back before I finished my sentence.
tr: Before I can finish my sentence, Ben whispers in response, "No." "Radar, did you bring the flashlight?"
es: —No —he also answers me in whispers before I have finished saying it—.

en: “Radar, did you bring a flashlight?”
vi: "Radar, do you have a flashlight?"
tr: Before I can finish my sentence, Ben whispers in response, "No." "Radar, did you bring the flashlight?"
es: Radar, did you bring a flashlight?

en: I hear Radar coming through the hole.
vi: I heard the sound of Radar climbing in.
tr: I hear Radar going through the hole.
es: I hear Radar coming in through the hole.

en: “I have one on my key chain.
vi: “There’s one on my keychain, but it’s not very bright.”
tr: "I have one on my keychain.
es: —I have one on the keychain, but it's not a big deal.

en: It’s not much, though.”
vi: “There’s one on my keychain, but it’s not very bright.”
tr: It's not a big deal, though."
es: Turn on the light.

en: The light comes on, and I still can’t see very well, but I can tell we’ve stepped into a big room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves.
vi: The light shone in, I still couldn't see anything clearly, but it could be said that we were in a large room, filled with a labyrinth of iron shelves.
tr: The light is on and I still can't see very well, but I can understand that we have stepped into a large room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves.
es: I still can't see very well, but it's clear that we have entered a large room with a labyrinth of metal shelves.

en: The papers on the floor are pages from an old day-by-day calendar, the days scattered through the room, all of them yellowing and mouse-bit.
vi: The pile of papers on the floor was from a daily torn calendar, the scattered pages falling all over the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice.
tr: The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar, days scattered around the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice.
es: The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar. The days are scattered around the room, all of them yellowed and gnawed by mice.

en: I wonder if this might once have been a little bookstore, although it’s been decades since these shelves held anything but dust.
vi: I wondered if this place had ever been a small bookstore, though decades had passed and there was nothing on the shelves but dust.
tr: I wonder if this place was once a small bookstore, however, these shelves haven't held anything but dust for decades.
es: I wonder if this could have been a bookstore, although the shelves have housed nothing but dust for decades.

en: We fall into line behind Radar.
vi: We walked in single file behind Radar.
tr: We line up behind Radar.
es: We line up behind Radar.

en: I hear something creak above us, and we all stop moving.
vi: I heard a creaking sound above, and we all stopped.
tr: I hear something creaking above us and we all stop moving.
es: I hear something creak above us and the three of us stand still.

en: I try to swallow the panic.
vi: Trying to swallow the feeling of panic, I could hear every breath of Radar and Ben, every rustling step.
tr: I try to suppress my panic.
es: I try to swallow my panic.

en: I can hear each of Radar’s and Ben’s breaths, their shuffling footsteps.
vi: Trying to swallow the feeling of panic, I could hear every breath of Radar and Ben, every rustling step.
tr: I can hear Radar and Ben's breaths and my feet scraping the ground.
es: I hear Radar and Ben's breathing, their shuffling footsteps.

en: I want out of here, but that could be Margo creaking for all I know.
vi: I wanted to get out of this place, but it could be Margo signaling to me.
tr: I want to get out of here, but it could just be Margo who's creaking.
es: I want to get out of here, but the creaking could be Margo.

en: It could also be crack addicts.
vi: It could also be the cunning addicts.
tr: Or cocaine addicts.
es: It could also be crack addicts.

en: “Just the building settling,” Radar whispers, but he seems less sure than usual.
vi: “It's just the building settling down after that little shake,” Radar whispered, but he didn't sound as confident as usual.
tr: “The floors are settling,” whispers Radar, but he seems less sure than usual.
es: —They are the foundations of the building —whispers Radar, although he seems less sure than usual.

en: I stand there unable to move.
vi: I stood frozen.
tr: I stand there unable to move.
es: I stay where I am, unable to move.

en: After a moment, I hear Ben’s voice.
vi: A moment later, I heard Ben's voice.
tr: A minute later, I hear Ben’s voice.
es: At that moment, I hear Ben's voice.

en: “The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.”
vi: “The last time I was this scared, I nearly peed my pants.”
tr: “The last time I was this scared, I peed my pants.”
es: —The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.

en: “The last time I was this scared,” Radar says, “I actually had to face a Dark Lord in order to make the world safe for wizards.”
vi: "The last time I was this scared," Radar chimed in, "I actually had to face the Dark Lord for the safety of the wizarding world."
tr: “The last time I was this scared,” says Radar, “I had to face the Dark Lord to make the world safe for wizards.”
es: —The last time I was this scared —said Radar— I had to face a Dark Lord to keep the wizards safe.

en: I made a feeble attempt.
vi: I made a feeble effort.
tr: I am making a weak attempt.
es: I made a feeble attempt:

en: “The last time I was this scared I had to sleep in Mommy’s room.”
vi: "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
tr: "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
es: —The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room.

en: Ben chuckles.
vi: Ben chuckled.
tr: I'm giggling.
es: Ben lets out a chuckle.

en: “Q, if I were you, I would get that scared Every.
vi: "Q, if I were you, I would want to be this scared Every.
tr: "Q, if I were you, I would always be that scared.
es: —Q, if I were you, I would be so scared every night.

en: Single.
vi: Night."
tr: Every.
es: —Q, if I were you, I would be so scared every night.

en: Night.”
vi: Night."
tr: Night."
es: —Q, if I were you, I would be so scared every night.

en: I’m not up for laughing, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to explore.
vi: I wasn't in the mood to laugh, but the laughter of the two made the room feel safer, and we began to explore.
tr: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to investigate.
es: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room seem safe, so we start to explore it.

en: We walk through each row of shelves, finding nothing but a few copies of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor.
vi: The three of us walked past each row of iron shelves, seeing nothing but a few issues of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s on the floor.
tr: We examine each row of shelves and find nothing but a few issues of Readers Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor.
es: We pass between the rows of shelves, but the only thing we find are some copies of Reader's Digest from the seventies lying on the floor.

en: After a while, I find my eyes adjusting to the darkness, and in the gray light we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
vi: After a while, our eyes adjusted to the darkness, and in the dim light, we began to move in different directions, at different paces.
tr: After a while, my eyes adjust to the darkness, and in the gray light, we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
es: After a while, my eyes have adjusted to the darkness and half in the dark we start to walk in different directions and at different speeds.

en: “No one leaves the room until everyone leaves the room,” I whisper, and they whisper okay’s back.
vi: “No one leaves this room until we all leave together, okay?” I whispered the agreement, and the other two whispered their consent.
tr: “No one leaves the room until everyone is mirrored,” I whisper, and they whisper back in agreement.
es: —Let no one leave until we all leave —I whisper. They whisper to me that they agree.

en: I get to a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since everyone left.
vi: I approached a partition wall in the room and discovered the first evidence that someone had entered here after the building was abandoned.
tr: I move towards one of the walls of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since it was abandoned.
es: I go towards a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here after everyone else had left.

en: A jagged semicircular, waist-high tunnel has been cut out of the wall.
vi: A jagged semicircular hole, about waist-high, had been chiseled through the wall.
tr: A semi-circular, indented, waist-high tunnel has been dug into the wall.
es: On the wall, at waist height, there is a more or less semicircular tunnel.

en: The words TROLL HOLE have been spray-painted in orange above the hole, with a helpful arrow pointing down to the hole.
vi: The words DEMON HOLE were spray-painted in orange above it, with an arrow helpfully pointing down to the hole below.
tr: Above, the words DWARF HOLE are written in orange spray paint, accompanied by an auxiliary arrow pointing to the hole below.
es: Above the hole, the words TROLL HOLE are written in orange spray, along with a helpful arrow pointing to the hole.

en: “Guys,” Radar says, so loud that the spell breaks for just a moment.
vi: “Hey,” Radar called out, loud enough that it seemed to shatter for a moment.
tr: “Kids,” says Radar, so loudly that the spell is broken for just a moment.
es: —Guys —says Radar so loudly that for a moment the spell is broken.

en: I follow his voice and find him standing by the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Troll Hole.
vi: I walked towards the sound and saw Radar standing in front of another section of wall, flashlight illuminating another Demon Hole.
tr: I follow his voice and find him standing against the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Dwarf Hole.
es: I follow his voice and find him on the other side of the wall, illuminating another Troll Hole with the flashlight.

en: The graffiti doesn’t look particularly like Margo’s, but it’s hard to tell for sure.
vi: The graffiti style didn’t particularly resemble Margo’s, but it was hard to be certain.
tr: The graffiti doesn't particularly look like it belongs to Margo, but it's hard to say for sure.
es: The graffiti doesn't look much like Margo's, but I couldn't be sure.

en: I’ve only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
vi: I had only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
tr: After all, I had seen her write a single letter with spray paint.
es: I've only seen her paint one letter.

en: Radar shines the light through the hole as I duck down and lead the way through.
vi: Radar shone the light through the hole while I bent down and crawled through first.
tr: Radar shines the light into the hole, and I crouch down and go inside.
es: Radar focuses the flashlight towards the hole, and I crouch down and enter first.

en: This room is entirely empty except for a rolled carpet in one corner.
vi: The room on this side was completely empty, except for a rolled-up carpet in the corner.
tr: This room is completely empty except for a rolled-up rug in one corner.
es: The only thing in the room is a rolled-up carpet in a corner.

en: As the flashlight scans the floor, I can see glue stains on the concrete from where the carpet had once been.
vi: When the light shone on the floor, I saw glue streaks still on the concrete, where there must have been a carpet before.
tr: As the flashlight scans the area, I can see adhesive stains on the concrete where a carpet once was.
es: The flashlight scans the floor and I see glue stains on the concrete, where the carpet used to be.

en: Across the room, I can just make out another hole cut into the wall, this time without the graffiti.
vi: Looking across the room, I saw another vent hole on the wall, this time without any writing.
tr: On the opposite side of the room, I can see just another hole dug into the wall, but this time there is no writing on the wall.
es: At the back of the room, I discover another hole in the wall, this time without graffiti.

en: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room lined with clothing racks, the stainless-steel poles still bolted into walls wine-stained with water damage.
vi: I crawled through that Devil's Hole into a room with rows of clothes hooks, the stainless steel posts still sturdy amidst the water-stained, patchy walls.
tr: I crawl through the Dwarf Hole into a room lined with clothes hangers, stainless steel poles still bearing water stains It remains attached to the walls.
es: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room with rows of clothing racks. The stainless steel hangers are still hanging on the walls with wine-colored and damp stains.

en: This room is better lit, and it takes me a moment to realize it’s because there are several holes in the roof—tar paper hangs down, and I can see places where the roof sags against exposed steel girders.
vi: This room was brighter; it took me a moment to realize it was because of several holes in the roof—the tarred paper had worn away, and I could see the spots where the roof pressed against the now-exposed iron beams.
tr: This room gets better light, and it doesn't take me long to realize that it's because there are a lot of holes in the roof... The tarred paper is hanging down, and I can see the places where the steel beams are exposed in the roof.
es: This room is more illuminated, and it takes me a moment to realize that it's because there are several holes in the ceiling. The asphalt fabric is hanging down, and I see parts where the ceiling is sagging over exposed iron beams.

en: “Souvenir store,” Ben whispers in front of me, and I know immediately he is right.
vi: “Souvenir shop,” Ben whispered in front of me, and I immediately realized he was right.
tr: In front of me, Ben whispers, "Gift shop," and I immediately realize he is right.
es: —A souvenir shop —whispers Ben in front of me. And at that moment I realize that he is right.

en: In the middle of the room five display cases form a pentagon.
vi: In the middle of the room, there were five display cabinets arranged in a pentagon shape.
tr: The five display cases in the middle of the room form a pentagon.
es: In the middle of the room, five display cases form a pentagon.

en: The glass that once kept the tourists from their tourist crap has mostly been shattered and lies in shards around the cases.
vi: The glass that once separated tourists from the useless souvenirs was mostly shattered, with shards of glass scattered around the cabinets.
tr: The glass that once kept tourists away from tourist knick-knacks is mostly shattered.
es: The glass that once separated tourists from their tourist trinkets is shattered on the floor, around the display cases.

en: The gray paint peels off the wall in odd and beautiful patterns, each cracked polygon of paint a snowflake of decay.
vi: The gray paint peeled off the walls into amusing patterns, each cracked polygon forming the shape of a withered snowflake.
tr: Gray paint is peeling off the wall with strange and beautiful patterns, each crack in the paint resembling a snowflake formed by decay.
es: The gray paint peels off the walls, forming beautiful patterns. Each polygon of peeled paint is like a snowflake of decay.

en: Strangely, though, there’s still some merchandise: there’s a Mickey Mouse phone I recognize from some way back part of childhood.
vi: But strangely, there were still some traces of commerce: a Mickey Mouse phone, the kind I had seen when I was a kid.
tr: Strangely, there are still some items left: A Mickey Mouse phone that I remember from a part of my childhood.
es: But the strange thing is that there are still some items left. There is a Mickey Mouse phone that reminds me of my childhood.

en: Moth-bit but still-folded SUNNY ORLANDO T-shirts are on display, splattered with broken glass.
vi: Some ORLANDO SUNSHINE t-shirts, nibbled by cockroaches but still folded and displayed, mixed with broken glass shards.
tr: The SUNSHINE ORLANDO t-shirts, which have been eaten by moths but are still folded, are still in the display, with broken glass scattered over them.
es: In the display cases, sprinkled with broken glass, there are moth-eaten t-shirts, still folded, that say ORLANDO IN THE SUN.

en: Beneath the glass cases, Radar finds a box filled with maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World and Crystal Gardens and fun houses that no longer exist.
vi: Under the glass cabinet, Radar found a box full of maps and travel books, advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and those now-defunct funhouses.
tr: Under the glass displays, they find a box full of old tourist brochures advertising now-defunct amusement parks like Alligator World, Crystal Gardens, and others, along with radar maps.
es: Under the display cases, Radar finds a box full of maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and other attractions that no longer exist.

en: Ben waves me over and silently points out the green glass alligator tchotchke lying alone in the case, almost buried in the dust.
vi: Ben waved at me, silently pointing to a green glass alligator souvenir, lying alone in a display case, almost buried in dust.
tr: He calls me over and silently points to a green glass alligator figurine standing alone in the display, almost buried in dust.
es: Ben gestures with his hand and without saying anything points to the green glass alligator in a box, almost buried in the dust.

en: This is the value of our souvenirs, I think: you can’t give this shit away.
vi: This is the value of souvenirs, I thought to myself: we can never throw them away.
tr: This is the value of our memories: it's impossible to give away these absurdities.
es: This is what our memories are worth, I think. You can't give this crap away.

en: We make our way back through the empty room and the shelved room and crawl through the last Troll Hole.
vi: We went back, through the empty room and the room with many iron shelves, crawling through the last Devil's Hole.
tr: First, we go back through the empty room, then through the room with shelves, and finally crawl through the last Dwarf Hole.
es: We go back through the empty room and the room with the shelves, and we crawl through the last Troll Hole.

en: This room looks like an office only without computers, and it appears to have been abandoned in a great hurry, like its employees were beamed up to space or something.
vi: This area looked like an office, except there were no computers, and it seemed to have been abandoned hastily, as if the employees had been suddenly abducted into space or something like that.
tr: This room looks like an office, but there are no computers, and it seems to have been abandoned in a great hurry, as if its workers were teleported to space or something.
es: This room looks like an office, only it doesn't have computers, and it gives the impression that it was abandoned in a hurry, as if the workers had been teleported into space or something like that.

en: Twenty desks sit in four rows.
vi: Twenty desks arranged in four rows.
tr: There are twenty desks arranged in four rows.
es: Twenty tables arranged in four rows.

en: There are still pens on some of the desks, and they all feature oversize paper calendars lying flat against the desks.
vi: Here and there were some pens on the desks, and each desk still had large wall calendars.
tr: Some desks still have pens on them, and all the desks feature large calendars lying flat on top of them.
es: There are still pens on some tables, and all of them are covered with giant paper calendars.

en: On each calendar, it is perpetually February of 1986.
vi: All the calendars stopped at February 1986.
tr: Each calendar shows February 1986.
es: All the calendars stopped in February 1986.

en: Ben pushes a cloth desk chair and it spins, creaking rhythmically.
vi: Ben pushed a fabric-covered chair, the swivel chair creaking rhythmically.
tr: I push a fabric-covered chair, and the chair spins with a rhythmic creak.
es: Ben pushes a desk chair, which squeaks rhythmically as it turns.

en: Thousands of Post-it notes advertising The Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp. are piled beside one desk in a rickety pyramid.
vi: Thousands of note pads advertising Martin-Gale Mortgage Company were piled next to a desk, forming a wobbly pyramid.
tr: Next to one desk, thousands of sticky notes advertising the MartinGale Mortgage Company are piled up in a pyramid shape.
es: Thousands of post-it notes with advertisements for the Martin-Gale mortgage company are piled in an unstable pyramid shape under a table.

en: Open boxes contain stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers, detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp.
vi: Uncovered boxes, containing stacks of paper from ancient dot matrix printers, held the financial statistics of Martin-Gale Mortgage Company.
tr: In open boxes, there are printouts from old dot matrix printers, MartinGale There are stacks of papers showing the details of the income and expenses of the Mortgage Company.
es: There are open boxes with stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale company.

en: On one of the desks, someone has stacked brochures for subdivisions into a single-story house of cards.
vi: On another desk, someone had arranged brochures of subdivisions into the shape of a one-story house.
tr: On top of one of the desks, someone has arranged neighborhood brochures to form a single-story house out of a card.
es: On one of the tables, someone has stacked brochures of housing developments to form a one-story house.

en: I spread the brochures out, thinking that they may hold a clue, but no.
vi: I knocked over the brochures, hoping they held some clue, but they didn't.
tr: Thinking there might be a clue inside them, I spread out the brochures, but there isn't.
es: I spread out the brochures to see if they hide any clues, but no.

en: Radar fingers through the papers, whispering, “Nothing after 1986.”
vi: Radar ran his finger through the pile of papers and said quietly, “Nothing after 1986.”
tr: Radar, "There is nothing after 1986," he whispers while shuffling the papers with his fingers.
es: —Nothing after 1986 —sighs Radar, running his fingers over the papers.

en: I start to go through the desk drawers.
vi: I started looking through the desk drawers.
tr: I start to inspect the desk drawers.
es: I start to check the drawers.

en: I find Q-tips and stickpins.
vi: There were cotton swabs and tie pins.
tr: I find cotton swabs and tie pins.
es: I find cotton swabs and pins.

en: Pens and pencils packed a dozen each in flimsy cardboard packaging with retro fonts and design.
vi: Pens and pencils by the dozen in rickety cardboard boxes, printed and styled old look.
tr: Dozens of fountain pens and pencils, packaged in cardboard boxes with old-fashioned fonts and designs.
es: Pens and pencils packed ten by ten in cardboard boxes with retro letters and designs.

en: Napkins.
vi: Napkin.
tr: Paper napkins.
es: Paper napkins.

en: A pair of golf gloves.
vi: A pair of golf gloves.
tr: A pair of golf gloves.
es: A pair of golf gloves.

en: “Do you guys see anything,” I ask, “that gives any hint that anyone has been here in the last, say, twenty years?”
vi: "Have you two seen anything that indicates someone has been here in the last, let's see, twenty years or so?" I asked.
tr: “Children, do you see anything?” I ask. “Any clue that someone has been here in the last twenty years?”
es: —Do you see the slightest indication that anyone has been here in the last twenty years, for instance? —I ask them.

en: “Nothing but the Troll Holes,” Ben answers.
vi: "Nothing except the Ghouls," Ben replied.
tr: “There is nothing but Dwarf Holes,” Ben replies.
es: —Only the Troll Holes —Ben answers me.

en: It’s a tomb, everything wrapped in dust.
vi: This place is a tomb, everything lies still under the dust.
tr: This place is a tomb, everything is covered in dust.
es: It is a tomb, all covered in dust.

en: “So why did she lead us here?” asks Radar.
vi: “So why did Margo bring us here?” Radar asked.
tr: “Then why did Margo direct us here?” asks Radar.
es: —And then why did you bring us here? —asks Radar.

en: We are speaking now.
vi: We could speak normally now, no longer whispering.
tr: We are talking now.
es: We finally started talking.

en: “Dunno,” I say.
vi: "I don't know," I replied.
tr: "I don't know," I say.
es: —No idea —I answered.

en: She is clearly not here.
vi: Clearly, Margo is not here.
tr: Clearly, Margo is not here.
es: There is no doubt that Margo is not here.

en: “There are some spots,” Radar says, “with less dust.
vi: “There are a few places with less dust,” Radar said.
tr: “There are some places,” says Radar, “that are less dusty.
es: —There are spots with less dust —says Radar—.

en: There’s a dustless rectangle in the empty room, like something was moved.
vi: “A dust-free rectangle in an otherwise empty room, as if something had been moved.
tr: In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something has been removed.
es: In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something had been moved.

en: But I don’t know.”
vi: But I don't know.”
tr: But I don't know.”
es: But I don't know.

en: “And there’s that painted part,” Ben says.
vi: "And there are some painted spots," Ben added.
tr: “And there's this painted section,” says Ben.
es: —And this section is painted —observes Ben, pointing to a wall.

en: Ben points and Radar’s flashlight shows me that a piece of the far wall in this office has been brushed over with white primer, like someone got the idea to remodel the place but abandoned the project after half an hour.
vi: Ben pointed, and Radar's light followed, illuminating a patch in the far corner of this office wall. The patch was covered with primer, as if someone had the idea to redesign this place but abandoned the project after about half an hour.
tr: He points, and Radar's flashlight shows that part of the office's opposite wall is painted with white primer, as if someone had the idea to make a change to the room but abandoned the project half an hour later.
es: Radar's flashlight shows me that on the back wall of the office there is a section that has been given a coat of white paint, as if someone had thought of remodeling it but abandoned the project after half an hour.

en: I walk over to the wall, and up close, I can see that there’s some red graffiti behind the white paint.
vi: I approached the patch, and up close, I saw red graffiti under the white paint.
tr: I walk towards the wall and, upon getting closer, I can see that there is red graffiti under the white paint.
es: I approach the wall and see that underneath the paint there is something written in red.

en: But I can only see occasional hints of the red paint bleeding through—not nearly enough to make anything out.
vi: But I could only see glimpses of red seeping through the white—almost impossible to discern what it was.
tr: But I can only see traces of the red graffiti... definitely not enough to make out anything.
es: But I only see traces of red paint seeping through, not enough to know what it says.

en: There’s a can of primer up against the wall, open.
vi: A can of primer was right next to the wall, still open.
tr: There is an open paint can directly opposite the wall.
es: Next to the wall, there is an open can of white paint.

en: I kneel down and push my finger into the paint.
vi: I knelt down and dipped my finger into the paint.
tr: I kneel down and press my finger into the paint.
es: I kneel down and dip my finger into the paint.

en: There’s a hard surface, but it breaks easily, and my finger comes up drenched in white.
vi: The surface of the paint had hardened, but it easily cracked, and when I pulled my finger out, it was completely covered in white.
tr: The surface is hard but breaks easily, and my finger comes out covered in white.
es: The surface is hard, but it breaks easily, so I pull out my white finger.

en: As the paint drips off my finger, I don’t say anything, because we’ve all come to the same conclusion, that someone has been here recently after all, and then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
vi: As drops of paint fell from my finger, I said nothing because we all reached the same conclusion: someone had been here recently. The creaking sound echoed again somewhere in the building, and Radar dropped his flashlight.
tr: As the paint drips from my finger, nothing I'm not saying anything because we all come to the same conclusion that someone recently came here, then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
es: I say nothing while the paint drips from my finger, because we have all come to the same conclusion: someone has been here recently. And then the building creaks again, and Radar drops the flashlight and lets out a curse.

en: “This is freaky,” he says.
vi: "Disgusting," he muttered angrily.
tr: "This is very scary," he says.
es: —This is very strange —he comments.

en: “Guys,” Ben says.
vi: “Look,” Ben exclaimed.
tr: “Kids,” says Ben.
es: —Guys —says Ben.

en: The flashlight is still on the ground, and I take a step back, to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing.
vi: The flashlight was still on the floor, I stepped back to pick it up, but at that moment I saw what Ben was pointing at.
tr: The flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up but then I see Ben pointing at something.
es: As the flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing.

en: He is pointing at the wall.
vi: He was pointing at a section of the wall.
tr: He is pointing at the wall.
es: What he's pointing at is the wall.

en: A trick of the indirect light has made the graffiti letters float up through the coat of primer, a ghost-gray print I recognize immediately as Margo’s.
vi: The play of reflected light had revealed some graffiti letters, making them stand out from the white paint covering them, the eerie handwriting I immediately recognized as Margo's.
tr: Thanks to the indirect light, the letters on the wall writing become readable through the layer of primer paint, and I see a faint writing that I immediately understand is Margo’s.
es: With the indirect light, the letters of the graffiti have pierced through the layer of paint. In that moment, I know that those ghostly gray letters are from Margo.

en: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS
vi: WILL COME TO PAPER CITIES
tr: YOU WILL GO TO PAPER TOWNS AND NEVER COME BACK
es: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS

en: AND YOU WILL NEVER COME BACK
vi: AND WILL NEVER RETURN
tr: YOU WILL GO TO PAPER TOWNS AND NEVER COME BACK
es: AND YOU WILL NEVER RETURN

en: I pick up the flashlight and shine it on the paint directly, and the message disappears.
vi: I picked up the flashlight and shone it directly on the paint, the message immediately disappeared.
tr: I pick up the flashlight from the ground and point it directly at the paint, and the message disappears.
es: I grab the flashlight, shine it directly at the painting, and the message disappears.

en: But when I shine it against a different part of the wall, I can read it again.
vi: But when I shone the light on other parts of the wall in the room, I could read those letters again.
tr: But when I point the flashlight at another part of the wall, I can read the writing again.
es: But when I focus on another area of the wall, it becomes readable again.

en: “Shit,” Radar says under his breath.
vi: "What the hell," Radar said under his breath.
tr: "Damn," Radar says in a low voice.
es: —Shit —says Radar in a low voice.

en: And now Ben says, “Bro, can we go now?
vi: And now Ben spoke up, "Guys, can we go now?
tr: Now I say, "Brother, can we leave now?
es: —Colleague, can we leave now? —asks Ben—.

en: Because the last time I was this scared . . . screw it.
vi: Because the last time I was this scared... damn it, I'm scared out of my wits here.
tr: Because the last time I was this scared... screw it.
es: Because the last time I was this scared... To hell with it.

en: I’m freaked out.
vi: Because the last time I was this scared... damn it, I'm scared out of my wits here.
tr: I'm terrified.
es: I'm terrified.

en: There’s nothing funny about this shit.”
vi: This game is no fun at all."
tr: There's nothing funny about this shitty situation," he says.
es: This shit isn't fun at all.

en: There’s nothing funny about this shit is the closest Ben can come to the terror I feel, maybe.
vi: This game is not fun at all, it's the closest way Ben can reach the horror I'm feeling, perhaps.
tr: There is nothing funny about this shitty situation, maybe the closest Ben can get to the horror I feel.
es: I think "This shit isn't fun at all" is what comes closest to my own terror.

en: And it is close enough for me.
vi: And for me, that's close enough.
tr: And for me, that's close enough.
es: And for me, that's close enough.

en: I fast-walk toward the Troll Hole.
vi: I quickly walked towards the Devil's Hole.
tr: I quickly walk towards the Dwarf Hole.
es: I hurry towards the Troll Hole.

en: I can feel the walls closing in on us.
vi: It feels like the walls are closing in behind us.
tr: I can feel the walls closing in on us.
es: I feel the walls closing in on us.

tr: I can feel the walls closing in on us.

en: Ben and Radar dropped me off at my house—even though they’d skipped school, they couldn’t afford to skip band practice.
vi: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home—those two were willing to skip school but definitely wouldn't miss band practice.
tr: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home... despite skipping school, don't skip band practice.
es: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home. Although they hadn't gone to class, they couldn't afford to skip rehearsal.

en: I sat alone with “Song of Myself” for a long time, and for about the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem starting at the beginning, but the problem was that it’s like eighty pages long and weird and repetitive, and although I could understand each word of it, I couldn’t understand anything about it as a whole.
vi: I sat alone for a long time with "Song of Myself." It must have been the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem from start to finish, but the problem was that the poem was about eighty pages long, convoluted, and repetitive. Even though I understood each individual word, when combined into a whole, I just couldn't make sense of it.
tr: For a long time, I sat alone with My Song and tried to read the entire poem from start to finish for about the tenth time, but the thing was, the poem was about eighty pages long, strange, and overly repetitive, and although I could understand every word, I couldn't understand anything as a whole.
es: I sat for a good while with "Song of Myself," and for the umpteenth time, I tried to read the entire poem, starting from the beginning, but the problem was that it's like eighty pages long, it's weird and repetitive, and even though I understood all the words, I didn't understand what it was trying to say.

en: Even though I knew the highlighted parts were probably the only important parts, I wanted to know whether it was a suicide-note kind of poem.
vi: Even knowing that perhaps only the marked parts were important, I still wanted to figure out whether this was a kind of suicide note poetry.
tr: Even though I knew that the underlined sections were probably the only important parts, I wanted to understand whether it was a poem in the style of a suicide note.
es: Even though I knew that probably the only important parts were the marked verses, I wanted to know if the poem was some kind of suicide note.

en: But I couldn’t make sense of it.
vi: But I still couldn't make any sense of it.
tr: But I couldn't make any sense of it.
es: But I didn't understand anything.

en: I was ten confusing pages into the poem when I got so freaked out that I decided to call the detective.
vi: After reading a dozen pages of the book, feeling utterly confused, I decided to call the detective.
tr: When I became frightened enough to decide to call the detective, I had gone through ten confusing pages of the poem.
es: I had already read ten confusing pages when I became so hysterical that I decided to call the detective.

en: I dug his business card out of a pair of shorts in the laundry hamper.
vi: I retrieved his business card from the pocket of my shorts, which I had tossed into the dirty laundry basket.
tr: I found and pulled out the detective's business card from the shorts in the laundry basket.
es: I took his card out of a pair of shorts from the dirty laundry basket.

en: He answered on the second ring.
vi: He picked up on the second ring.
tr: He answered on the second ring.
es: He answered on the second ring.

en: “Warren.”
vi: "Warren, listen."
tr: "Warren."
es: —Warren.

en: “Hi, um, it’s Quentin Jacobsen.
vi: "Uh, yes, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, do you remember me?"
tr: "Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen.
es: Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: I’m a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman?”
vi: "Uh, yes, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, do you remember me?"
tr: I am a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, but?"
es: Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: “Sure, kid, I remember you.
vi: “I remember, son.
tr: “Of course, child, I remember you.
es: —Of course, boy, I remember you.

en: What’s up?”
vi: What's the matter?”
tr: How are you?”
es: What’s happening?

en: I told him about the clues and the minimall and about paper towns, about how she had called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust Building, but she hadn’t used it in the plural, about her telling me that she wouldn’t want to be found, about finding her underneath our bootsoles.
vi: I told him about the clues, the mini shopping mall, about the paper towns and how Margo called Orlando a paper town when we looked down from the SunTrust building, but she didn't use the plural form. I recounted how Margo told me that she didn't want to be found, and to look for her under the soles of boots.
tr: I told her about the clues in the small shopping center and the paper towns, how she called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust building but didn't use it in plural, how she told me she didn't want to be found, and the matter of finding her under the soles of my shoes.
es: I told him about the clues, the mall, and the paper towns, I explained that from the top of the SunTrust Building she had told me that Orlando was a paper town, but she hadn't talked about towns in plural, that she had told me she didn't want to be found and about looking for her under the soles of our shoes.

en: He didn’t even tell me not to break into abandoned buildings, or ask why I was at an abandoned building at 10 A. M. on a school day.
vi: He didn't even raise his voice to tell me not to go into abandoned buildings, nor did he ask why I was in an abandoned building at 10 AM on a school day.
tr: She didn't tell me not to trespass into abandoned buildings or even ask why I was in an abandoned building at ten in the morning on a school day. She just let me talk
es: The detective didn't even tell me that I shouldn't enter abandoned buildings, nor did he ask me what I was doing there at ten in the morning on a school day.

en: He just waited until I stopped talking and said, “Jesus, kid, you’re almost a detective.
vi: He just waited until I finished speaking before saying, "Good Lord, boy, you're almost a detective already.
tr: He waited until he finished and said, "My God, son, you're almost a detective.
es: He waited until I had finished speaking. —For God's sake, boy, you're almost a detective.

en: All you need now is a gun, a gut, and three ex-wives.
vi: Now you just need a gun, a detective's intuition, and three ex-wives.
tr: Now all you need is a gun, courage, and three ex-wives.
es: The only thing you're missing is a gun, a good belly, and three ex-wives.

en: So what’s your theory?”
vi: So what's your hypothesis?"
tr: So, what's your theory?"
es: What's your theory?

en: “I’m worried that she might have, um, I guess killed herself.”
vi: "It's possible that Margo, um, I'm afraid she might have committed suicide."
tr: “I am worried that he might have, umm, killed himself.”
es: —I'm worried that he might have... well, that he might have committed suicide, I suppose.

en: “It never crossed my mind this girl did anything but run off, kid.
vi: “In my mind, I always believed that the girl just ran away, son.
tr: “The thought that this girl did anything other than run away never even crossed my mind, son.
es: —It has never crossed my mind that this girl did anything other than run away, boy.

en: I can see your case, but you gotta remember she’s done this before.
vi: I understand your reasoning, but you should also remember that the girl has behaved like this before.
tr: I can understand her situation, but you must remember that she has done this before.
es: I understand what you're telling me, but remember that she has done it before.

en: The clues, I mean.
vi: I mean the clues that were left behind.
tr: Clues... add excitement to this whole endeavor.
es: I'm referring to the clues.

en: Adds drama to the whole enterprise.
vi: Adding more drama to the whole process.
tr: Clues... add excitement to this whole endeavor.
es: She adds a bit of drama that way.

en: Honestly, kid, if she wanted you to find her—dead or alive—you already would have.”
vi: Honestly, son, if Margo wants you to find her—alive or dead—then you will find her.”
tr: Honestly, son, if she wanted you to find herdead or aliveyou would have found her by now.”
es: Honestly, if she had wanted you to find her, alive or dead, you would have found her by now.

en: “But don’t you—”
vi: “But you don't–”
tr: “But you too...”
es: —But didn't you…?

en: “Kid, the unfortunate thing is that she’s a legal adult with free will, you know?
vi: "Son, the unfortunate thing is that Margo is already a legally recognized adult, with a free will, you understand?
tr: “Child, the unfortunate thing is that he is legally an adult with free will.
es: —Boy, we have the bad luck that legally she is an adult and free, you know?

en: Let me give you some advice: let her come home.
vi: My advice to you is this: let her come back on her own."
tr: Let me give you some advice: Let him come home.
es: Allow me to give you some advice: wait for her to come back.

en: I mean, at some point, you gotta stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days you’ll look back down and see that you floated away, too.”
vi: "What I mean is that eventually, you will stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days, you will look down and realize that you yourself have drifted away."
tr: At some point, you will have to stop looking at the sky, or one day you will look down and see that you have flown away too.”
es: Well, at some point you'll stop looking at the sky, or one of these days you'll look down and see that you too have flown away.

en: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth—I realized it wasn’t Warren’s poetry that would take me to Margo.
vi: I put the phone down with an uncomfortable feeling in my mouth—I realized that Dr. Warren's poetic substance would not lead me to Margo.
tr: I hung up the phone with a bad taste in my mouth... I had realized that what would lead me to Margo was not Warren's poem.
es: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth. It was clear that what would lead me to Margo would not be Warren's poetry.

en: I kept thinking about those lines at the end Margo had underlined: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.”
vi: I pondered over the last lines that Margo had underlined: "I give myself back to the earth, nourishing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under your boot-soles."
tr: I kept thinking about the lines Margo had underlined at the end: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles.”
es: I kept thinking about the final verses that Margo had marked: "Let the mud be my heir, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the sole of your shoes."

en: That grass, Whitman writes in the first few pages, is “the beautiful uncut hair of graves.”
vi: That grass, Whitman wrote in the first pages, is "the beautiful uncut hair of graves."
tr: According to what Whitman wrote in the first few pages, that grass was the “beautiful uncut hair of graves.”
es: In the first pages, Whitman writes that this grass, this herb, is "the loose and beautiful hair of graves."

en: But where were the graves?
vi: But where are the graves?
tr: But where were the graves?
es: But where were the graves?

en: Where were the paper towns?
vi: Where are the paper towns?
tr: Where were the paper towns?
es: Where were the paper towns?

en: I logged onto Omnictionary to see if it knew anything more about the phrase “paper towns” than I did.
vi: I logged into the Encyclopedia of Everything to see if there was any information about "paper towns" that I didn't know.
tr: “Paper towns” sözü hakkında benden daha fazla bir şey bilip bilmediğini görmek için Omnictionary’ye girdim.
es: I entered the Omnictionary to see if anything more was known about the expression "paper towns."

en: They had an extremely thoughtful and helpful entry created by a user named skunkbutt: “A Paper Town is a town that’s got a paper mill in it.”
vi: There was an extremely insightful and useful entry from a user named mongchonhoi: "A Paper Town is a town where there is a paper mill."
tr: Kokarcakıç adlı bir kullanıcı tarafından yaratılmış, aşırı derecede düşünceli ve yararlı bir girdi vardı: “Paper Town, içinde kâğıt fabrikası olan bir şehirdir.”
es: I found an enormously detailed and useful entry created by a user named skunkbutt: "A Paper Town is a town with a paper factory."

en: This was the shortcoming of Omnictionary: the stuff written by Radar was thorough and extremely helpful; the unedited work of skunk-butt left something to be desired.
vi: This is the downside of the Encyclopedia of Everything: the things Radar writes are extremely detailed and absolutely useful; while mongchonhoi's crude work only teases the issue, leaving people wanting more.
tr: Bu Omnictionary’nin kusuruydu: Radar tarafından yazılan şeyler eksiksiz ve aşırı derecede yararlıydı; kokarcakıç’ın editlenmemiş yazısıysa hiç tatmin edici değildi.
es: That was the flaw of the Omnictionary: the entries written by Radar were exhaustive and tremendously useful, but the one by this skunkbutt left much to be desired.

en: But when I searched the whole Web, I found something interesting buried forty entries down on a forum about real estate in Kansas.
vi: But when I searched more broadly across the internet, I found about forty interesting entries, buried deep within a real estate forum in Kansas.
tr: Ama bütün interneti taradığımda, Kansas’taki gayrimenkullerle ilgili bir forumda yaklaşık kırk girdi alta gömülmüş ilginç bir şey buldum.
es: But when I searched the web in general, I found something interesting hidden among the entries of a forum about real estate properties in Kansas.

en: Looks like Madison Estates isn’t going to get built; my husband and I bought property there, but someone called this week to say they’re refunding us our deposit because they didn’t presell enough houses to finance the project.

en: The conclusion seemed inescapable.
vi: It seemed impossible to avoid that outcome.
tr: The outcome seemed inevitable; despite everything that had broken inside her and all the decisions she had made, Margo had not accepted disappearing forever.
es: The conclusion seemed irrefutable.

en: Even with everything broken and decided inside her, she couldn’t quite allow herself to disappear for good.
vi: Even though everything inside her had shattered and reached a verdict, Margo seemingly did not allow herself to disappear forever.
tr: The outcome seemed inevitable; despite everything that had broken inside her and all the decisions she had made, Margo had not accepted disappearing forever.
es: Although everything inside her had broken and she had made her decision, she did not allow herself to disappear forever, so she had decided to leave her body —leave it to me— in a gloomy version of our neighborhood, where the first threads had broken.

en: And she had decided to leave her body—to leave it for me—in a shadow version of our subdivision, where her first strings had broken.
vi: And she decided to leave her body behind–leave it for me–in the guise of our ghost town, where her first threads had snapped.
tr: And she had decided not to leave her body in an imaginary version of our neighborhood where the first ties had broken.
es: Although everything inside her had broken and she had made her decision, she did not allow herself to disappear forever, so she had decided to leave her body —leave it to me— in a gloomy version of our neighborhood, where the first threads had broken.

en: She had said she didn’t want her body found by random kids—and it made sense that out of everyone she knew, she would pick me to find her.
vi: Margo had said that she didn't want her body to be found by random children–and it could be understood that among those who knew her, Margo would choose me to be the one to find her.
tr: She had said she didn't want her body to be found by random children... and it made sense that she had chosen me to find her among all her acquaintances.
es: She had said that she didn't want any child to find her body, and it seemed logical that, of all the people she knew, she chose me to find it.

en: She wouldn’t be hurting me in a new way.

es: It wouldn't hurt me as much because it wouldn't be new to me.

es: But I couldn't calm down, so I called Ben from the bed and told him my theory.

en: “Whatever, it’s a little lame of her to, like, hijack the last three weeks of high school, you know?

es: I wanted to laugh at him for using chat acronyms IRL, but I didn't have the strength.

en: After I hung up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of pseudovisions in Florida.
vi: After hanging up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of ghost towns in Florida.
tr: After hanging up the phone with Ben, I went back online to search for a list of neighborhoods in Florida.
es: I hung up and went back online in search of a list of Florida's pseudo-visions.

en: I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching “abandoned subdivisions” and “Grovepoint Acres” and the like for a while, I managed to compile a list of five places within three hours of Jefferson Park.
vi: I didn't find any such list, but after searching for "abandoned subdivisions" and "Grovepoint Acres," something similar, I gathered a list of five locations within about a three-hour drive from Jefferson Park.
tr: I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching for a while with terms like “abandoned neighborhoods” and “Grovepoint Acres,” I managed to list five places located within a three-hour distance from Jefferson Park.
es: I couldn't find it anywhere, but after typing "abandoned developments," "Grovepoint Acres," and things like that for a while, I managed to get a list of five places less than three hours from Jefferson Park.

en: I printed out a map of Central Florida, tacked the map to the wall above my computer, and then added a tack for each of the five locations.
vi: I printed out a map of Central Florida, pinned it to the wall above my computer, and marked those five places with pushpins.
tr: I printed out a map of Central Florida and pinned it to the wall above my computer, then added a pin for each of the five places.
es: I printed a map of central Florida, pinned it to the wall above the computer, and put a pin in each of the five locations.

en: Looking at the map, I could detect no pattern among them.
vi: Looking at the map, I didn't see any connection.
tr: Looking at the map, I couldn’t find any connection between them.
es: At first glance, I didn't detect the slightest connection between them.

en: They were randomly distributed among the far-flung suburbs, and it would take me at least a week to get to all of them.
vi: Those locations were scattered in remote suburbs, and it would probably take at least a week to visit them all.
tr: They were randomly scattered across remote outskirts, and reaching each of them would take at least It would take my whole week.
es: They were randomly scattered among the farthest developments, so I would need at least a week to visit them all.

en: Why hadn’t she left me a specific place?
vi: Why didn't Margo narrow it down to a specific area for me?
tr: Why hadn't he specified a particular place for me?
es: Why hadn't he left me a specific place?

en: All these scary-as-hell clues.
vi: All these creepy-to-the-point-of-gross clues.
tr: All these hellish, terrifying clues.
es: Several damn sinister clues, several hints of tragedy, but not a single place.

en: All this intimation of tragedy.
vi: All this proximity to disaster.
tr: All these implications of tragedy.
es: Several damn sinister clues, several hints of tragedy, but not a single place.

en: But no place.
vi: But not a single place.
tr: But there was no place.
es: Several damn sinister clues, several hints of tragedy, but not a single place.

en: Nothing to hold on to.
vi: Nothing to hold on to.
tr: There was nothing to hold on to.
es: Nothing to hold on to.

en: Like trying to climb a mountain of gravel.
vi: Like having to climb a mountain full of loose rocks.
tr: It was like trying to climb a mountain made of pebbles.
es: Like trying to climb a gravel mountain.

en: Ben gave me permission to borrow RHAPAW the next day, since he was going to be driving around, prom shopping with Lacey in her SUV.
vi: The next day, Ben lent me RHAPAW because he would be driving Lacey's SUV around to shop for the graduation party.
tr: The next day, since Ben would be driving around in Lacey's jeep for prom shopping, he allowed me to borrow SESIB.
es: Ben gave me permission to take the Chuco the next day, because he was going shopping with Lacey in his SUV.

en: So for once I didn’t have to sit outside the band room—the seventh-period bell rang and I raced out to his car.
vi: So this time I didn't have to wait outside the music room–as soon as the bell rang to end the seventh period, I dashed to the car.
tr: So, for the first time, I didn't have to sit outside the band room... the seventh bell rang, and I ran to Ben's car.
es: So for once, I didn't have to wait at the rehearsal room door. The bell rang and I ran to his car.

en: I lacked Ben’s talent for getting RHAPAW to start, so I was one of the first people to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but finally the engine caught, and I was off to Grovepoint Acres.
vi: But I couldn't start RHAPAW as easily as Ben, so even though I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot, I was one of the last to leave. Eventually, the engine did start, and I headed straight to Grovepoint Acres.
tr: Since I lacked the ability to start Ben's SESIB, I was one of the first to reach the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but I finally got the engine running and headed towards Grovepoint Acres.
es: Since I didn't have Ben's talent for starting the Chuco, I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but in the end, the engine caught and I set off towards Grovepoint Acres.

en: I drove out of town on Colonial, driving slowly, watching for any other pseudovisions I might have missed online.
vi: I drove along Colonial Road, slowly driving to see if there was any ghost town I had missed when searching online.
tr: Driving slowly out of the city on Colonial Boulevard, I kept an eye out for other neighborhoods I might have missed on the internet.
es: I drove slowly through Colonial, looking for other pseudovisions that might have escaped me in the net.

en: A long line of cars trailed behind me, and I felt anxious about holding them up; I marveled at how I could still have room to worry about such petty, ridiculous crap as whether the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an excessively cautious driver.
vi: A long line of cars followed behind my car. I felt a bit flustered seeing that scene, then immediately admired myself for still having the energy to worry about such childish, trivial, and silly things: wondering if the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver, driving as slow as a turtle.
tr: A long line of cars formed behind me, and I felt uneasy for delaying them; I marveled at how I still had room to worry about such trivial, ridiculous things, like whether the man in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver.
es: There was a long line of cars behind me, and I was anxious thinking that I was creating a traffic jam. I was surprised that I could still worry about insignificant and ridiculous bullshit like whether the guy in the car behind me thought I was driving too cautiously.

en: I wanted Margo’s disappearance to change me; but it hadn’t, not really.
vi: I had hoped that Margo's disappearance would change me; but it didn't change much, not significantly.
tr: I wished Margo's disappearance had changed me, but it hadn't, not exactly.
es: I would have liked Margo's disappearance to have changed me, but the truth was that it hadn't.

en: As the line of cars snaked behind me like some kind of unwilling funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to her.
vi: When the line of cars behind kept stretching out like an unwilling funeral procession, I realized I was speaking loudly to her.
tr: As the line of cars snaked behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to Margo.
es: While the line of cars crawled behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking to Margo out loud.

en: I will play out the string.
vi: I will follow the connection.
tr: I will pull all the strings.
es: «I will follow the thread.

en: I will not betray your trust.
vi: I will not betray your trust.
tr: I will not break your trust.
es: I will not betray your trust.

en: I will find you.
vi: I will find you.
tr: I will find you.
es: I will find you».

en: Talking like this to her kept me calm, strangely.
vi: Strangely, speaking out loud like that made me calmer.
tr: Strangely, talking to him this way calmed me down.
es: As strange as it may seem, speaking to her out loud calmed me.

en: It kept me from imagining the possibilities.
vi: I no longer conjured up hypotheses.
tr: It prevented me from imagining the possibilities.
es: It prevented me from imagining the various possibilities.

en: I came again to the sagging wooden sign for Grovepoint Acres.
vi: Passing the old wooden sign that read Grovepoint Acres again, I almost heard a sigh of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the paved dead-end road.
tr: I arrived again at the crooked, wooden Grovepoint Acres sign.
es: I reached the worn wooden sign of Grovepoint Acres.

en: I could almost hear the sighs of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road.
vi: Passing the old wooden sign that read Grovepoint Acres again, I almost heard a sigh of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the paved dead-end road.
tr: As I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road, I could almost hear the sighs of relief from those behind me.
es: I almost heard the sighs of relief from those following me when I turned left onto the dead-end paved road.

en: It looked like a driveway without a house.
vi: It looked like a path that didn't lead to any house.
tr: It looked like a driveway without a house.
es: It seemed like an access road to a house but without a house.

en: I left RHAPAW running and got out.
vi: I let RHAPAW run the entire length of that road.
tr: I left the SESIB running and got out.
es: I left the Chuco running and got out.

en: From close up, I could see that Grovepoint Acres was more finished than it initially appeared.
vi: Up close, Grovepoint Acres seemed more complete than it initially appeared.
tr: Up close, the Grovepoint Acres’ initially I could see that it was more completed than it appeared.
es: As I approached, I saw that Grovepoint Acres was more rundown than it initially appeared.

en: Two dirt roads ending in cul-de-sacs had been cut into the dusty ground, although the roads had eroded so much I could barely see their outlines.
vi: Two dirt roads led into a cul-de-sac, intersecting each other into dusty patches. Although the roads were heavily eroded, I could still faintly see the edges.
tr: Two dirt roads that ended in dead ends were dug into the dusty ground; although the roads were quite worn, I could barely see their outlines.
es: They had opened two dead-end dirt roads in the ground, although they had eroded so much that the outlines were barely visible.

en: As I walked up and down both streets, I could feel the heat in my nose with each breath.
vi: Walking back and forth on those two streets, I felt the heat emanating from my nostrils with each breath.
tr: As I walked back and forth on both roads, I could feel the warmth in my nose with every breath.
es: I walked up and down the two streets, feeling the heat in my nose with each breath.

en: The scalding sun made it hard to move, but I knew the beautiful, if morbid, truth: heat made death reek, and Grovepoint Acres smelled like nothing except cooked air and car exhaust—our cumulative exhalations held close to the surface by the humidity.
vi: The sun was scorching, making the walk quite tiring, but I understood a beautiful, albeit slightly foolish, truth: the heat would force the smell of death to rise, and Grovepoint Acres only emitted the scent of heated air and car exhaust—the accumulated emissions pushed down close to the ground by the humidity.
tr: The scorching sun made it difficult to move, but I knew the truth that felt good despite being a bit sickly: The heat smelled of death, and Grovepoint Acres smelled of nothing but cooked air and car exhaust...
es: The scorching sun made movement difficult, but I knew the pretty, though macabre, truth: heat makes the dead stink, and Grovepoint Acres only smelled of hot air and exhaust fumes. The humidity caused the accumulation of exhalations to linger in the air around me.

en: I looked for evidence she had been there: footprints or something written in the dirt or some memento.
vi: I searched for evidence that Margo had been here: footprints, something written on the ground, or some kind of memento.
tr: I searched for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or a keepsake.
es: I looked for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or anything she might have left behind, but it seemed like I was the first person to walk those nameless streets in years.

en: But I seemed to be the first person to walk on these unnamed dirt streets in years.
vi: But it seemed that after many years, I was the first person to set foot on these nameless dusty streets.
tr: But I seemed to be the first person to walk these nameless dirt roads in years.
es: I looked for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or anything she might have left behind, but it seemed like I was the first person to walk those nameless streets in years.

en: The ground was flat, and not much brush had grown back yet, so I could see for a ways in every direction.
vi: The ground was flat, and the shrubs had not grown much, so I could see in all directions.
tr: The ground was flat and not many bushes had grown yet, so I could see quite far in every direction.
es: The ground was flat and not much grass had grown yet, so I had a clear view in all directions.

en: No tents.
vi: No tents.
tr: There was no tent.
es: I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.

en: No campfires.
vi: No signs of fire.
tr: There was no campfire.
es: I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.

en: No Margo.
vi: No Margo.
tr: There was no Margo.
es: I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.

en: I got back in RHAPAW and drove to I-4 and then went northeast of town, up to a place called Holly Meadows.
vi: I turned back to RHAPAW, drove onto the I-4 highway, and then headed northeast of the city to a place called Holly Meadows.
tr: I went back to SESIB and drove to I4, then went to a place called Holly Meadows in the northeast of the city.
es: I returned to Chuco, headed to I-4, and turned northeast of the city, towards a place called Holly Meadows.

en: I drove past Holly Meadows three times before I finally found it—everything in the area was oak trees and ranch land, and Holly Meadows—lacking a sign at its entrance—didn’t stand out much.
vi: I drove past Holly Meadows three times before actually finding it—the entire area was just oak trees and vacant land, and Holly Meadows—with no sign at the entrance—wasn't very noticeable.
tr: I passed by Holly Meadows three times until I finally found it... The only things around were oak trees and farmland, and Holly Meadows, which had no sign at its entrance, didn't stand out much.
es: I passed it by three times before finally finding it, because the whole area was surrounded by oaks and ranches, and since there was no sign indicating the entrance, Holly Meadows was not visible.

en: But once I drove a few feet down a dirt road through the initial roadside stand of oak and pine trees, it was every bit as desolate as Grovepoint Acres.
vi: I drove a few meters along the dirt road through the first cluster of oak and pine trees, and this place seemed no less desolate than Grovepoint Acres.
tr: But as soon as I moved a few meters along the dirt road branching off from the first road with oak and pine trees, the place became as desolate as Grovepoint Acres.
es: But as soon as I advanced a few meters on an unpaved road between the oaks and pines, everything appeared as desolate as in Grovepoint Acres.

en: The main dirt road just slowly evaporated into a field of dirt.
vi: The main dirt road gradually blurred into a field of soil.
tr: The main dirt road slowly evaporated and turned into a dirt field.
es: The main road slowly dissolved into a dirt terrain.

en: There were no other roads that I could make out, but as I walked around, I did find a few spray-painted wooden stakes lying on the ground; I guessed that they had once been lot line markers.
vi: I didn't see any other roads, but as I went around, I did see some painted wooden stakes lying scattered on the ground; they probably once marked the boundaries.
tr: I couldn't see any other road, but while walking around, I found a few spray-painted wooden stakes on the ground; I guessed they were once boundary markers for the plots.

en: I couldn’t smell or see anything suspicious, but even so I felt a fear standing on my chest, and at first I couldn’t understand why, but then I saw it: when they’d clear-cut the area to build, they’d left a solitary live oak tree near the back of the field.
vi: I didn't smell or detect anything suspicious, yet I still felt a fear rising in my chest. At first, I didn't understand why, but then I realized: when they cleared the land for construction, they left a single oak tree at the far end of the field.
