en: And the gnarled tree with its thick-barked branches looked so much like the one where we’d found Robert Joyner in Jefferson Park that I felt sure she was there, on the other side of the tree.
vi: And the twisted trunk with its thick bark looked very much like the tree from long ago in Jefferson Park, where we had found Robert Joyner, so much so that I was almost certain Margo was there, behind the trunk.

en: And for the first time, I had to picture it: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against the tree, her eyes silent, the black blood pouring out of her mouth, everything bloated and distorted because I had taken so long to find her.
vi: And for the first time, I had to imagine this: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against a tree, her eyes vacant, black blood pouring from her mouth, everything swollen and deformed because I had taken too long to find her.
tr: I had to bring that moment to my mind for the first time: Margo Itoth Spiegelman, leaning against the trunk of the tree, her eyes dull, black blood flowing from her mouth, her whole body swollen and decomposed because it took me so long to find her.
es: And for the first time, I had to imagine it: Margo Roth Spiegelman collapsed on the tree, her eyes silent, dark blood coming out of her mouth, all swollen and deformed because it had taken too long to find her.

vi: I almost wanted to be glad that it wasn't this place.
tr: I wanted to be happy that it wasn’t the place.
es: I wanted to be glad that it wasn't there.

en: But if it wasn’t Quail Hollow, it would be the next place, or the one after that, or the one after that.
vi: But if it's not Quail Hollow, then it could be the next location, or the one after that, or the one after that again.
tr: But if it wasn’t Quail Hollow, it would be the next place or the one after that or the one after that...
es: But if it wasn't Quail Hollow, it would be the next one, or the next one, or the next one.

en: Or maybe I’d never find her.
vi: Or maybe I will never find Margo.
tr: Or maybe I would never find her.
es: Or maybe I would never find it.

en: Was that the better fate?
vi: Is that a better fate?
tr: Was that a better fate?
es: Was that the best thing that could happen?

en: I finished my rounds, finding nothing, and headed back toward the highway.
vi: In conclusion, there was nothing at Quail Hollow, so I got back on the highway.
tr: I finished my patrol without finding anything and returned to the main road.
es: I finished the round without having found anything and returned to the highway.

en: I got lunch at a drive-thru and then ate as I drove out west toward the minimall.
vi: I bought lunch at a drive-in, eating while driving west, heading to the mini shopping center from the other day.
tr: I got lunch from a place that serves cars, then ate it while driving west towards the small shopping mall.
es: I bought something to eat at a drive-thru restaurant and ate while driving west, towards the small abandoned shopping center.

tr: I got lunch from a place that serves cars, then ate it while driving west towards the small shopping mall.

en: As I pulled into the minimall parking lot, I noticed that blue painters’ tape had been used to seal our hole in the board.
vi: When I pulled into the parking lot next to the mini shopping area, I noticed that someone had covered the hole we made in the plywood the other day with thick blue tape.
tr: As I was pulling into the parking lot of the small shopping center, I noticed that blue electrical tape was used to cover the hole we had made in our sign.
es: Upon entering the parking lot, I noticed that they had covered the hole we had made in the particle board with blue adhesive tape.

en: I wondered who could have been there after us.
vi: I wonder who was here after we left.
tr: I wondered who could have come here after us.
es: I wondered who had been there after us.

en: I drove around to the back and parked the minivan next to a rusted Dumpster that hadn’t encountered a garbage truck in decades.
vi: I drove to the back, parked next to a large rusty dumpster that hadn't seen a garbage truck in decades.
tr: I drove around and moved the car to the back, parking the minivan next to a shabby dumpster that hadn't encountered a garbage truck in decades.
es: I drove the car to the back and parked next to a rusty dumpster that hadn't seen a garbage truck in decades.

en: I figured I could bust through the painters’ tape if I needed to, and I was walking around toward the front when I noticed that the steel back doors to the stores didn’t have any visible hinges.
vi: I figured if necessary, I would just push through the tape, so I started to walk around to the front but then noticed that the metal back doors weren't attached to any hinges.
tr: I thought I could pierce through the electrical tape if necessary; I was heading towards the front when I noticed that the steel back doors leading to the stores had no visible hinges.
es: I figured I could slip through the adhesive tape if necessary, and I was heading towards the facade when I noticed that the steel doors at the back of the stores didn't have visible hinges.

en: I’d learned a thing or two about hinges thanks to Margo, and I realized why we hadn’t had any luck pulling on all those doors: they opened in.
vi: Thanks to Margo, I gained a bit of expertise about door hinges and realized why the three of us couldn't pull those doors open: because they all opened inward.
tr: Thanks to Margo, I had learned a thing or two about hinges and realized why we never had any luck pulling all those doors: They opened inward.
es: Thanks to Margo, I had learned a couple of things about hinges, so I understood why we hadn't had any luck pulling on those doors: they opened inward.

en: I walked up to the door to the mortgage company office and pushed.
vi: I went to the office door of the mortgage company and pushed in.
tr: I went to the mortgage company's office and pushed the door.
es: I approached the door of the mortgage company's office and pushed.

en: It opened with no resistance whatsoever.
vi: The door swung open effortlessly.
tr: It opened without any resistance.
es: It opened without the slightest resistance.

en: God, we were such idiots.
vi: My God, the other day all three of us were really clueless.
tr: God, we were so stupid.
es: Damn, we were such idiots.

en: Surely, whoever cared for the building knew about the unlocked door, which made the painters’ tape seem even more out of place.
vi: Surely someone concerned about this building already knew about the unlocked door, so the blue tape on the other side seemed even more redundant.
tr: Surely whoever was in charge of the building was aware of the unlocked door, which made the electrical tape even more pointless.
es: Undoubtedly, the person in charge of the building knew that the door wasn't locked, which made the adhesive tape seem even more out of place.

en: I wiggled out of the backpack I’d packed that morning and pulled out my dad’s high-powered Maglite and flashed it around the room.
vi: I dropped the backpack I had packed since the morning, took out my dad's high-powered Maglite flashlight, and shone it around the room.
tr: I took out the backpack I had prepared that morning and lit up the room with my dad's high-powered Maglite.
es: I took off the backpack I had prepared in the morning, took out my father's powerful flashlight, and shone the light around the entire room.

en: Something sizable in the rafters scurried.
vi: It seemed like something large had just scurried away among the beams on the roof.
tr: Something rather large quickly fled from the roof beam.
es: Something of considerable size ran across the beams.

en: I shivered.
vi: I shivered.
tr: I shuddered.
es: I shuddered.

en: Little lizards jump-ran through the path of the light.
vi: Some small lizards jumped into the dark corner, avoiding the path of the light.
tr: Small lizards scurried away, jumping from the places illuminated by the light.
es: Several lizards moved in the beam of light.

en: A single shaft of light from a hole in the ceiling shone in the front corner of the room, and sunlight peeked out from behind the particleboard, but I mostly relied on the flashlight.
vi: The only beam of light through a hole in the ceiling fell into the front corner of the room, and a bit of sunlight peeked through the plywood, but I mostly relied on the flashlight.
tr: A single beam of light coming from the hole in the ceiling illuminated the front corner of the room, and sunlight was seeping in from behind the chipboard, but I mostly relied on the flashlight.
es: A single ray of light could be seen coming from a hole in the ceiling, in the front corner of the room, and some light filtered in from the other side of the conglomerate, but it practically depended on the flashlight.

en: I walked up and down the rows of desks, looking at the items we’d found in the drawers, which we’d left.
vi: I walked back and forth through the rows of tables, looking at the things we had seen in the drawers and left behind.
tr: I walked back and forth among the rows of desks, looking at the items we found in the drawers and left there.
es: I walked through the rows of tables observing the objects we had found in the drawers and had left there.

en: It was profoundly creepy to see desktop after desktop with the same unmarked calendar: February 1986.
vi: A creepy feeling surged up terribly as I looked from table to table, each one holding a calendar page without any notes: February 1986.
tr: Seeing the same unmarked calendar on the desks one after another was chilling enough to seep into one's soul: February 1986.
es: It was absolutely creepy to see table after table with the same calendar: February 1986.

en: February 1986.
vi: February 1986. February 1986. June 1986.
tr: February 1986. February 1986. June 1986.
es: February 1986. February 1986. June 1986.

en: February 1986.
vi: February 1986.
tr: February 1986.
es: February 1986.

en: June 1986.
vi: February 1986.
tr: February 1986.
es: February 1986.

en: February 1986.
vi: February 1986.
tr: February 1986.
es: February 1986.

en: I spun around and shone the light on a desk in the very center of the room.
vi: I turned around and shone the light on the table in the middle of the room.
tr: I turned around and shone the light on the desk in the very center of the room.
es: I turned and focused on a table located in the center of the room.

en: The calendar had been changed to June.
vi: The calendar was turned to June.
tr: The calendar had moved to June.
es: They had changed the calendar to June.

en: I leaned in close and looked at the paper of the calendar, hoping to see a jagged edge where previous months had been torn off, or some marks on the page where a pen had pushed through the paper, but there was nothing different from the other calendars, save the date.
vi: I leaned in closer and scrutinized the calendar page, hoping to see a ragged edge where the previous months had been torn off, or some mark on the paper indicating that a pen had passed over it, but there was nothing different from the other calendar pages, except the dates.
tr: I leaned in closer and looked at the calendar page, hoping to see a jagged edge where previous months had been torn off or some marks where a pen had left an impression on the paper, but there was nothing different from the other calendars, except for the date.
es: I leaned in and observed the calendar paper expecting to see the jagged block left after tearing off the pages, or some pen mark on the page, but the only difference from the other calendars was the date.

en: With the flashlight crooked between my neck and shoulder, I started to look through desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: some napkins, some still-sharp pencils, memos about mortgages addressed to one Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost-full bottle of red nail polish.
vi: Holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, I checked the drawers again, paying special attention to the June desk: a few napkins, some still-sharp pencils, notes on the mortgages of a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro cigarettes, and a nearly full bottle of red nail polish.
tr: With the flashlight wedged between my neck and shoulder, I began to carefully examine the desk drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: a few napkins, a few still sharp pencils, notes about mortgages addressed to someone named Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Lights, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.
es: I placed the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, and started searching the drawers again, paying special attention to the June table: napkins, sharpened pencils, mortgage reports addressed to a certain Dennis McMahon, an empty pack of Marlboro Light, and an almost full bottle of red nail polish.

en: I took the flashlight in one hand and the nail polish in the other and stared at it closely.
vi: I switched the flashlight to one hand, held the nail polish bottle in the other, and observed carefully.
tr: I took the flashlight in one hand and the nail polish in the other, and looked closely at the bottle.
es: I grabbed the flashlight with one hand, the nail polish with the other, and observed it closely.

en: So red it was almost black.
vi: The red color was so dark it almost looked black.
tr: It was so red that it was almost black.
es: It was so red that it almost looked black.

en: I’d seen this color before.
vi: I had seen this red color before.
tr: I had seen this color before.
es: I had seen that color before that night.

en: It had been on the minivan’s dash that night.
vi: On the dashboard of the minivan that night.
tr: This nail polish was on the panel of the minivan that night.
es: On the dashboard of the minivan.

en: Suddenly, the scurrying in the rafters and the creaking in the building became irrelevant—I felt a perverted euphoria.
vi: Suddenly, the large creatures lurking on the roof and the creaking sounds in the building no longer mattered–I just felt a strange exhilaration.
tr: Suddenly, the scurrying in the rafters and the creaking inside the building became insignificant... I felt a perverse excitement.
es: Suddenly, the running on the beams and the creaking of the building became irrelevant. I felt a perverse euphoria.

en: I couldn’t know if it was the same bottle, of course, but it was certainly the same color.
vi: Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle of polish, but it was definitely the same shade.
tr: Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, but it was definitely the same color.
es: I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, of course, but it was definitely the same color.

en: I rotated the bottle around and saw, unambiguously, a tiny smear of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle.
vi: I rotated the jar and saw, without a doubt, a tiny smudge of sky-blue paint on its surface.
tr: I turned the bottle around and saw, undeniably, the stain of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle.
es: I turned the jar and saw without the slightest doubt a tiny blue spray stain on the outside of the glass.

en: From her spray-painted fingers.
vi: Smeared from Margo's sky-blue paint-stained finger.
tr: It was coming from her spray-painted fingers.
es: From his spray-stained fingers.

en: I could be sure now.
vi: Now I could be certain.
tr: Now I could be sure.
es: Then I was sure.

en: She’d been here after we parted ways that morning.
vi: She had come here after we said goodbye that morning.
tr: After we parted ways that morning, Margo had come here.
es: He had been there after we parted that morning.

en: Maybe she was still staying here.
vi: Perhaps she was still here.
tr: Maybe she was still staying here.
es: Maybe he was still there.

en: Maybe she only showed up late at night.
vi: Perhaps she would only appear late at night.
tr: Maybe she only appeared late at night.
es: Maybe he only came out at night.

en: Maybe she had taped up the particleboard to keep her privacy.
vi: Perhaps she had taped the plywood to maintain her privacy.
tr: Maybe she had taped the sign to protect her privacy.
es: Maybe he had put the tape on the conglomerate to maintain privacy.

en: I resolved right then to stay until morning.
vi: I immediately decided that I would stay here until morning.
tr: At that moment, I made a firm decision to stay there until morning.
es: At that moment, I decided to stay until the next day.

en: If Margo had slept here, I could, too.
vi: If Margo could sleep in this place, then I could sleep too.
tr: If Margo had slept here, I could sleep too.
es: If Margo had slept there, I could do it too.

en: And thus commenced a brief conversation with myself.
vi: And thus, a brief self-examination took place.
tr: Thus, a brief conversation began between myself and me.
es: And so began a brief conversation with myself.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Me: There are still those rats.
tr: Ben: But mice.
es: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Yeah, but they seem to stay in the ceiling.
vi: Me: Yeah, but it seems like they only parade on the ceiling.
tr: Ben: Yes, but they look like they're melting on the ceiling.
es: Me: Yes, but it seems they stay on the roof.

en: Me: But the lizards.
vi: Me: More lizards.
tr: Ben: But lizards.
es: Me: But there are lizards.

en: Me: Oh, come on.
vi: Me: More lizards.
tr: Ben: Oh, come on.
es: Me: Oh, come on.

en: You used to pull their tails off when you were little.
vi: Me: Oh well, when I was a kid, I used to pull off lizard tails.
tr: When you were little, you used to pull off my tails.
es: When you were little, you used to cut off their tails.

en: You’re not scared of lizards.
vi: What is the lizard afraid of?
tr: You're not afraid of lizards.
es: Lizards don't scare you.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Me: But what about the mouse?
tr: Ben: But mice.
es: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Rats can’t really hurt you anyway.
vi: Me: After all, who can a mouse hurt?
tr: Ben: Mice can't really hurt you anyway.
es: Me: But the rats can't hurt you.

en: They’re more scared of you than you are of them.
vi: Mice are more afraid of us than we are of them.
tr: They are more afraid of you than you are of them.
es: You scare them more than they scare you.

en: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?
vi: Me: Well, what about the rats?
tr: Ben: But what about the mice?
es: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?

en: Me: Shut up.
vi: Me: Stop it right now.
tr: Ben: Shut your mouth.
es: Me: Shut up.

en: In the end, the rats didn’t matter, not really, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive.
vi: In the end, the actual rats didn't really matter because I was where Margo had been.
tr: In the end, the mice didn't matter much because I was in a place where Margo was alive.
es: In the end, it didn't matter that there were rats, at least not much, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive.

en: I was in a place that saw her after I did, and the warmth of that made the minimall almost comfortable.
vi: I was in a place that had seen her after I had seen her, and the warmth from that thought made this mini-mall almost pleasant.
tr: I was in a place where she had been seen after me, and the warmth of that made this small shopping mall almost comfortable.
es: I was in a place that had seen her after me, and that warmth made the mall an almost comfortable place.

en: I mean, I didn’t feel like an infant being held by Mommy or anything, but my breath had stopped catching each time I heard a noise.
vi: I didn't feel like a child, always having my mother close by, but I still held my breath whenever I heard a strange noise.
tr: So, I didn't feel like a baby being hugged by its mother or anything, but my breath no longer stopped every time I heard a sound.
es: Well, I didn't feel like a child in his mother's arms, but I no longer ran out of breath every time I heard a noise.

en: And in becoming comfortable, I found it easier to explore.
vi: And because of the pleasant feeling, this place became easier to explore.
tr: And being relaxed made it easier to do research.
es: And as I felt more comfortable, it became easier for me to explore.

en: I knew there was more to find, and now, I felt ready to find it.
vi: There was much to discover, and now, I was ready.
tr: I knew there was more to be found, and now I felt ready to find it.
es: I knew there were still things to find, and I was ready to find them.

en: I left the office, ducking through a Troll Hole into the room with the labyrinthine shelves.
vi: I left the office, crawled through a Devil's Hole into the maze-like room of iron shelves.
tr: I crawled out of the office through a Dwarf Hole leading to a room with labyrinth-like shelves.
es: I went through a Troll Hole and arrived at the labyrinth of shelves room.

en: I walked up and down the aisles for a while.
vi: I walked back and forth along the aisle between the rows of shelves for a moment, reached the end of the room, and through the next Devil's Hole into an empty room.
tr: I walked back and forth among them for a while.
es: I walked through the aisles for a good while.

en: At the end of the room I crawled through the next Troll Hole into the empty room.
vi: I walked back and forth along the aisle between the rows of shelves for a moment, reached the end of the room, and through the next Devil's Hole into an empty room.
tr: At the end of the room, I crawled through the next Dwarf Hole into an empty room.
es: Eventually, I went into the next Troll Hole and crawled to the empty room.

en: I sat down on the carpet rolled against the far wall.
vi: I sat down on the rolled-up carpet, leaning against the wall in the corner of the room.
tr: I sat on the rolled-up carpet in front of the opposite wall.
es: I sat on the rolled-up carpet against the back wall.

en: The cracked white paint crunched against my back.
vi: The patchy white paint behind me sounded more brittle and cracked.
tr: The cracked white paint crackled behind my back.
es: The chipped white paint creaked as I leaned my back against it.

en: I stayed there for a while, long enough that the jagged beam of light coming through a hole in the ceiling crept an inch along the floor as I let myself become accustomed to the sounds.
vi: I sat there for a while, long enough for the slanted beam of light from the ceiling to crawl a few inches across the floor, while I gradually adapted to the sounds.
tr: I stayed there for a while; long enough for the beam of light coming through the hole in the ceiling to shift a few centimeters on the floor as I let myself get used to the sounds.
es: I stayed there for a while, long enough for the jagged ray of light coming through a hole in the ceiling to move three centimeters across the floor as I got used to the sounds.

en: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole into the souvenir shop.
vi: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Ghost Hole into the souvenir room.
tr: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Dwarf Hole to the gift shop.
es: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole to the souvenir shop.

en: I rifled through the T-shirts.
vi: I browsed through the T-shirts.
tr: I quickly looked at the t-shirts.
es: I rummaged through the T-shirts.

en: I pulled the box of tourist brochures out from under the display case and looked through them, looking for some hand-scrawled message from Margo, but I found nothing.
vi: I pulled out the travel book box from under the display case and looked through it, searching to see if Margo had scribbled a few words, but I found nothing.
tr: I pulled the box of tourist brochures from under the display and examined the brochures, looking for a handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.
es: I took the box of tourist brochures from the display case and leafed through them looking for any handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.

en: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library.
vi: I returned to the room I now call the library.
tr: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library.
es: I returned to the room that I found myself calling the library.

en: I thumbed through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was covered in so much dust that I knew Margo had never been inside it.
vi: Flipping through the pile of Reader’s Digest magazines, I found a stack of National Geographic issues from the 1960s. But these items were covered in layers of dust, so I knew Margo had never looked through them.
tr: I flipped through the pages of Reader’s Digest with my finger and found a stack of National Geographic from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that I knew Margo had never touched it.
es: I flipped through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that it was clear Margo hadn't taken out its contents.

en: I began to find evidence of human habitation only when I got back to the empty room.
vi: It wasn't until I returned to the empty room that I found evidence of human activity.
tr: However, when I returned to the empty room, I began to find evidence of human habitation.
es: I didn't start finding signs that someone had been there until I returned to the empty room.

en: On the wall with the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and paint-peeled wall.
vi: On the wall near the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine pinholes on the cracked and peeling painted surface.
tr: I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and peeling wall where a poster had been hung.
es: On the chipped wall of the carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes.

en: Four of the holes made an approximate square, and then there were five holes inside the square.
vi: Four holes formed a relatively square shape, and within that square, there were five more holes.
tr: Four of the holes formed a shape close to a square, and then five more were inside the square.
es: Four holes formed a sort of square, and the other five were inside the square.

en: I thought perhaps Margo had stayed here long enough to hang up some posters, although there were none obviously missing from her room when we searched it.
vi: I guessed that Margo had probably been here for quite a while, long enough to want to hang some kind of poster, although we didn't find anything missing when we searched her room.
tr: I thought that Margo might have stayed here long enough to hang a few posters, but when we searched, there was nothing noticeably missing from her room.
es: I thought that maybe Margo had spent enough time there to hang some posters, although at first glance it didn't seem like any were missing when we inspected her room.

en: I unrolled the carpet partway and immediately found something else: a flattened, empty box that had once contained twenty-four nutrition bars.
vi: I had spread the carpet halfway when I discovered something else: an empty, flat-folded box that had once contained twenty-four synthetic nutrition bars.
tr: I partially opened the drawer and found something else inside: a flattened, empty box that once contained twenty-four wafers.
es: I unrolled part of the carpet and immediately found something else: a crushed box that had once contained twenty-four cereal bars.

en: I found myself able to imagine Margo here, leaning against the wall with musty rolled-up carpet for a seat, eating a nutrition bar.
vi: I began to imagine Margo had been here, leaning against the wall, sitting on the musty rolled-up carpet, eating a nutrition bar.
tr: I could imagine Margo here, using the moldy carpet as a seat, leaning against the wall, and eating a wafer.
es: I found myself imagining Margo there, sitting on the rolled-up and moldy carpet, leaning against the wall and eating a cereal bar.

en: She is all alone, with only this to eat.
vi: She was completely alone, with only this to eat.
tr: Completely alone, with only these wafers as food.
es: She is alone and has nothing else to eat.

en: Maybe she drives once a day to a convenience store to buy a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but most of every day is spent here, on or near this carpet.
vi: Maybe every day Margo still drove to the convenience store to buy sandwiches and a few bottles of Mountain Dew, but most of the time she was here, on or near the carpet.
tr: Maybe she goes to a market once a day to get a sandwich and a few Mountain Dews, but she spends most of her days here, on or beside this carpet.
es: Maybe once a day she drives to a store to buy herself a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but she spends most of the day on this carpet or near it.

en: This image seemed too sad to be true—it all struck me as so lonely and so very unMargo.
vi: That image seemed too bleak to be true–it all conjured up in my mind a Margo who was too lonely and too unlike-Margo.
tr: This vision seemed too pitiful to be real... it struck me that all of this was very lonely and very unMargo-like.
es: It seemed too sad an image to be real. Too lonely and not at all like Margo.

en: But all the evidence of the past ten days accumulated toward a surprising conclusion: Margo herself was—at least part of the time—very unMargo.
vi: But all the evidence from the past ten days pointed to a surprising conclusion: Margo–at least at times–was very unlike Margo.
tr: But when all the evidence of the last ten days was accumulated, a surprising result emerged: even Margo herself was, at least sometimes, very unMargo-like.
es: But the clues from the last ten days seemed to lead to a surprising conclusion: Margo was —at least a good part of the time— very unlike Margo.

en: I rolled out the carpet farther and found a blue knit blanket, almost newspaper thin.
vi: I spread out the rest of the carpet and saw a sky-blue knitted wool blanket, thin almost like newspaper.
tr: I opened the carpet further and found an almost paper-thin blue knitted blanket.
es: I unrolled the carpet a bit more and found a blue knitted blanket, almost as thin as a newspaper.

en: I grabbed it and held it to my face and there, God, yes.
vi: I hurriedly grabbed it and brought it to my face, yes, thank God, that's right.
tr: I took the blanket and held it up to my face and there, my God, yes... Margo's scent.
es: I picked it up, brought it to my face and yes, yes.

en: Her smell.
vi: The scent of Margo.
tr: I took the blanket and held it up to my face and there, my God, yes... Margo's scent.
es: Its smell.

en: The lilac shampoo and the almond in her skin lotion and beneath all of that the faint sweetness of the skin itself.
vi: Lilac-scented shampoo and almond-scented lotion, with a faint sweetness of skin lingering within.
tr: Lilac shampoo, almond skin lotion, and beneath it all, the intoxicating sweetness of her skin.
es: The lilac shampoo and almond lotion, and beyond that, the faint softness of her skin.

en: And I could picture her again: she unravels the carpet halfway each night so her hip isn’t against bare concrete as she lies on her side.
vi: I imagine her again: every night Margo spreads this rug halfway so that her hip doesn't press against the hard concrete when she lies on her side.
tr: And I could picture her again: Every night she would roll the carpet halfway open, so that when she lay on her side, her hip wouldn't rest on the bare concrete.
es: And I imagined her again: she unrolls part of the carpet every night so she doesn't dig her hip into the concrete when she sleeps on her side.

en: She crawls beneath the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and sleeps.
vi: She curls up under this blanket, resting her head on the part of the rug that isn't fully spread out, and closes her eyes to sleep.
tr: She would crawl under the blanket, her honey uses the rest as a pillow and sleeps.
es: She gets under the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and falls asleep.

en: But why here?
vi: But why here?
tr: But why is she here?
es: But why here?

en: How is this better than home?
vi: What is better about this place than home?
tr: How could this place be better than home?
es: Why is it better here than at her house?

en: And if it’s so great, why leave?
vi: If she liked it here so much, why did she leave?
tr: And if it’s so great, why is she leaving?
es: And if it's so good, why leave?

en: These are the things I cannot imagine, and I realize that I cannot imagine them because I didn’t know Margo.
vi: Those things I can't imagine, I realize I can't imagine because I don't understand Margo.
tr: These are things I can’t imagine, and I realize that I can’t imagine them because I don’t know Margo.
es: That's what I couldn't imagine, and I realize that I couldn't imagine it because I didn't know Margo.

en: I knew how she smelled, and I knew how she acted in front of me, and I knew how she acted in front of others, and I knew that she liked Mountain Dew and adventure and dramatic gestures, and I knew that she was funny and smart and just generally more than the rest of us.
vi: I know how she smells, I know how she behaves in front of me, I know how she behaves in front of others, I know she likes Mountain Dew, likes adventure and dramatic games, I also know she is funny, smart, and generally superior to the rest of us.
tr: I knew how she smelled, I knew how she behaved in front of me, I knew how she behaved in front of others, I knew she loved Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, I knew she was fun, smart, and generally more than the rest of us.
es: I knew her smell, and I knew how she acted with me, and I knew how she acted with others, and I knew she liked Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, and I knew she was funny, smart, and generally superior to all of us.

en: But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave.
vi: But I don't know what brought Margo here, what made her stay here, what made her leave.
tr: But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave.
es: But I didn't know what had brought her there, or what had kept her there, or what had made her leave there.

en: I didn’t know why she owned thousands of records but never told anyone she even liked music.
vi: I don't know why she has thousands of records but never tells anyone how much she loves music.
tr: I didn’t know why she had thousands of records, yet never told anyone she loved music.
es: I didn't know why she had thousands of records, but had never told anyone she liked music.

en: I didn’t know what she did at night, with the shades down, with the door locked, in the sealed privacy of her room.
vi: I don't know what she does every night, behind the discreetly drawn curtains, behind the locked door, in the inviolable private space that is her room.
tr: I didn’t know what she did at night, with the blinds closed, the door locked, in the secret privacy of her room.
es: I didn't know what she did at night, in the dark, with the door closed, in the sealed privacy of her room.

en: And maybe this was what I needed to do above all.
vi: And perhaps more than anything, this is what I need to do.
tr: And maybe this was what I needed to do before anything else.
es: And maybe it was what I needed more than anything.

en: I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn’t being Margo.
vi: I need to find out what Margo is like when she is not being Margo.
tr: I needed to discover what Margo looked like when she wasn't being Margo.
es: I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn't being Margo.

en: I lay there with the her-scented blanket for a while, staring up at the ceiling.
vi: I lay there for a while in the blanket that smelled of Margo, staring up at the ceiling.
tr: I lay there for a while, staring at the ceiling with a blanket that smelled like him.
es: I lay down for a while with the blanket that smelled like her and looked at the ceiling.

en: I could see a sliver of late-afternoon sky through a crack in the roof, like a jagged canvas painted a bright blue.
vi: The twilight sky filtered through the crack in the roof, like a canvas torn to reveal a pale blue strip.
tr: Through a crack in the roof, I could see a thin piece of the sky in the afternoon, like a rough canvas painted bright blue.
es: Through a hole, I could see a small piece of the afternoon sky, like a jagged canvas painted blue.

en: This would be the perfect place to sleep: one could see stars at night without getting rained on.
vi: This must be the perfect place to fall asleep: at night, you can watch the stars without fearing the rain.
tr: This would be a perfect place to sleep: One could see the stars at night without getting rained on.
es: It was the perfect place to sleep. You could see the stars at night without getting wet if it rained.

en: I called my parents to check in.
vi: I called home to report my safety.
tr: I called my mom and dad to inform them.
es: I called my parents.

en: My dad answered, and I said we were in the car on the way to meet Radar and Angela, and that I was staying with Ben overnight.
vi: Dad answered the phone, I said we were in the car, on the way to Radar and Angela's place, and I would stay with Ben all night.
tr: My dad answered, I told him that we were on the road with Radar and Angela and that I would stay at Ben's place for the night.
es: My father answered, and I told him that we were in the car, that we were going to pick up Radar and Angela, and that I would stay with Ben all night.

en: He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn’t, and he said he was proud of me for going to prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for doing what I was actually doing.
vi: Dad told me not to drink recklessly, I replied I wouldn't, and he said he was very happy that I went to the prom. And I wondered if he would still be happy if he really knew what I was doing.
tr: He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for going to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for what I was actually doing.
es: He asked me not to drink, I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for deciding to go to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for deciding to do what I was actually doing.

en: This place was boring.
vi: This place is boring.
tr: This place was boring.
es: The place was a bore.

en: I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious the-building-is-falling-apart groans in the walls, there wasn’t anything to do.
vi: Once you've gotten the upper hand over the gang of rodents and deciphered the mysterious groans of the building-about-to-collapse echoing from the walls, there's nothing left to do.
tr: I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious "building is falling apart" creaks, there was nothing to do.
es: I mean that once you got past the rodents and the mysterious creaking of the walls, as if the building was about to collapse, there was nothing to do.

en: No Internet, no TV, no music.
vi: No Internet, no TV, no music.
tr: No internet, no television, no music.
es: No internet, no TV, no music.

en: I was bored, so it again confused me that she would pick this place, since Margo always struck me as a person with a very limited tolerance for boredom.
vi: I'm bored, so I don't understand why Margo chose this place; she always gave the impression that she had very little tolerance for boredom.
tr: I was bored, so the fact that he had chosen this place puzzled me again; because Margo had always caught my attention as a person with limited tolerance for boredom.
es: I was bored, so it kept puzzling me that she had chosen that place, because Margo had always seemed to me like someone with a very limited tolerance for boredom.

en: Maybe she liked the idea of slumming it?
vi: Or does she like this dilapidated scene?
tr: Did she like the idea of living in a ruin?
es: Maybe she liked the idea of living like a poor person.

en: Unlikely.
vi: Could it be.
tr: It was quite unlikely.
es: I doubt it.

en: Margo wore designer jeans to break into SeaWorld.
vi: With that Margo who wore stylish jeans to break into SeaWorld.
tr: Margo was wearing designer jeans while sneaking into SeaWorld.
es: Margo wore brand-name jeans when we snuck into SeaWorld.

en: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that led me back to “Song of Myself,” the only certain gift I had from her.
vi: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that brought me back to "Self-Elegy," the only certain gift I received from Margo.
tr: It was the lack of an alternative stimulus that brought me back to My Own Song, the only gift I received from it.
es: The absence of alternative stimuli led me back to "Song of Myself," the only gift that had undoubtedly been left for me.

en: I moved to a water-stained patch of concrete floor directly beneath the hole in the ceiling, sat down cross-legged, and angled my body so the light shone upon the book.
vi: I went to the floor, stained with long-dried water marks, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and leaned to let the light shine down on the page.
tr: I moved to a water-stained part of the concrete floor, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and adjusted my body angle so that the light would illuminate the book.
es: I moved to a spot on the cement floor that had water stains, directly under the hole in the roof, sat cross-legged, and tilted the book so that the ray of light fell directly on it.

en: And for some reason, finally, I could read it.
vi: In the end, somehow, I managed to read through it.
tr: And somehow, I was finally able to read the poem.
es: And for some reason, I was finally able to read it.

en: The thing is that the poem starts out really slowly—it’s just sort of a long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts to tell a bit of a story, and that’s where it picked up for me.
vi: The problem is that the poem starts extremely slowly—the introduction drags on and on, and it isn't until the ninth line that Whitman finally begins to reveal the story, and that's where I started to understand.
tr: The thing is, the poem starts very slowly... There is a kind of long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts telling a bit of a story, and this is where the poem picks up pace for me.
es: The thing is that the poem starts very slowly, with a sort of long introduction, but around verse ninety Whitman finally begins to tell a story, so I started from there.

en: So Whitman is sitting around (which he calls loafing) on the grass, and then:
vi: So Whitman is sitting idly (which he calls being at ease) on the grass, then:
tr: In the end, Whitman is sitting idly on the grass (which he calls loafing) and then:
es: Whitman is sitting on the grass (he says lying down), and then:

en: A child said, What is the grass?
vi: A child spoke up, What is grass?
tr: A child said, What is grass?
es: A child asked me: What is grass?, bringing it in handfuls,

en: fetching it to me with full
vi: and brought us a handful;
tr: bringing it to me in his hands;
es: A child asked me: What is grass?, bringing it in handfuls,

en: hands;
vi: and brought us a handful;
tr: bringing it to me in his hands;
es: A child asked me: What is grass?, bringing it in handfuls,

en: How could I answer the child?
vi: How should I answer the child?...
tr: How could I answer the child?
es: How could I answer him?

en: . . . . . . I do not know what
vi: I don't know much more than what the child knows.
tr: I don't know what it is
es: I don't know either.

en: it is any more than he.
vi: I don't know much more than what the child knows.
tr: more than him/her/it.
es: I don't know either.

en: I guess it must be the flag of my disposition, out of hopeful
vi: Perhaps that is surely our flag of virtue, woven with the color of hope.
tr: I suppose it must be a sign of my creation, emerging from the weave of promising greenery.
es: I suspect that it is the flag of my character woven with hopeful green fabric.

en: green stuff woven.
vi: Perhaps that is surely our flag of virtue, woven with the color of hope.
tr: I suppose it must be a sign of my creation, emerging from the weave of promising greenery.
es: I suspect that it is the flag of my character woven with hopeful green fabric.

en: There was the hope dr Holden had talked about—the grass was a metaphor for his hope.
vi: This is the hope that Ms. Holden mentioned–grass is a metaphor for hope.
tr: This was the hope that Dr. Holden talked about... The grass was a metaphor for Whitman's hope.
es: There was the hope that Dr. Holden had told me about. The grass was a metaphor for hope.

en: But that’s not all.
vi: But that's not all, the poet continues:
tr: But that's not all.
es: But that's not all.

en: He continues,
vi: But that's not all, the poet continues:
tr: It continues as follows:
es: It goes on to say:

en: Or I guess it is the handkerchief of the Lord,
vi: Or perhaps that is the handkerchief of the Person,
tr: Or maybe I think it's God's handkerchief,
es: Or the handkerchief of God,

en: A scented gift and remembrancer designedly dropped,
vi: The gift carries a fragrance, a keepsake bestowed by Him.
tr: A fragrant gift and a deliberately dropped keepsake,
es: a fragrant garment deliberately dropped,

en: Like grass is a metaphor for God’s greatness or something.
vi: It's like grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, and there's more...
tr: As if the grass is a metaphor for something like the grandeur of God...
es: The grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, or something like that.

vi: Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr: As if the grass is a metaphor for something like the grandeur of God...
es: The grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, or something like that.

en: Or I guess the grass is itself a child . . . .
vi: Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr: Or maybe I think the grass itself is a child...
es: Or I suspect that the grass itself is a child...

en: And then soon after that,
vi: And right after that,
tr: And a little after this,
es: And something later:

en: Or I guess it is a uniform hieroglyphic,
vi: Or perhaps grass is a uniform pictogram,
tr: Or perhaps I think it is a monotonous hieroglyph,
es: A uniform hieroglyph,

en: And it means, Sprouting alike in broad zones and narrow
vi: Rising up amidst the vast forest and from a limited corner,
tr: And this means to sprout in wide areas and narrow areas without discrimination,
es: what it means: I grow equally in the vast regions and in the narrow ones,

en: zones,
vi: Rising up amidst the vast forest and from a limited corner,
tr: And this means to sprout in wide areas and narrow areas without discrimination,
es: what it means: I grow equally in the vast regions and in the narrow ones,

en: Growing among black folks as among white.
vi: Green grows among black friends as well as white friends.
tr: Growing up among white people as well as within black communities.
es: I grow equally among blacks and whites.

en: So maybe the grass is a metaphor for our equality and our essential connectedness, as dr Holden had said.
vi: So perhaps grass is a metaphor for equality and the close connection between us, as Ms. Holden mentioned.
tr: So maybe grass is a metaphor for our equality and fundamental interconnectedness, just as Dr. Holden said.
es: So maybe the grass is a metaphor that we are equal and basically connected, as Dr. Holden had told me.

en: And then finally, he says of grass,
vi: And Whitman's final words about grass:
tr: And then finally, he says this about the grass:
es: And then it says about the grass:

en: And now it seems to me the beautiful uncut hair of graves.
vi: And now to me, the grass is the hair of the grave, hanging loose without the sorrow of cutting.
tr: And now it seems to me like the uncut beautiful hair of graves.
es: And now it seems to me that it is the loose and beautiful hair of the tombs.

en: So grass is death, too—it grows out of our buried bodies.
vi: Thus, grass is also death–growing from the buried bodies.
tr: So, grass at the same time is death... growing out from our buried bodies.
es: So the grass is also death. It grows above our buried bodies.

en: The grass was so many different things at once, it was bewildering.
vi: There are too many layers of meaning in the image of grass; it truly is a tangled mess.
tr: Grass simultaneously expressed so many different things that it was astonishing.
es: The grass was many different things at once. It was bewildering.

en: So grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for connectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.
vi: In summary, grass is a metaphor for life, death, equality, connection, and it alludes to children, God, and hope.
tr: So, grass was a metaphor for life, for death, for equality, for connectedness, for children, for God, and for hope.
es: The grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for our interconnectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.

en: I couldn’t figure out which of these ideas, if any, was at the core of the poem.
vi: I have yet to figure out what, if anything, in these images is the essence of this poem.
tr: I couldn't understand which of these ideas, if any, was the essence of the poem.
es: I couldn't figure out which of these ideas was the crux of the poem, assuming any of them were.

en: But thinking about the grass and all the different ways you can see it made me think about all the ways I’d seen and mis-seen Margo.
vi: But thinking about grass and the different ways of perceiving it makes me think of all the ways I have seen and mis-seen Margo.
tr: But thinking about the grass and all the different ways to understand it made me think about all the ways I understood and misunderstood Margo.
es: But thinking about the grass and the different ways of seeing it made me think about all the ways I had seen and misseen Margo.

en: There was no shortage of ways to see her.
vi: There is no shortage of ways to look at her.
tr: There was no lack of ways to see her.
es: The ways of seeing her were not few.

en: I’d been focused on what had become of her, but now with my head trying to understand the multiplicity of grass and her smell from the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the most important question was who I was looking for.
vi: I was too focused on what she became, but now, as I try to understand the multifaceted nature of grass, with Margo's scent still lingering in my throat from the blanket, I realize that the most important question is: who am I trying to find.
tr: I had focused on what had happened to her, but now, with my mind trying to understand the variety of the grass and the scent of the blanket still in my nose, I realized that the most important question was whom I was searching for.
es: I had focused on what had become of her, but there, trying to understand the multiplicity of the grass and with the smell of the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the more important question was who I was looking for.

en: If “What is the grass?” has such a complicated answer, I thought, so, too, must “Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?”
vi: If "What is grass?" requires such a complex answer, then the same must be true for the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?"
tr: If the question "What is grass?" has such a complex answer, I thought that the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?" must be the same.
es: I thought that if it was so complicated to answer the question "What is the grass?", it must also be complicated to answer the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?".

en: Like a metaphor rendered incomprehensible by its ubiquity, there was room enough in what she had left me for endless imaginings, for an infinite set of Margos.
vi: Like a metaphor that cannot be instantly conveyed in its entirety by its simultaneous layers of meaning, in what Margo left for me, there is enough room for endless imaginations, for an unlimited series of different Margos.
tr: Like a metaphor that becomes incomprehensible because it is everywhere, in what she left for me, there was enough room for endless dreams and an unlimited group of Margos.
es: Like a metaphor elusive in its breadth, in what she had left me, there was room to imagine infinitely, for an infinite series of Margos.

en: I had to narrow her down, and I figured there had to be things here that I was seeing wrong or not seeing.
vi: I have to narrow her down, and I realize that in this place, there must be things I have seen incorrectly or not seen at all.
tr: I had to narrow Margo down and I thought there must be things here that I misunderstood or didn't understand.
es: I had to narrow it down, and I assumed that there had to be things I was seeing wrong or not seeing at all.

en: I wanted to tear off the roof and light up the whole place so that I could see it all at once, instead of one flashlight beam at a time.
vi: I want to tear open the roof above, illuminating every corner to see everything at once, rather than just following the scattered flashlight beams sweeping back and forth.
tr: I wanted to hold and tear off the roof and light up this whole place so I could see everything at once instead of just one lantern light at a time.
es: I wanted to tear off the roof so that the light could come in and I could see everything at once, not each thing separately with the flashlight.

en: I put aside Margo’s blanket and shouted, loud enough for all the rats to hear, “I Am Going To Find Something Here!”
vi: I set Margo's blanket aside and shouted, loud enough for all the gnawing creatures to hear, "I Will Find Something In This Place!"
tr: Putting Margo's blanket aside, I shouted loud enough for all the mice to hear, "I Will Find Something Here!"
es: I pulled Margo's blanket aside and shouted loud enough for the rats to hear me: —Am I going to find something here?

en: I went through each desk in the office again, but it seemed more and more obvious that Margo had used only the desk with the nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
vi: I checked each desk in the office, and the more I searched, the clearer it became that Margo only used the desk with the nail polish bottle in the drawer and the calendar stopped at June.
tr: I reviewed every desk in the office again, but it was becoming increasingly apparent that Margo only used the desk with nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
es: I returned to the desks in the office, but it seemed increasingly obvious that Margo had only used the one with the nail polish and the calendar set to the month of June.

en: I ducked through a Troll Hole and made my way back to the library, walking again through the abandoned metal shelves.
vi: I crawled through the Devil's Hole, returned to the library, and once again walked along the empty iron shelves.
tr: I crouched through a Dwarf Hole and walked back through the abandoned shelves, then proceeded in the library.
es: I crawled through a Troll Hole, returned to the library, and once again wandered through the abandoned metal shelves.

en: On each shelf I looked for dustless shapes that would tell me Margo had used this space for something, but I couldn’t find any.
vi: On each shelf, I strained my eyes to see if there was any spot not covered in dust, indicating that Margo had used it for something, but I saw nothing.
tr: I looked for dust-free shapes on each shelf that would show me Margo had used that area for something, but I found nothing.
es: I searched all the shelves for dust-free marks that would indicate Margo had used them for something, but I found none.

en: But then my darting flashlight happened across something atop the shelf in a corner of the room, right near the boarded-up storefront window.
vi: Then my flashlight happened to sweep over something on top of a shelf in the corner of the room, right near the front window blocked by plywood.
tr: But then, my swiftly moving flashlight caught something at the top of a shelf in a corner of the room, just to the side of the store's boarded-up front window.
es: But suddenly, the flashlight beam passed over something on a shelf in a corner of the room, right next to the display case with the particle board.

en: It was the spine of a book.
vi: It was the spine of a book.
tr: It was the spine of a book.
es: It was the spine of a book.

en: The book was called Roadside America: Your Travel Guide, and had been published in 1998, after this place had been abandoned.
vi: The book is titled Following America: A Travel Guide, published in 1998, after this place was abandoned.
tr: The book had "Along the Road America: Your Travel Guide" written on it and was published in 1998, after this place was abandoned.
es: The book was titled Roadside America and had been published in 1998, after that place had been abandoned.

en: I flipped through it with the flashlight crooked between neck and shoulder.
vi: I wedged the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, flipping through the pages with my hands.
tr: I turned the pages of the book with the flashlight I had wedged between my neck and shoulder.
es: I flipped through it holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder.

en: The book listed hundreds of attractions you could visit, from the world’s largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world’s largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska.
vi: The book lists hundreds of attractions to visit, from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska.
tr: The book listed hundreds of interesting places to visit; from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska.
es: The book offered a list of hundreds of tourist attractions, from the world's largest ball of twine, in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps, in Omaha, Nebraska.

en: Someone had folded down the corners of several seemingly random pages.
vi: Someone had dog-eared a few pages seemingly at random.
tr: Someone had seemingly randomly dog-eared many pages.
es: Someone had dog-eared several pages, seemingly at random.

en: The book wasn’t too dusty.
vi: The book wasn't very dusty.
tr: The book wasn't very dusty.
es: The book wasn't very dusty.

en: Maybe SeaWorld was only the first stop on some kind of whirlwind adventure.
vi: Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in the whirlwind of adventures.
tr: Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in a whirlwind adventure.
es: Maybe SeaWorld had just been the first stop in some kind of whirlwind of adventures.

en: Yes.
vi: Indeed.
tr: Yes.
es: Yes.

en: That made sense.
vi: That makes a lot of sense.
tr: This made sense.
es: It wasn't nonsense.

en: That was Margo.
vi: That's so Margo.
tr: This was Margo.
es: That was Margo.

en: She found out about this place somehow, came here to gather her supplies, spent a night or two, and then hit the road.
vi: Somehow she had discovered this place, came here to pack her bags, stayed a night or two, and then hit the road.
tr: Somehow she had discovered this place, come here to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and then set off.
es: Somehow she discovered that place, went to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and moved on.

en: I could imagine her pinballing among tourist traps.
vi: I can picture her bouncing from one tourist trap to another.
tr: I could imagine her going from one tourist trap to another.
es: I imagined her wandering between tourist traps.

en: As the last light fled from the holes in the ceiling, I found more books above other bookshelves.
vi: As the last beam of light gradually faded through the hole in the ceiling, I found a few more books on the other shelves.
tr: As the last light escaped through the holes in the ceiling, I found other books on top of the other bookshelves.
es: As the last rays of light came through the holes in the roof, I found more books on other shelves: General Guide to Nepal, Great Attractions of Canada, America by Car, Fodor's Guide to the Bahamas, and Let's Go to Bhutan.

en: The Rough Guide to Nepal; The Great Sights of Canada; America by Car; Fodor’s Guide to the Bahamas; Let’s Go Bhutan.
vi: A brief journey to Nepal; Majestic Canada; Roaming by car across America; Fodor's guide to the Bahamas; Onward to Bhutan.
tr: “Nepal Travel Guide”; “Canada’s "Important Landscapes"; "America by Car"; "Fodor's Bahamas Guide"; "Let's Go to Bhutan".
es: As the last rays of light came through the holes in the roof, I found more books on other shelves: General Guide to Nepal, Great Attractions of Canada, America by Car, Fodor's Guide to the Bahamas, and Let's Go to Bhutan.

en: There seemed to be no connection at all among the books, except that they were all about traveling and had all been published after the minimall was abandoned.
vi: There seemed to be no connection between the books, except that they were all travel guides and were published after this mini-mall was abandoned.
tr: There seemed to be no connection between all these books, except that they were all about travel and all published after the mall had been abandoned.
es: There didn't seem to be the slightest connection between the books, except that they were all travel books and the publication date was after the building was abandoned.

en: I tucked the Maglite under my chin, scooped up the books into a stack that extended from my waist to my chest, and carried them into the empty room I was now imagining as the bedroom.
vi: I tucked the flashlight under my chin, stacked all the books into a pile from waist-high to chest-high, and carried them to the empty room that I now imagined as the bedroom.
tr: I wedged the Maglite under my chin, embraced the books in a stack that stretched from my waist to my chest, and carried them to the empty room I now imagined as a bedroom.
es: I tucked the flashlight under my chin, loaded the pile of books, which reached from my waist to my chest, into my arms, and carried them to the empty room, which I then imagined was the bedroom.

en: So it turned out that I did spend prom night with Margo, just not quite as I’d dreamed.
vi: It turns out I spent the prom night with Margo, just not quite like in my dreams.
tr: Thus, it felt like I spent the prom night with Margo, just not exactly as I had imagined.
es: So it turned out that I did spend prom night with Margo, just not in the way I had dreamed.

en: Instead of busting into prom together, I sat against her rolled-up carpet with her ratty blanket draped over my knees, alternately reading travel guides by flashlight and sitting still in the dark as the cicadas hummed above and around me.
vi: Instead of tearing up the dance floor together, I sat leaning against her rolled-up carpet, covering my knees with her old blanket, reading travel guides by flashlight, and sitting quietly in the dark as the cicadas harmonized melodiously above and around me.

en: She was too small and the space covered by the maps too big.
vi: She was too small and the space on the maps was too large.
tr: She was very small, while the area covered by the maps was very large.
es: She was too small and the space covered by the maps, too large.

en: They were more than a waste of time—they were the physical representation of the total fruitlessness of all of it, my absolute inability to develop the kinds of palms that cover continents, to have the kind of mind that correctly imagines.
vi: These maps were more than just a waste of time—they were the tangible manifestation of completely useless conclusions, my absolute inability to create palms that could cover continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.
tr: The maps were much more than a waste of time... they were physical representations of my absolute inability to develop continent-spanning hands and to possess the kind of mind that imagines properly, the total inefficiency of all this.
es: They were more than a waste of time. They were the physical representation of the inefficacy of it all, my absolute incapacity to develop palms that could encompass continents, to have a mind that could imagine correctly.

en: I got up and walked over to the maps and tore them off the wall, the pins and tacks flying out with the paper and falling to the ground.

es: I got up, went to the maps, and pulled them down. The thumbtacks came off with the paper and fell to the floor.

en: I balled up the maps and threw them in the garbage can.
vi: I crumpled the maps and threw them all into the trash can.
tr: I crumpled the maps into a ball and threw them into the trash can.
es: I crumpled the maps and threw them in the trash can.

en: On my way back to bed I stepped on a tack, like an idiot, and even though I was annoyed and exhausted and out of pseudovisions and ideas, I had to pick up all the thumbtacks scattered around the carpet so I didn’t step on them later.
vi: When I returned to the bed, I stupidly stepped on a thumbtack. Even though I was angry, exhausted, and out of ideas, drained of even the ghost towns, I still had to pick up the scattered thumbtacks on the carpet to avoid stepping on them again.

es: On my way back to bed, I stepped on a thumbtack, like an idiot, and although I was angry, exhausted, and had run out of pseudo-visions and ideas, I had to pick up all the thumbtacks scattered on the carpet so I wouldn't step on them later.

en: I just wanted to punch the wall, but I had to pick up those stupid goddamned thumbtacks.
vi: I just wanted to pound the wall with all my might, but I had to pick up all these damn stupid thumbtacks first.
tr: I just wanted to punch the wall, but I had to pick up those damn stupid tacks.
es: What my body wanted was to punch the wall, but I had to pick up the damn thumbtacks.

en: When I finished, I got back into bed and socked my pillow, my teeth clenched.

tr: When I finished, I went back to bed and punched the pillow, gritting my teeth.
es: When I was done, I got back into bed and punched the pillow with clenched teeth.

en: I started trying to read the Whitman again, but between it and thinking of Margo, I felt exposed enough for this night.
vi: I tried to read Whitman again, but between the pages of the book and thoughts of Margo, I felt that tonight I had been exposed enough already.
tr: I started trying to read Whitman again, but between thinking about poetry and Margo, I've had enough exposure for tonight I was feeling it.
es: I tried to keep reading Whitman's book, but between reading and not stopping thinking about Margo, I felt suffocated enough for that night, so in the end, I put the book down.

es: I didn't even bother to get up to turn off the light.

es: I stayed staring at the wall, blinking more and more.

es: And every time I opened my eyes, I saw the piece of wall where the maps had been, the four holes forming a rectangle, and the holes inside the rectangle, scattered randomly.

es: But even though we sang "You Are My Sunshine" in front of his window, all we managed to do was get him to open it and yell at us.

es: He talked to me for a while about Angela, told me that he liked her a lot and that it was weird to fall in love a few months before each of them went to a different university, but I found it hard to pay attention.

en: I wanted that map.

es: I wanted that map.

es: I wanted to see the places she had marked.

es: I wanted to pin the tacks back on the wall.

en: The place didn’t scare me at all anymore.

es: The building no longer scared me in the slightest.

es: As soon as we had gone through all the rooms and confirmed that we were alone, I felt as safe as I did at home.

vi: Under a display counter, I saw the box containing maps and travel brochures that I had rummaged through during the night of the party.
tr: Under a display counter, I found the box of maps and brochures that I had quickly glanced at on the night of the ball.
es: Under a display case, I found the box of maps and brochures that I had rummaged through on the night of the dance.

es: I lifted it and leaned it against the corner of a display case with broken glass.

es: Radar was looking for anything that had a map, and I unfolded it and checked if it had holes.

en: We were getting near the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black-and-white brochure entitled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES.
vi: Near the bottom of the box, Radar lifted up a stack of black and white prints titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES.
tr: We were approaching the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black and white brochure titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES.
es: We were reaching the bottom of the box when Radar pulled out a black and white pamphlet titled FIVE THOUSAND AMERICAN CITIES.

en: It was copyrighted 1972 by the Esso company.

es: The copyright was from 1972, by the Esso company.

es: As he carefully unfolded the map and tried to smooth out the creases, I saw a hole in the corner.

en: “This is it,” I said, my voice rising.
vi: “Here it is,” I whispered excitedly.

es: "It's this one," I said, raising my voice.

tr: There was a tear around the pinhole, as if it had been ripped off a wall.
es: Next to the hole there was a torn piece, as if they had ripped the map off the wall.

en: It was a yellowing, brittle, classroom-size map of the United States printed thick with potential destinations.
vi: It was a map of the United States, the kind you hang in a classroom, with brittle and yellowed paper, densely printed with potential destinations.
tr: It was a yellowed, thin map of the United States, the kind used in classrooms, with possible direction names written in bold letters.
es: It was a yellowed and brittle map of the United States, the kind you find in classrooms, marked with possible destinations.

en: The rips in the map told me that she had not intended this as a clue— Margo was too precise and assured with her clues to muddy the waters.
vi: The small tear in the corner told me that Margo did not intend to leave this map as a clue—she was too precise and certain with her clues to play a misleading game.
tr: The tears on the map showed me that this wasn’t designed as a clue... Margo didn’t leave clues that would muddy the waters.
es: From the creases in the map, I understood that Margo hadn't intended it to be a clue. She was too precise and sure with her clues to muddy the waters.

en: Somehow or another, we’d stumbled into something she hadn’t planned, and in seeing what she hadn’t planned, I thought again of how much she had planned.
vi: Fate had led us to a part Margo had not anticipated, and seeing what she had not anticipated made me think about how much she had planned.
tr: One way or another, we had stumbled upon something she hadn’t planned, and seeing what she hadn’t planned made me think again about how much she had planned.
es: In any case, we had found something she hadn't anticipated, and seeing what she hadn't anticipated, I thought again that she had anticipated many things.

en: And maybe, I thought, that’s what she did in the quiet dark here.
vi: And perhaps, I thought, that’s what she had been doing in the quiet darkness here.
tr: And maybe, I thought, in this silent darkness, what she was doing here It was.
es: And I thought that maybe that was what she had done in that dark and silent room.

en: Traveling while loafing, like Whitman had, as she prepared for the real thing.

tr: Traveling while idling as he prepared for the real thing, like Whitman did.
es: Traveling while lying down, like Whitman, as she prepared for what she was really going to do.

en: I ran all the way back to the office and found a bunch of thumbtacks in a desk adjacent to Margo’s, before Radar and I carefully carried the unfurled map back to Margo’s room.
vi: I ran straight to the office and saw a handful of push pins on the table next to Margo's desk. Then Radar and I carefully carried the flattened map to Margo's room.

es: I returned to the office and found a handful of thumbtacks on a table next to Margo's. Then Radar and I carefully carried the unfolded map to Margo's room.

es: I held it against the wall while Radar tried to insert the thumbtacks into the holes, but three of the four corners had broken, as well as three of the five locations, probably from removing the map from the wall.

en: Yeah.
vi: There.
tr: Yes.

en: Don’t move.”

es: Don't move.

es: The lettering was so small that I had to get on the carpet and bring my eyes a few centimeters from the map to try to identify each town.

vi: “Matches with what we already know.”

vi: “But my God, where in New York is this?

en: That’s the question.”

vi: "It could be Poughkeepsie or Woodstock or Catskill Park."
tr: It could be Poughkeepsie, Woodstock, or Catskill Park."
es: It could be Poughkeepsie, Woodstock, or the Catskill park.

en: “Woodstock,” Radar said.
vi: “Woodstock,” Radar said.
tr: “Woodstock,” said Radar.
es: —Woodstock —said Radar—.

en: “That’d be interesting.
vi: “This place is cool.
tr: “It would be interesting.
es: It would be interesting.

en: She’s not much of a hippie, but she has that whole free-spirit vibe.”
vi: Margo doesn't seem like a hippie, but she has the spirit of a free soul.”
tr: Margo is not much of a hippie, but all that free spirit stuff suits her.”
es: Margo isn't very hippy, but she has that free spirit vibe.

en: “I don’t know,” I said.
vi: “I don't know,” I said.
tr: “I don't know,” I said.
es: —I don't know —I replied—.

es: —It would help a bit if there was only one point on the map —said Radar in a somber tone.

en: “But she’s probably going from place to place,” I said.

tr: “But he is probably going from one place to another,” I said.
es: —But surely he goes from one place to another —I told him.

en: Tramping her perpetual journey.
vi: Immersing herself in her endless journey.
tr: Slowly progressing on his eternal journey.
es: Embarking on his eternal journey.

en: What it does is it allows you to enter a category—it can be a geographical area or like a family in the animal kingdom— and then you can read the first sentences of up to a hundred Omnictionary articles about your topic on a single page.
