es: After a long day of final exams, returning to the comfortable seclusion of "Song of Myself" was almost a relief.

en: I had reached a weird part of the poem—after all this time listening and hearing people, and then traveling alongside them, Whitman stops hearing and he stops visiting, and he starts to become other people.
vi: I read a very strange passage of the poem—after all the time listening and hearing people, then wandering with them, Whitman no longer listens and no longer wanders, he begins to become other people.
tr: I had reached a strange part of the poem... After spending so much time hearing, listening to, and wandering among people, Whitman hearing and stops visiting and starts becoming other people.
es: I had reached a strange part of the poem. After having been listening to and hearing people, and traveling with them, Whitman stops listening and traveling and starts becoming other people.

en: Like, actually inhabit them.
vi: As if truly being inside them.
tr: As if he were living inside them.
es: As if he inhabited them.

en: He tells the story of a ship’s captain who saved everyone on his boat except himself.
vi: He tells the story of the captain of a ship who saved everyone on board, except himself.
tr: He tells the story of a captain who saved everyone on his ship except himself.
es: He tells the story of a ship captain who saved everyone except himself.

en: The poet can tell the story, he argues, because he has become the captain.
vi: Whitman says that the poet can tell the story because he has become that captain.
tr: The poet says he can tell the story because he is the captain.
es: The poet says he can tell that story because he has become the captain.

en: As he writes, “I am the man . . . . I suffered . . . . I was there.”
vi: When he writes, "I am that man... I endure... I was there."
tr: “I am that man... I suffered... I was there,” he writes.
es: And he writes: "I am the man, I suffered, I was there."

en: A few lines later, it becomes even more clear that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become another: “I do not ask the wounded person how he feels . . . . I myself become the wounded person.”
vi: A few lines later, it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become someone else: "I do not ask the wounded person how he feels... I myself become the wounded person."
tr: A few lines later, it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become others: “I do not ask the wounded person how he feels... I myself become the wounded person.”
es: A few verses later it becomes even clearer that Whitman no longer needs to listen to become another person: "I do not ask the wounded how he feels, I am the wounded."

en: I put the book down and lay on my side, staring out the window that had always been between us.
vi: I put the book down and lay on my side, looking out the window that had always been between me and her.
tr: I put the book aside and turn sideways to look outside through the window that has always been between us.
es: I put down the book and lay on my side, looking through the window that had always been between us.

en: It is not enough just to see her or hear her.
vi: Just seeing or hearing her was not enough.
tr: It is not enough to just see or hear her.
es: It's not enough to see her or hear her.

en: To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
vi: To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, one must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
tr: To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you must become Margo Roth Spiegelman.
es: To find Margo Roth Spiegelman, you have to become Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: And I had done many of the things she might have done: I had engineered a most unlikely prom coupling.
vi: I did many things she might have done: I created a pair least likely to attend a gala together.
tr: And I had done many of the things he might have done: I had arranged an impossible ballroom couple.
es: And I had done many of the things that perhaps she had done. I had managed to unite the most unlikely couple at the dance.

en: I had quieted the hounds of caste warfare.
vi: I silenced the hounds of the class war.
tr: I had silenced the dogs of social class warfare.
es: I had silenced the dogs of the caste war.

en: I had come to feel comfortable inside the rat-infested haunted house where she did her best thinking.
vi: I was naturally comfortable in the haunted house where the rats reigned supreme, where she had done most of her thinking.
tr: I had managed to feel comfortable in the haunted house infested with mice, where my thinking action was at its best.
es: I had managed to feel comfortable in the haunted, rat-filled house where Margo had planned everything.

en: I had seen.
vi: I saw.
tr: I had seen.
es: I had seen.

en: I had listened.
vi: I listened.
tr: I had listened.
es: I had listened.

en: But I could not yet become the wounded person.
vi: But I have yet to become the bearer of the wound.
tr: But I had not yet become that wounded person.
es: But I still couldn't become the wounded person.

en: I limped through my physics and government finals the next day and then stayed up till 2 A. M. on Tuesday finishing my final reaction paper for English about Moby Dick.
vi: The next day, I was sluggish throughout the physics exam and the government and politics class, then on Tuesday stayed up until 2 AM to finish the final essay for the National Language subject, about Moby Dick.
tr: The next day, I barely passed my physics and politics exams, and then I stayed up until two in the morning to finish my final assignment on Moby Dick for literature.
es: The next day I did the physics and politics exams as best as I could, and on Tuesday I stayed up until two in the morning finishing the end-of-course literature paper on Moby Dick.

en: Ahab was a hero, I decided.
vi: Ahab is a hero, I have decided that.
tr: I decided that Ahab was a hero.
es: I decided that Ahab was a hero.

en: I had no particular reason for having decided this—particularly given that I hadn’t read the book—but I decided it and reacted thusly.
vi: There is no particular reason for this decision—especially since I haven't read the book—but I have decided it and just went on writing.
tr: I had no particular reason for this decision—especially considering I hadn't read the book—but I made the decision and reacted accordingly.
es: I had no particular reason for making that decision—especially considering that I hadn't read the book—but I decided it and acted accordingly.

en: The abbreviated exam week meant that Wednesday was the last day of school for us.
vi: The shortened exam week means that Wednesday is our last day at school.
tr: The shortened exam week meant that Wednesday was our last day of school.
es: The shortened exam week meant that Wednesday was our last day of class.

en: And all day long, it was hard not to walk around thinking about the lastness of it all:
vi: Throughout that day, it was hard not to wander around, thinking about all the lasts:
tr: And all day, it was hard not to think about the finality of it all: in front of the band room, under the shade of that oak tree that had sheltered generations of band geeks, my last stand in a circle.
es: And throughout the day, I found it difficult not to wander around thinking about everything I was doing for the last time.

en: The last time I stand in a circle outside the band room in the shade of this oak tree that has protected generations of band geeks.
vi: The last time standing with the group in a circle outside the music room, under the oak tree that has sheltered generations of talented musicians.
tr: And all day, it was hard not to think about the finality of it all: in front of the band room, under the shade of that oak tree that had sheltered generations of band geeks, my last stand in a circle.
es: The last time forming a circle by the rehearsal room door, in the shade of the oak tree that has sheltered generations of band geeks.

en: The last time I eat pizza in the cafeteria with Ben.
vi: The last time eating pizza in the cafeteria with Ben.
tr: My last pizza with Ben in the cafeteria.
es: The last time eating pizza in the cafeteria with Ben.

en: The last time I sit in this school scrawling an essay with a cramped hand into a blue book.
vi: The last time sitting in this school, one hand hurriedly writing an essay, the other hand wedged between the pages of a blue book.
tr: My last scribbled essay in a blue notebook, sitting in this school with my clenched hand.
es: The last time sitting in that high school writing a paper with one hand tucked into a blue book.

en: The last time I glance up at the clock.
vi: The last time glancing at the clock.
tr: My last glance at the clock.
es: The last time looking at the clock.

en: The last time I see Chuck Parson prowling the halls, his smile half a sneer.
vi: The last time seeing Chuck Parson trudging through the hallway, with a fleetingly disdainful and nonchalant smile.
tr: Chuck Parson’s partially scornful smile as he patrolled the hallways for the last time.
es: The last time seeing Chuck Parson lurking in the hallways with a half-contemptuous smile.

en: God.
vi: Oh my.
tr: my view.
es: Damn.

en: I was becoming nostalgic for Chuck Parson.
vi: I'm starting to feel nostalgic about Chuck Parson, of all people.
tr: My God. I was longing for Chuck Parson.
es: I was starting to feel nostalgic for Chuck Parson.

en: Something sick was happening inside of me.
vi: Some kind of illness must be taking over me.
tr: Something sickly was happening inside me.
es: I must have been sick.

en: It must have been like this for Margo, too.
vi: For Margo, it must have been the same.
tr: It must have been the same for Margo.
es: Something like that Margo must have felt too.

en: With all the planning she’d done, she must have known she was leaving, and even she couldn’t have been totally immune to the feeling.
vi: With all the time spent planning, she must have known she was going to leave, even though she wasn't entirely immune to emotions.
tr: According to all the planning she did, she must have known she was going to leave, and even she wasn't completely devoid of emotions.
es: While she was making her plans, she undoubtedly knew she would leave, and surely even she couldn't be completely immune to that feeling.

en: She’d had good days here.
vi: She had some beautiful days here.
tr: She had had good days here.
es: She had had good times at that school.

en: And on the last day, the bad days become so difficult to recall, because one way or another, she had made a life here, just as I had.
vi: In the final moments, it was hard to recall the bad days, because in one way or another, she had spent part of her life in this place, just like I did.
tr: On one's last day, it becomes very difficult to remember the bad days because, one way or another, she too had built a life here just like I did.
es: And on the last day, it's very hard to remember the bad times, because in any case, she had made her life there, just like I did.

en: The town was paper, but the memories were not.
vi: This city is paper, but the memories are not.
tr: The city was made of paper, but the memories were not.
es: The city was paper, but the memories were not.

en: All the things I’d done here, all the love and pity and compassion and violence and spite, kept welling up inside me.
vi: Everything I did here, all the affection, sorrow, compassion, cruelty, and malice, it's all filling up inside me.
tr: Everything I did here, all that love, compassion, tenderness, violence, and hatred, continued to accumulate inside me.
es: Everything she had done there, all the love, the sorrow, the compassion, the violence, and the resentment kept flowing from within me.

en: These whitewashed cinder-block walls.
vi: The white-painted honeycomb walls.
tr: These whitewashed concrete walls.
es: Those whitewashed concrete walls.

en: My white walls.
vi: My white walls.
tr: My white walls.
es: My white walls.

en: Margo’s white walls.
vi: Margo's white walls.
tr: Margo's white walls.
es: Margo's white walls.

en: We’d been captive in them for so long, stuck in their belly like Jonah.
vi: We had been trapped between those walls for too long, stuck in its belly like Jonah was stuck in the belly of the whale.
tr: We had been trapped among them for so long that we were stuck in their stomachs like Jonah.
es: For a long time, we had been captives within them, trapped in their stomach, like Jonah.

en: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that maybe this feeling was why she’d planned everything so intricately and precisely: even if you want to leave, it is so hard.
vi: All day long, I had thought that perhaps this emotion was the reason why she planned everything so meticulously and precisely: even if you want to go, leaving is still very difficult.
tr: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps this was the reason Margo planned everything so meticulously and precisely: Even if you wanted to leave, it was so difficult.
es: Throughout the day, I found myself thinking that perhaps that feeling was the reason why Margo had planned everything so complexly and precisely. Even if you want to leave, it is very difficult.

en: It took preparation, and maybe sitting in that minimall scrawling her plans was both intellectual and emotional practice—Margo’s way of imagining herself into her fate.
vi: It needs to be prepared, and perhaps sitting down to plan in that abandoned shopping mall was both an intellectual and emotional task—the way Margo envisioned herself embarking on her destiny.
tr: You had to prepare, and maybe sitting in the shopping mall scribbling my plans was both a mental and emotional exercise... A way to imagine Margo living out her destiny.
es: It required preparation, and perhaps sitting in that shopping mall to write her plans was both an intellectual and emotional task, her way of imagining herself at her destination.

en: Ben and Radar both had a marathon band practice to make sure they would rock “Pomp and Circumstance” at graduation.
vi: Ben and Radar practiced music tirelessly to ensure that they would make everyone rock during the "Pomp and Circumstance" march at the graduation ceremony.
tr: Both Ben and Radar had a long band rehearsal to ensure they could play the Pomp and Circumstance march properly at graduation.
es: Ben and Radar had a marathon rehearsal with the band to make sure they would play "Pomp and Circumstance" at graduation.

en: Lacey offered me a ride, but I decided to clean out my locker, because I didn’t really want to come back here and again have to feel like my lungs were drowning in this perverse nostalgia.
vi: Lacey said she could give me a ride home, but I decided to clean out my locker because I didn't want to come back to school and feel my lungs drowning in the stubborn nostalgia that surged up.
tr: Lacey offered to drive me, but I decided to clean out my locker because I really didn't want to have to come back here later and feel my lungs choking with this perverse longing.
es: Lacey offered to take me home, but I decided to empty my locker, because the truth was that I didn't feel like going back to the school and having to feel my lungs drowning in that stubborn nostalgia again.

en: My locker was an unadulterated crap hole—half trash can, half book storage.
vi: My locker is purely a chaotic mess–half filled with trash, half filled with books.
tr: My locker was a pure junk nest... partly a trash can, partly a book depot.
es: My locker was a real shithole, half trash can and half book storage.

en: Her locker had been neatly stacked with textbooks when Lacey opened it, I remembered, as if she intended to come to school the next day.
vi: Margo's locker was still neatly organized when Lacey opened it, I still remember, as if Margo planned to return to school the very next day.
tr: I remembered that when Lacey opened it, Margo's textbooks were neatly arranged in her locker, as if she intended to come to school the next day.
es: I remembered that when Lacey opened Margo's locker, the books were perfectly stacked, as if she intended to go to class the next day.

en: I pulled a garbage can over to the bank of lockers and opened mine up.
vi: I pulled the trash can closer to the row of lockers and opened mine.
tr: I pulled a trash can next to the row of lockers and opened mine, starting to take out the contents with a photo of Radar, Ben, and me goofing around.
es: I placed a trash can on the bench and opened my locker.

en: I began by pulling off a picture of Radar and Ben and me goofing off.
vi: I started with a photo of Radar, Ben, and me, the three of us lazily staring blankly.
tr: I pulled a trash can next to the row of lockers and opened mine, starting to take out the contents with a photo of Radar, Ben, and me goofing around.
es: The first thing I did was peel off a photo of Radar, Ben, and me grinning from ear to ear.

en: I put it inside my backpack and then started the disgusting process of picking through a year’s worth of accumulated filth—gum wrapped in scraps of notebook paper, pens out of ink, greasy napkins—and scraping it all into the garbage.
vi: I put the photo into my backpack, then began the horrifying process of picking out all the filthy things accumulated over the year–wads of gum wrapped in torn notebook paper, countless empty pens, grease-stained tissues–I tossed them all into the trash can.
tr: I put the photo in my backpack, then the filth that had accumulated over a year, notebook Gums wrapped in pieces of paper, pens with no ink, greasy napkins—I began the disgusting process of scraping them into the trash.
es: I put it in my backpack and started the disgusting process of rummaging through the junk accumulated over the whole year—gum wrapped in pieces of notebook paper, pens without ink, greasy napkins—and throwing it into the trash can.

en: All along, I kept thinking, I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, Radar and I will never write notes in calculus again, I will never see Margo across the hall again.
vi: All the while, I kept thinking, I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, Radar and I will never pass notes in calculus again, I will never see Margo walking in the hallway again.
tr: From the beginning, I kept thinking: I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this will never be my locker again, I will never write notes in math with Radar again, I will never see Margo from the other side of the hallway again.
es: As I did so, I thought: "I will never do this again, I will never be here again, this locker will never be mine again, Radar and I will never write notes to each other in calculus class again, I will never see Margo in the hallway again."

en: This was the first time in my life that so many things would never happen again.
vi: For the first time in my life, there were so many things that would never happen again.
tr: This was the first time in my life that many things would never happen again.
es: It was the first time in my life that so many things would never happen again.

en: And finally it was too much.
vi: And finally, it was too much.
tr: And in the end, it was too much.
es: And in the end, it was too much.

en: I could not talk myself down from the feeling, and the feeling became unbearable.
vi: I couldn't control the flow of emotions, and the feelings became unbearable.
tr: I couldn't overcome this feeling and it became unbearable.
es: I couldn't shake off that feeling and it became unbearable.

en: I reached in deep to the recesses of my locker.
vi: I delved deep into the drawer, pulling out everything—photos, notes, and books—and swept them all into the trash.
tr: I reached into the depths, the insides of my closet.
es: I extended my arms, reached deep into the locker, and pushed everything —photos, notes, and books— into the trash bin.

en: I pushed everything—photographs and notes and books—into the trash can.
vi: I delved deep into the drawer, pulling out everything—photos, notes, and books—and swept them all into the trash.
tr: I threw everything—photos, notes, books—into the trash can.
es: I extended my arms, reached deep into the locker, and pushed everything —photos, notes, and books— into the trash bin.

en: I left the locker open and walked away.
vi: I left the drawer open and walked away.
tr: I left the closet open and walked away.
es: I left the locker open and walked away.

en: As I walked past the band room, I could hear through the walls the muffled sounds of “Pomp and Circumstance.” I kept walking.
vi: Passing by the music room, I heard the song "Pomp and Circumstance" muffled through the walls. I kept walking.
tr: As I passed by the band room, I could hear the muffled sound of "Pomp and Circumstance" from behind the walls.
es: As I passed by the rehearsal room, I heard the muffled sound of "Pomp and Circumstance" on the other side of the wall. I kept walking.

en: It was hot outside, but not as hot as usual.
vi: Outside, it was hot, but not as hot as usual.
tr: It was hot outside but not as much as usual.
es: Outside, it was hot, though not as much as usual.

en: It was bearable.
vi: Bearable.
tr: It was bearable.
es: It was bearable.

en: There are sidewalks most of the way home, I thought.
vi: The way home was mostly sidewalk, I thought.
tr: Most of the way home has a sidewalk, I thought.
es: "There are sidewalks for almost the entire way home," I thought.

en: So I kept walking.
vi: So I kept walking.
tr: So I kept walking.
es: And I kept walking.

en: And as paralyzing and upsetting as all the never agains were, the final leaving felt perfect.
vi: Just as dazed and worn out as all the never-agains, this final departure was truly perfect.
tr: No matter how paralyzing and upsetting the never-agains were, the feeling given by the last exit was perfect.
es: And as paralyzing and sad as all those "never agains" were, it seemed perfect to leave like this for the last time.

en: Pure.
vi: Pure.
tr: It was pure.
es: A pure departure.

en: The most distilled possible form of liberation.
vi: The most easily distilled form of liberation.
tr: It was the most distilled form of salvation.
es: The most refined form of liberation possible.

en: Everything that mattered except one lousy picture was in the trash, but it felt so great.
vi: All attachments, except for a lousy photo, stayed in the trash, but the feeling was wonderful.
tr: Everything that mattered, except that lousy photo, was in the trash, but I felt great.
es: Everything important, except for one terrible photo, was in the trash, but I felt great.

en: I started jogging, wanting to put even more distance between myself and school.
vi: I started to walk quickly, wanting to widen the distance between me and the school.
tr: I started running with the desire to put even more distance between me and the school.
es: I started to run, because I wanted to put even more distance between the school and me.

en: It is so hard to leave—until you leave.
vi: Leaving is truly difficult—until we leave.
tr: Leaving is very hard... until you leave.
es: Leaving is very hard... until you leave.

en: And then it is the easiest goddamned thing in the world.
vi: And then it becomes the easiest thing in the world.
tr: After that, it's the easiest damn thing in the world.
es: Then it is the easiest thing in the world.

en: As I ran, I felt myself for the first time becoming Margo.
vi: While running, I felt like I was becoming Margo for the first time.
tr: While running, for the first time, I felt like I was becoming Margo.
es: While I was running, I felt that for the first time I was becoming Margo.

en: I knew: she is not in Orlando.
vi: I knew: she was not in Orlando.
tr: I knew: She is not in Orlando.
es: I knew it: "She is not in Orlando.

en: She is not in Florida.
vi: She was not in the state of Florida.
tr: She is not in Florida.
es: She is not in Florida."

en: Leaving feels too good, once you leave.
vi: Leaving felt too wonderful, once you had left.
tr: Once you leave, leaving feels really good.
es: Leaving is fantastic once you have left.

en: If I’d been in a car, and not on foot, I might have kept going, too.
vi: If I were in a car, not walking, I would have driven away forever.
tr: If I were in a car instead of on foot, I could have kept going too.
es: If I had gone by car, not on foot, I probably would have kept going as well.

en: She was gone and not coming back for graduation or anything else.
vi: Margo had left and would not return for graduation or anything else.
tr: Margo was gone and she wasn't coming back for graduation or anything else.
es: Margo had left and was not going to return, neither for graduation nor for anything else.

en: I felt sure of that now.
vi: Now I felt certain.
tr: I was sure of that now.
es: I was sure of it.

en: I leave, and the leaving is so exhilarating I know I can never go back.
vi: I left, and the departure was so exhilarating that I knew I might never return.
tr: I am leaving, and leaving is so invigorating that I know I can never return.
es: I'm leaving, and leaving is so stimulating that I know I can't go back.

en: But then what?
vi: But then what?
tr: But what then?
es: And then?

en: Do I just keep leaving places, and leaving them, and leaving them, tramping a perpetual journey?
vi: Would I continue to leave somewhere, to depart and depart again, plunging myself into an endless journey?
tr: Will I just continue to leave places, slowly progressing on an eternal journey?
es: Do I devote myself to leaving places over and over again? Do I embark on an eternal journey?

en: Ben and Radar drove past me a quarter mile from Jefferson Park, and Ben brought RHAPAW to a screeching halt right on Lakemont in spite of traffic everywhere, and I ran up to the car and got in.
vi: Ben and Radar drove by when I was a quarter mile from Jefferson Park. Ben abruptly stopped RHAPAW right on Lakemont, despite the surrounding traffic. I ran over and got into the car.
tr: Ben and Radar drove past me in a car five hundred meters from Jefferson Park, and despite there being traffic everywhere, Ben stopped the SESIB with a high-pitched sound right at Lakemont. I ran to the car and got in.
es: Ben and Radar passed by me half a kilometer from Jefferson Park. Ben slammed on the brakes right in front of Lakemont, even though the road was full of cars. I ran to the car and got in.

en: They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to tell them no, because I was closer than I’d ever been before.
vi: The two guys wanted to come to my house to play Resurrection, but I had to say no, because I was closer than ever.
tr: They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to say no to them because I was closer than I had ever been before.
es: They wanted to play Resurrection at my house, but I had to tell them no, because I was closer to Margo than ever.

en: All night Wednesday, and all day Thursday, I tried to use my new understanding of her to figure out some meaning to the clues I had—some relationship between the map and the travel books, or else some link between the Whitman and the map that would allow me to understand her travelogue.
vi: Throughout Wednesday night and all day Thursday, I tried to leverage my new understanding of Margo to derive some meaning from the clues I had—the connection between the map and the travel books, or between Whitman and the map, connections that would help me understand her wanderlust language.
tr: All Wednesday night and Thursday, I tried to use my new understanding to find a connection between the clues I had, the travel guides, and the map; or between Whitman and the map, to understand his journey.
es: On Wednesday night and all of Thursday, I tried to use everything I already knew about Margo to find some meaning in the clues I had, some connection between the map and the travel books, or perhaps some link between Whitman and the map that would help me understand her travel diary.

en: But increasingly I felt like maybe she had become too enthralled with the pleasure of leaving to construct a proper bread crumb trail.
vi: But I increasingly felt that perhaps the joy of departure had captivated Margo to the extent that she didn't really care to leave a complete trail of breadcrumbs.
tr: But more and more, I was thinking, perhaps he had taken pleasure in abandoning the trail so much that it wouldn't form a proper trace from breadcrumbs.
es: But I increasingly got the impression that maybe she was too fascinated by the pleasure of leaving to leave a breadcrumb trail.

en: And if that were the case, the map she had never intended for us to see might be our best chance to find her.
vi: If that were the case, the map Margo didn't intend for us to discover might be the best chance to find her.
tr: And if that was the case, the map he never planned for us to see might be our best chance to find him.
es: And if that was the case, the map she hadn't intended for us to see could be our best bet to find her.

en: But no site on the map was adequately specific.
vi: But no location on the map was precise enough.
tr: But none of the locations on the map were clear enough.
es: But the markings on the map weren't concrete enough.

en: Even the Catskill Park dot, which interested me because it was the only location not in or near a big city, was far too big and populous to find a single person.
vi: Even Catskill Park, which caught my attention because it was the only place not in or near a major city, was still too vast, too crowded to search for a single individual.
tr: Even the point of interest, Catskill Park, which caught my attention because it was the only place not in or near a big city, was too large and crowded to find a single person.
es: Even the Catskill Park, which interested me because it was the only spot not in a big city, not even close, was too large and had too many inhabitants to find one person.

en: “Song of Myself” made references to places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track them all down.
vi: "Song of Myself" led to places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track.
tr: My Song referred to places in New York, but there were too many places to track them all.
es: "Song of Myself" mentioned places in New York City, but there were too many locations to track them all.

en: How do you pinpoint a spot on the map when the spot seems to be moving from metropolis to metropolis?
vi: How could one pinpoint a location on the map when that point seemed to always be moving from one city to another?
tr: If the point seemed to be moving from one big city to another, how would you pinpoint that location on the map?
es: How do you locate a point on a map when it seems the point moves from one city to another?

en: I was already up and paging through travel guides when my parents came into my room on Friday morning.

en: Woodstock, New York, is a town in Ulster County, New York, perhaps best known for the eponymous Woodstock concert [see Woodstock Concert] in 1969, a three-day event featuring acts from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, which actually occurred in a nearby town.
vi: I began reading: Woodstock, New York, is a town in Ulster County, New York, perhaps best known for the namesake music festival [see Woodstock Festival] in 1969, a three-day event featuring artists from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, which actually took place in a nearby town.
tr: Woodstock, New York, located in Ulster County, is a city known for the 1969 Woodstock concert, a three-day festival where many performers, from Jimi Hendrix to Janis Joplin, took the stage, although it was actually held in a nearby town [see. Woodstock Concert].
es: Woodstock, New York, is a city in Ulster County, New York, well known for the 1969 concert that bore its name (see Woodstock Concert), a three-day event where artists like Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin performed, although the concert was actually held in a nearby town.

en: The Catskill Park comprises 700,000 acres of land in the Catskill Mountains owned jointly by state and local governments, including a 5 percent share held by New York City, which gets much of its water from reservoirs partly inside the park.
vi: Catskill Park covers 2,800 square kilometers, located in the Catskill Mountains, co-managed by the federal government and local authorities, including 5 percent ownership by New York City; part of the city's drinking water is sourced from lakes in Catskill Park.

es: The Catskill Park covers almost three thousand square kilometers of the Catskill Mountains and is jointly owned by the State and local government, with a 5 percent stake held by New York City, which receives a good portion of its water from reservoirs located partially within the park.

en: Agloe, New York, is a fictitious village created by the Esso company in the early 1930s and inserted into tourist maps as a copyright trap, or paper town.

es: Agloe, New York, is a fictional town created by the Esso company in the early 1930s and included in tourist maps as a trap to control copyright. These fictional towns are also called paper towns.

en: Located at the intersection of two dirt roads just north of Roscoe, NY, Agloe was the creation of mapmakers Otto G. Lindberg and Ernest Alpers, who invented the town name by anagramming their initials.

es: Agloe, situated at the intersection of two unpaved roads north of Roscoe, New York, was created by cartographers Otto G. Lindberg and Ernest Alpers, who invented the name of the town by forming an anagram with their initials.

en: Copyright traps have featured in mapmaking for centuries.
vi: Copyright traps have existed in the cartography industry for many centuries.
tr: Copyright traps have been a part of mapmaking for centuries.
es: For centuries, traps have been introduced into maps to control copyright.

en: Cartographers create fictional landmarks, streets, and municipalities and place them obscurely into their maps.

tr: Cartographers create imaginary boundary markers, streets, and areas and place them on their maps in a way that is difficult to understand.
es: Cartographers create fictitious places, streets, and towns and place them in an inconspicuous spot on their map.

en: If the fictional entry is found on another cartographer’s map, it becomes clear a map has been plagiarized.
vi: If those fictitious place names are found on another cartographer's map, it is certain that a map has been illicitly copied.
tr: If the imaginary input appears on another cartographer's map, it reveals that the map has been copied and published.
es: If the fictitious entry appears on another cartographer's map, it is evident that the map has been plagiarized.

es: These traps are also known as key traps, paper streets, and paper towns (see also fictitious entries).

en: Although few cartographic corporations acknowledge their existence, copyright traps remain a common feature even in contemporary maps.

The older lady seemed a bit confused, but agreed nonetheless.

es: While Ben runs to the bathroom, Lacey explains to the gray-haired woman (it is indeed a woman) that we are going to buy a lot of things, that we are in a huge hurry, and that she should start scanning the items as we bring them, charging everything to her BP card. The woman looks somewhat bewildered, but agrees.

Both she and I were in cars with windows and mirrors everywhere, while she murmured along driving next to us on this congested road.

It turned out that what I was doing was very simple, driving on the interstate was the simplest and most pleasant thing in the world: all I had to do was stay in my lane, make sure no one got too close to me and I didn't get too close to anyone, and keep going.

I suddenly think that what I'm doing is very easy, that driving on the highway is the easiest and most pleasant thing in the world. The only thing I have to do is stay between the lines, make sure no one gets too close to me and that I don't get too close to anyone, and keep moving forward.

tr: I can feel that he has turned into Serious Ben and is looking at me.
es: I notice that he is looking at me very seriously—. But...

en: “Just— Just remember that sometimes, the way you think about a person isn’t the way they actually are.
vi: “It's just—remember that sometimes your thoughts about someone don't match who they really are.
tr: “It's just... Just remember that sometimes people aren't exactly as you think they are.
es: But remember that sometimes people are not how you think they are.

en: Like, I always thought Lacey was so hot and so awesome and so cool, but now when it actually comes to being with her . . . it’s not the exact same.
vi: For example, I used to always think Lacey was hot and amazing, but now actually being around her... it's not exactly like that.
tr: Like how I think Lacey is very sexy, very amazing, and very cool, but now when it comes to actually being with her... it's not exactly the same, people are different when you can feel them, when you can see them up close.”
es: For example, I always thought that Lacey was really hot, that she was incredible and cool, but now, when I'm actually with her... it's not the same.

en: People are different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?”
vi: People become very different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?”
tr: Like how I think Lacey is very sexy, very amazing, and very cool, but now when it comes to actually being with her... it's not exactly the same, people are different when you can feel them, when you can see them up close.”
es: People are different when you can smell them and see them up close, you know?

en: “I know that,” I say.
vi: “I know,” I replied.
tr: “I know this,” I say.
es: —I know —I reply to him.

en: I know how long, and how badly, I wrongly imagined her.

tr: I know how long, how badly, and how wrongly I have imagined Margo.
es: I know that for a long time I have been wrong, and very much so, imagining her.

en: “I’m just saying that it was easy for me to like Lacey before.
vi: “What I mean is that it used to be very easy for me to like Lacey.
tr: “I'm just saying it was easy for me to like Lacey from a distance before.
es: —I’m just saying that it used to be easy for me to like Lacey.

en: It’s easy to like someone from a distance.
vi: Liking someone from afar is always very easy.
tr: It's easy to love someone from afar.
es: It’s easy to like someone from a distance.

en: But when she stopped being this amazing unattainable thing or whatever, and started being, like, just a regular girl with a weird relationship with food and frequent crankiness who’s kinda bossy—then I had to basically start liking a whole different person.”
vi: But when she was no longer a distant wonder, and started to become, well, an ordinary girl with weird eating habits, occasionally acting like a bully–basically, I had to start liking a completely different person.”
tr: But when she stopped being surprisingly unattainable and started being an ordinary girl with a weird relationship with food, often cranky and a bit bossy... then I had to start liking a completely different person.”
es: But when it stops being something incredible and unattainable and starts being a normal girl, with a strange relationship with food, quite grumpy and bossy… then basically I have to start liking a totally different person.

en: I can feel my cheeks warming.
vi: I felt my cheeks heating up.
tr: I can feel my cheeks burning.
es: I feel my cheeks burning.

en: “You’re saying I don’t really like Margo?
vi: “Are you telling me I don't really like Margo?
tr: "Are you saying that I really don't like Margo?
es: —Are you telling me that I don't actually like Margo?

en: After all this—I’m twelve hours inside this car already and you don’t think I care about her because I don’t— ” I cut myself off.
vi: After all this–I've been in this car for twelve hours and you're saying I don't care about Margo because I don't–” I paused.
tr: After all this... I've been in this car for twelve hours and you don't think I care about her because I...” I cut myself off.
es: After all this... I've been stuck in this car for twelve hours and you think I don't care about Margo because I don't... —I interrupt myself—.

en: “You think that since you have a girlfriend you can stand atop the lofty mountain and lecture me?
vi: “You think just because you have a girlfriend now, you can stand on a high horse and lecture me?
tr: “Do you think you can stand on top of the high mountains and lecture me just because you have a girlfriend?
es: You think that just because you have a girlfriend you can climb up the mountain and preach to me?

en: You can be such a—”
vi: You really are–”
tr: So much...”
es: Sometimes you are so...

en: I stop talking because I see in the outer reaches of the headlights the thing that will shortly kill me.
vi: I stopped speaking because I saw ahead, outside the beam of the headlights, something that was about to ruin everything for me.
tr: I stop talking because outside, at the very edge of where the headlights can reach, I see the thing that will soon kill me.
es: I stay silent because at the end of the headlights' light, I see something that will soon kill me.

en: Two cows stand oblivious in the highway.
vi: Two cows stood innocently in the middle of the highway.
tr: Two cows are standing on the main road with indifferent attitudes.
es: In the middle of the highway, there are two cows so calm.

en: They come into view all at once, a spotted cow in the left lane, and in our lane an immense creature, the entire width of our car, standing stock-still, her head turned back as she appraises us with blank eyes.
vi: In a flash, we saw them: the spotted one in the left lane, and in our lane, a gigantic creature, as wide as the car, standing motionless. It turned its head and calmly looked at us with indifferent eyes.
tr: They suddenly appear; a spotted cow in the left lane and in our lane, a massive creature the width of a car stands completely motionless, its head turned backward as it tries to perceive us.
es: They suddenly appear in my field of vision, one cow with black spots in the left lane, and in our lane, an immense creature, the size of our car, completely motionless, with its head turned back, staring at us with blank eyes.

en: The cow is flawlessly white, a great white wall of cow that cannot be climbed or ducked or dodged.
vi: The cow was completely white without a single spot, a white wall of a cow that couldn't be jumped over, crawled under, or circled around.
tr: The cow is perfectly white; an enormous white wall made of cow, which cannot be climbed over, passed under, or bypassed.
es: It is absolutely white, an enormous white wall of cow that we cannot jump over, pass under, or avoid.

en: It can only be hit.
vi: The only option was to crash into it.
tr: The only option is to crash.
es: We can only crash into it.

en: I know that Ben sees it, too, because I hear his breath stop.
vi: I knew Ben had seen it too, because I heard Ben's breath stop abruptly.
tr: I know Ben sees it too because I hear his breath catch.
es: I know that Ben sees it too, because I hear him stop breathing.

en: They say that your life flashes before your eyes, but for me that is not the case.
vi: They say that life flashes before your eyes, but for me, it wasn't like that.
tr: They say that your life flashes before your eyes like a film strip, but that's not the case for me.
es: They say that life flashes before your eyes, but in my case, it isn't like that.

en: Nothing flashes before my eyes except this impossibly vast expanse of snowy fur, now only a second from us.
vi: Nothing flashed before my eyes except this vast, impossibly white expanse, now just seconds away from us.
tr: Before my eyes, nothing passes except for this incredibly vast, snow-like fur that is now just a second away from us.
es: Nothing flashes before my eyes except that enormous expanse of white fur, now just a second away from us.

en: I don’t know what to do.
vi: I didn't know what to do.
tr: I don't know what to do.
es: I don't know what to do.

en: No, that’s not the problem.
vi: No, that wasn't the issue.
tr: No, that's not the problem.
es: No, that's not the problem.

en: The problem is that there is nothing to do, except to hit this white wall and kill it and us, both.
vi: The issue was that there was nothing to do except crash into that white wall, destroying it and us, both sides.
tr: The problem is that there's nothing to do except crash into this white wall and kill both it and ourselves.
es: The problem is that there's nothing to do, except crash into that white wall, kill it and kill ourselves.

en: I slam on the brakes, but out of habit not expectation: there is absolutely no avoiding this.
vi: I slammed on the brakes, out of habit rather than hoping to change the outcome: it was clearly unavoidable.
tr: I'm slamming on the brakes out of habit, with no expectation: it's impossible to avoid this.
es: I hit the brakes, but out of habit, without expectations. There's no way to avoid it.

en: I raise my hands off the steering wheel.
vi: I raised my hands off the steering wheel.
tr: I take my hands off the steering wheel and raise them up.
es: I don't know why, but I raise my hands, as if surrendering.

en: I do not know why I am doing this, but I raise my hands up, as if I am surrendering.
vi: I didn't know why I did it, but I raised my hands, as if surrendering.
tr: I don't know why I'm doing this, but I raise my hands, as if I'm surrendering.
es: I don't know why, but I raise my hands, as if surrendering.

en: I’m thinking the most banal thing in the world: I am thinking that I don’t want this to happen.
vi: I thought about the most mundane thing in the world: that I didn't want this to happen.
tr: I'm thinking about the most boring thing in the world: I'm thinking that I don't want this to happen.
es: I think about the most banal thing in the world: that I don't want it to happen.

en: I don’t want to die.
vi: I didn't want to die.
tr: I don't want to die.
es: I don't want to die.

en: I don’t want my friends to die.
vi: I didn't want my friends to die.
tr: I don't want my friends to die.
es: I don't want my friends to die.

en: And to be honest, as the time slows down and my hands are in the air, I am afforded the chance to think one more thought, and I think about her.
vi: And honestly, as time slowed down and my hands were in the air, I had the chance for one more thought, and I thought of her.
tr: Also, to be honest, as time slows down and my hands are in the air, I have the strength for one more thought and I think of Margo.
es: And to be honest, as time slows down and my hands are in the air, I allow myself to think of one more thing, and I think of Margo.

en: I blame her for this ridiculous, fatal chase—for putting us at risk, for making me into the kind of jackass who would stay up all night and drive too fast.
vi: I blamed her for this deadly, ridiculous chase—for putting us at risk, for turning me into a fool driving like a maniac all night.
tr: I blame her for this absurd, deadly chase... for putting us in danger; for turning me into the kind of fool who drives fast all night without sleeping.
es: I blame her for this ridiculous and fatal chase... for putting us in danger, for turning me into an idiot who spends the night sleepless and drives too fast.

en: I would not be dying were it not for her.
vi: If it weren't for her, I wouldn't be dying.
tr: If it weren't for her, I wouldn't be dying.
es: I wouldn't be about to die if it weren't for her.

en: I would have stayed home, as I have always stayed home, and I would have been safe, and I would have done the one thing I have always wanted to do, which is to grow up.

tr: I would be at home as always, safe, and doing the only thing I've ever wanted to do, which is to grow up.
es: I would have stayed home, as always, and would have been safe, and would have done the only thing I've always wanted to do, which is to grow up.

en: Having surrendered control of the vessel, I am surprised to see a hand on the steering wheel.

es: Although I have abandoned control of the ship, I am surprised to see a hand on the wheel.

en: They are there.

en: And Ben says, “I’mfineI’mfineQisbleeding.”

vi: Lacey pressed on the scratch with her slender, soft fingers, telling Ben to find something to bandage it. And then a strip of the Union flag was pressed against my right cheek, near my nose.
tr: Lacey gently and softly presses on the cut with her fingers and yells at Ben to find something that can be used as a bandage; then I have a bandage made from a Confederate flag pressed against my cheek, just to the right of my nose.

en: It’s gonna blow!”

tr: "All the beers are broken," he says, nodding his head towards the opened cooler, from which liters of foamy liquid are spilling out.

en: I laugh.
