es: The blanket still smelled like you.

en: And when I say that her hand brushes up against mine, and I just grab hers because it feels like there is less to ruin now.
vi: When I said that, Margo's hand gently touched me, and I immediately held that hand, because it felt like there were fewer things that could be ruined at that moment.
tr: When I say this, his hand lightly touches mine and I immediately grab his hand because it feels like there are fewer things left to ruin.
es: And when I tell her, her hand brushes against mine, and I take it because it feels like there's not much left to ruin now.

en: She looks at me.
vi: Margo looked at me.
tr: He looks at me.
es: She looks at me.

en: “I had to leave.
vi: "I had to leave.
tr: “I had to go.
es: —I had to leave.

en: I didn’t have to scare you and that was stupid and I should have done a better job leaving, but I did have to leave.
vi: I didn't need to scare you and that was really stupid. I should have left more neatly, but I really had to go.
tr: I didn't need to scare you, it was foolish, and I should have done a better job when leaving, but I had to go.
es: I shouldn't have scared you, it was stupid, I should have left in another way, but I had to go.

en: Do you see that yet?”
vi: Do you understand?"
tr: Do you understand now?”
es: Do you understand now?

en: “Yeah,” I say, “but I think you can come back now.
vi: “Yes,” I replied, “but I think now you can also return.
tr: “Yes,” I say, “but I think you can come back now.
es: —Yes —I tell him—, but I think you can come back now.

en: I really do.”
vi: That's exactly what I think.”
tr: I really think so.”
es: I really believe it.

en: “No, you don’t,” she answers, and she’s right.
vi: “No, you don't think that way,” Margo replied, and she was right.
tr: “No, you are not thinking,” he replies, and he is right.
es: —No, you don't believe it —he replies to me. And he is right.

en: She can see it in my face—I understand now that I can’t be her and she can’t be me.
vi: She could see it on my face–now I understand that I can't be her and she can't be me.
tr: He can read it from my face... I now understand that I cannot be him and he cannot be me.
es: He sees it in my face. At last, I understand that I cannot be her, and that she cannot be me.

en: Maybe Whitman had a gift I don’t have.
vi: Maybe Whitman has a talent that I don't have.
tr: Maybe Whitman had a talent that I did not possess.
es: Maybe Whitman had a gift that I do not have.

en: But as for me: I must ask the wounded man where he is hurt, because I cannot become the wounded man.
vi: For me: I have to ask the wounded person where he is hurt, because I can't become the wounded person.
tr: But I must ask the wounded man where it hurts because I cannot be the wounded man.
es: As far as I am concerned, I have to ask the wounded where the wound is, because I cannot become the wounded.

en: The only wounded man I can be is me.
vi: The only wounded person I can be is myself.
tr: The only wounded man I can be is myself.
es: The only wounded person I can be is myself.

en: I stomp down some grass and sit.
vi: I trampled a patch of grass and sat down.
tr: I sit down, crushing the grass under my feet.
es: I trample the grass and sit down.

en: She lies down next to me, her backpack a pillow.
vi: Margo lay down next to me, resting her head on the backpack.
tr: He lies down next to me, his backpack as a pillow.
es: Margo lies down next to me, using the backpack as a pillow.

en: I lay back, too.
vi: I lay down as well.
tr: I also lie down on my back.
es: I lie down on my back as well.

en: She digs a couple of books out of her backpack and hands them to me so I can have a pillow, too.
vi: Margo took some books out of the backpack and gave them to me to use as a pillow.
tr: He searches for a few books in his backpack and hands them to me so that I also have a pillow.
es: She takes a couple of books out of the backpack and hands them to me to use as a pillow.

en: Selected Poems of Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass.
vi: A collection of Emily Dickinson's poetry and Leaves of Grass.
tr: Selected Poems by Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass, “there were two,” he says with a smile.
es: An anthology of poems by Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass.

en: “I had two copies,” she says, smiling.
vi: “I have two books,” Margo said, smiling.
tr: Selected Poems by Emily Dickinson and Leaves of Grass, “there were two,” he says with a smile.
es: —I had two copies —he tells me, smiling.

en: “It’s a hell of a good poem,” I tell her.
vi: “A beautiful poem,” I said to Margo.
tr: “A terribly good poem,” I say.
es: —It's excellent —I tell him—.

en: “You couldn’t have picked a better one.”
vi: “You couldn't have chosen better.”
tr: “You couldn't have chosen a better one.”
es: You couldn't have chosen better.

en: “Really, it was an impulse decision that morning.
vi: "Actually, it was just a spontaneous decision that morning.
tr: “Really? It was a sudden decision I made that morning.
es: —It was an impulsive decision that morning, truly.

en: I remembered the bit about the doors and thought that was perfect.
vi: I remembered a quote about doors and thought it was very fitting.
tr: I remembered the small piece about doors and thought it was perfect.
es: I remembered the passage about the doors and thought it was perfect.

en: But then when I got here I reread it.
vi: But then when I got here, I read it again.
tr: But then when I came here, I read it again.
es: But then, upon arriving here, I read it again.

en: I hadn’t read it since sophomore English, and yeah, I liked it.
vi: I hadn't read it again since I was in tenth grade studying the national language.
tr: I hadn't read it since literature class in the second year of high school, and yes, I liked it.
es: I hadn't read it since my sophomore year of high school and, yes, I liked it.

en: I tried to read a bunch of poetry.
vi: Yes, I really liked that poem. I tried to read a lot of poetry.
tr: I tried to read a lot of poetry.
es: I've tried to read a lot of poetry.

en: I was trying to figure out—like, what was it that surprised me about you that night?
vi: I tried to understand—yes, what was it that surprised me so much about you that night?
tr: Well, that night I was trying to figure out what it was about you that surprised me.
es: I was trying to figure out… what it was that surprised me about you that night.

en: And for a long time I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.”
vi: For a long time, I thought maybe it was when you read T. S. Eliot."
tr: And for a long time, I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.”
es: And for a long time, I thought it was when you quoted T. S. Eliot.

en: “But it wasn’t,” I say.
vi: “But that's not it,” I said.
tr: “But it wasn't,” I say.
es: —But that wasn't it —I tell her—.

en: “You were surprised by the size of my biceps and my graceful window-exiting.”
vi: “You're astonished by the mouse's biceps and my charming leap through the window, aren't you?”
tr: “You were surprised by the size of my biceps and the grace with which I exited through the window.”
es: You were surprised by my biceps and my elegant exit through the window.

en: She smirks.
vi: Margo smirked.
tr: Grinning.
es: Smile.

en: “Shut up and let me compliment you, dillhole.
vi: "Shut up and let me compliment you, you chatterbox.
tr: "Shut up so I can compliment you, idiot.
es: —Shut up and let me compliment you, dumbass.

en: It wasn’t the poetry or your biceps.
vi: It's not poetry, you little mouse.
tr: It wasn't the poetry or the muscles.
es: It wasn't the poetry or your biceps.

en: What surprised me was that, in spite of your anxiety attacks and everything, you were like the Quentin in my story.
vi: What surprises me is that despite the stress and everything else, you have been like Quentin in my story.
tr: What surprised me was that, despite anxiety attacks and all, you were as disciplined as Quentin in my story.
es: What surprised me was that, despite your anxiety attacks and all that, you really were like the Quentin from my story.

en: I mean, I’ve been crosshatching over that story for years now, and whenever I write over it, I also read that page, and I would always laugh, like—don’t get offended, but, like, ‘God I can’t believe I used to think Quentin Jacobsen was like a superhot, superloyal defender of justice.’
vi: I've been writing in the margins of those pages for years, and every time I write, I reread the story, always laughing to myself, like–don't be offended–'God, I can't believe I once thought Quentin Jacobsen was such a super hot, super dedicated justice warrior.'
tr: I mean, for years now, I've been writing crosswise over that story, and whenever I write over it, I read that page, and always, well... no offense, but I would laugh and say, 'My God, I can't believe I thought of Quentin Jacobsen as the super sexy and super loyal protector of justice.'
es: Well, I had been writing over that story for years, and every time I wrote, I also read that page, and I always laughed and told myself… No offense, but I told myself: "Damn, I can't believe I thought Quentin Jacobsen was a super good-looking, super loyal defender of justice."

en: But then—you know—you kind of were.”
vi: But then–you know–you kind of are."
tr: But then I realized that, in a way, you were."
es: But… well… you were.

en: I could turn on my side, and she might turn on her side, too.
vi: I can turn sideways, she can also turn sideways, and then we can kiss each other.
tr: I can turn sideways and so can he.
es: I could turn around, and she could also turn around.

en: And then we could kiss.
vi: I can turn sideways, she can also turn sideways, and then we can kiss each other.
tr: And then we can kiss.
es: And we could kiss.

en: But what’s the point of kissing her now, anyway?
vi: But in the end, what is the point of kissing her now?
tr: But what's the point of kissing him now anyway?
es: But what sense does it make to kiss her now?

en: It won’t go anywhere.
vi: It won't lead anywhere.
tr: It won't lead anywhere.
es: It's something that won't go anywhere.

en: We are both staring at the cloudless sky.
vi: We both looked up at the clear sky.
tr: We are both watching the cloudless sky.
es: We both gaze at the cloudless sky.

en: “Nothing ever happens like you imagine it will,” she says.
vi: "Nothing happens the way we imagine it," she said.
tr: "Nothing ever turns out the way you imagine," he says.
es: —Things never happen the way you imagine —he tells me.

en: The sky is like a monochromatic contemporary painting, drawing me in with its illusion of depth, pulling me up.
vi: The sky at this moment is like a monochromatic contemporary painting, drawing me in with the illusion of its depth, pulling me ever upwards.
tr: The sky is like a monochrome modern painting, with the illusion of depth pulling me upward, towards itself.
es: The sky is like a contemporary monochromatic painting, its illusion of depth attracts and elevates me.

en: “Yeah, that’s true,” I say.
vi: "Yes, that's right," I said.
tr: “Yes, that's right,” I say.
es: —Yes, it's true —I tell him.

en: But then after I think about it for a second, I add, “But then again, if you don’t imagine, nothing ever happens at all.”
vi: But then, after a second of thought, I added, "But if we don't imagine, nothing can happen at all."
tr: But after thinking for a second, I add: “But if you don't imagine, nothing will happen.”
es: But I think for a second and add—: But it's also true that if you don't imagine, nothing ever happens.

en: Imagining isn’t perfect.
vi: Imagination is not perfect.
tr: Imagining is not perfect.
es: Imagining is not perfect.

en: You can’t get all the way inside someone else.
vi: We cannot imagine every aspect inside another person.
tr: You can't fully enter into another person.
es: You can't get inside another person.

en: I could never have imagined Margo’s anger at being found, or the story she was writing over.
vi: I had never imagined that Margo could get as angry as she just did, nor the story she had written.
tr: I could never imagine Margo getting angry when found or the story she wrote.
es: I could never have imagined Margo's rage when we found her, nor the story she was writing.

en: But imagining being someone else, or the world being something else, is the only way in.
vi: But imagining oneself as someone else, or imagining the world differently, is the only way to get inside.
tr: But imagining being another person or the world being something else is the only way in.
es: But imagining that you are someone else, or that the world is something else, is the only way to enter.

en: It is the machine that kills fascists.
vi: That is the machine that can destroy fascists.
tr: This is the machine that kills fascists.
es: It is the machine that kills fascists.

en: She turns over toward me and puts her head onto my shoulder, and we lie there, as I long ago imagined lying on the grass at SeaWorld.
vi: Margo turned and rested her head on my shoulder, and we lay there, just as I had imagined long ago, the two of us lying on the grass in SeaWorld.
tr: He turns to me, puts his hand on my shoulder, and we lie there just like that, as I had imagined us lying on the grass at SeaWorld a long time ago.
es: She turns towards me, rests her head on my shoulder, and we lie down, just as I imagined us in the grass at SeaWorld.

en: It has taken us thousands of miles and many days, but here we are: her head on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, the fatigue thick inside both of us.
vi: It took thousands of miles and many days, but now we are here: her head resting on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, the fatigue deeply embedded in both of us.
tr: It cost us thousands of kilometers and many days, but here we are: His head on my shoulder, his breath on my neck, There is a fatigue deeply ingrained in both of us.
es: We have traveled thousands of kilometers and many days, but here we are: her head on my shoulder, her breath on my neck, and the immense fatigue of both of us.

en: We are now as I wished we could be then.
vi: We are now just as I had once wished.
tr: Right now, we are just as I wished we were back then.
es: We are now as I would have wished to be then.

en: When I wake up, the dying light of the day makes everything seem to matter, from the yellowing sky to the stalks of grass above my head, waving in slow motion like a beauty queen.
vi: When I woke up, the daylight was fading, making everything look so special, from the golden sky to the blades of grass above me, swaying like beauty queens.
tr: When I wake up, the dying light of the day makes everything seem important, from the yellowing sky to the blades of grass waving slowly above my head like a beauty queen.
es: When I wake up, the dim daylight makes everything seem important, from the yellowish sky to the blades of grass above my head, swaying in slow motion like a beauty queen.

en: I roll onto my side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman on her hands and knees a few feet from me, the jeans tight against her legs.
vi: I lay on my side, seeing Margo Roth Spiegelman kneeling on the ground a few meters away from me, her jeans clinging to her legs.
tr: I turn to the side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman a few meters away from me, with her hands on her knees, her pants clinging to her legs.
es: I turn to the side and see Margo Roth Spiegelman kneeling with her hands on the ground a few meters from me, her jeans hugging her legs.

en: It takes me a moment to realize that she is digging.
vi: It took me a moment to realize Margo was digging.
tr: It takes me a short time to realize that I am digging the ground.
es: It takes me a moment to realize that she is digging.

en: I crawl over to her and start to dig beside her, the dirt beneath the grass dry as dust in my fingers.
vi: I crawled over and started digging next to her, the soil beneath the dry grass crumbling like dust in my fingers.
tr: I crawl towards her and start digging beside her, the soil beneath the grass as dry as the dust on my fingers.
es: I crawl over to her and start digging beside her. The earth beneath the grass is dry as dust between my fingers.

en: She smiles at me.
vi: Margo looked at me and smiled.
tr: She smiles at me.
es: She smiles at me.

en: My heart beats at the speed of sound.
vi: My heart pounded wildly like the speed of sound.
tr: My heart is beating at the speed of sound.
es: My heart beats at the speed of sound.

en: “What are we digging to?” I ask her.
vi: “What are we digging?” I asked her.
tr: "Why are we digging?" I ask.
es: —What are we digging? —I ask him.

en: “That’s not the right question,” she says.
vi: “That's not the right question,” Margo replied.
tr: “That is not the right question,” he says.
es: —That is not the right question —he tells me—.

en: “The question is, Who are we digging for?”
vi: “The question should be, who are we digging for?”
tr: “The right question is, for whom are we digging.”
es: The question is: For whom are we digging?

en: “Okay, then.
vi: “Alright, who am I digging the soil for?”
tr: “Alright then.
es: —Alright.

en: Who are we digging for?”
vi: “Alright, who am I digging the soil for?”
tr: Who are we digging for?”
es: Who are we digging for?

en: “We are digging graves for Little Margo and Little Quentin and puppy Myrna Mountweazel and poor dead Robert Joyner,” she says.
vi: “I am digging a grave for little Margo, little Quentin, the dog Myrna Mountweazel, and poor deceased Mr. Robert Joyner,” Margo replied.
tr: "We are digging graves for Little Margo, Little Quentin, Puppy Myma Mountweazel, and poor dead Robert Joyner," he says.
es: —We are digging graves for little Margo, little Quentin, the puppy Myrna Mountweazel, and poor dead Robert Joyner —he answers me.

en: “I can get behind those burials, I think,” I say.
vi: “I think I'm overwhelmed with all these funerals,” I said.
tr: “I can't miss these funerals,” I say.
es: —I think I support those burials —I tell him.

en: The dirt is clumpy and dry, drilled through with the paths of insects like an abandoned ant farm.
vi: The ground was rough and dry, crisscrossed with the paths of underground insects, looking like an abandoned ant farm.
tr: The soil is clumpy and dry, like an abandoned ant nest, perforated with paths made by insects.
es: The earth is lumpy and dry, perforated by the passage of insects like an abandoned anthill.

en: We dig our bare hands into the ground over and over again, each fistful of earth accompanied by a little cloud of dust.
vi: We dug into the earth with our bare hands, each handful of soil accompanied by a small cloud of dust.
tr: We repeatedly dig our bare hands into the soil, and a small cloud of dust accompanies each handful of earth.
es: We sink our hands into the ground again and again, and each handful of soil drags a small cloud of dust.

en: We dig the hole wide and deep.
vi: The two of us dug a deep and wide hole.
tr: We are digging a deep and wide hole.
es: We open a large and deep hole.

en: This grave must be proper.
vi: This grave is just perfect.
tr: This grave must be neat.
es: The grave must be appropriate.

en: Soon I’m reaching in as deep as my elbows.
vi: Soon, I was digging down to my elbows.
tr: Soon, I find myself digging up to my elbows.
es: It doesn't take long to reach my elbows.

en: The sleeve of my shirt gets dusty when I wipe the sweat from my cheek.
vi: My sleeves got dusty as I wiped the sweat off my cheek.
tr: When I wipe the sweat off my cheek, the sleeve of my t-shirt gets dusty.
es: My shirt sleeve gets dirty when I wipe the sweat from my cheek.

en: Margo’s cheeks are reddening.
vi: Her cheeks turned rosy.
tr: Margo's cheeks are turning red.
es: Margo's cheeks are getting redder and redder.

en: I can smell her, and she smells like that night right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
vi: I could smell Margo, she smelled just like that night, right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
tr: I can smell her, and it smells just like that night at SeaWorld, right before we jumped into the moat.
es: Her scent reaches me, and it smells like that night before we jumped into the pit at SeaWorld.

en: “I never really thought of him as a real person,” she says.
vi: “I never really thought that he was a real person,” she said.
tr: "I had never thought of him as a real person," she says.
es: —I have never thought of him as a real person —she tells me.

en: When she speaks, I take the opportunity to take a break, and sit back on my haunches.
vi: While Margo was talking, I took advantage of the break and sat down.
tr: When she talks, I get a chance to take a break and sit down.
es: While he speaks, I take the opportunity to pause and squat down.

en: “Who, Robert Joyner?”
vi: "Who, Robert Joyner?"
tr: "Who, Robert Joyner?""
es: —In whom, in Robert Joyner?

en: She keeps digging.
vi: Margo kept digging.
tr: He continues digging.
es: Keep digging.

en: “Yeah.
vi: "Yeah.
tr: “Yes.
es: —Yes.

en: I mean, he was something that happened to me, you know?
vi: He was like something that happened to me, you know?
tr: I mean, it was something that happened to me, do you understand?
es: Well, you know, it was something that happened to me.

en: But before he was this minor figure in the drama of my life, he was—you know, the central figure in the drama of his own life.”
vi: But before he was this little character in the play of my life, he was—you know, the main character in the play of his own life."
tr: But before he took a small role in the drama of my life... he was the main character in the drama of his own life.”
es: But before he was a minor figure in the drama of my life, he was... well, the central figure in the drama of his own life.

en: I have never really thought of him as a person, either.
vi: I also never thought of him as a human being.
tr: I had never thought of him as a real person either.
es: I have never thought of him as a person either.

en: A guy who played in the dirt like me.
vi: A person who also played with dirt like me.
tr: As a man playing in the dirt like me.
es: A guy who played on the earth like me.

en: A guy who fell in love like me.
vi: A person who also knew how to love like me.
tr: As a man who falls in love like me.
es: A guy who fell in love like me.

en: A guy whose strings were broken, who didn’t feel the root of his leaf of grass connected to the field, a guy who was cracked.
vi: A person whose connections were all severed, who couldn't feel the roots of his grass reaching into the earth, a person who had cracked open.
tr: As a man who had broken strings, who had never felt that his own grass blade root was connected to the meadow, a cracked man.
es: A guy whose threads broke, who didn't feel that the roots of his blade of grass were connected to the field, a guy who was crazy.

en: Like me.
vi: Like me.
tr: Like me.
es: Like me.

en: “Yeah,” I say after a while as I return to digging.
vi: "Yeah," I said after a while and turned back to continue digging.
tr: “Yes," I say after a while, returning to digging.
es: —Yes —I say after a while, as I resume digging—.

en: “He was always just a body to me.”
vi: "To me, he was always just a corpse."
tr: “For me, he was always a corpse. always a corpse.”
es: It was always just a corpse to me.

en: “I wish we could have done something,” she says.
vi: “I wish we had done something worthwhile,” she said.
tr: “I wish we could have done something,” he says.
es: —I wish we could have done something —says Margo—.

en: “I wish we could have proven how heroic we were.”
vi: “I wish we had shown how heroic we are.”
tr: “I wish we could have proven how brave we are.”
es: I wish we could have shown how heroic we were.

en: “Yeah,” I say.
vi: "Yeah," I replied.
tr: “Yes,” I say.
es: —Yes.

en: “It would have been nice to tell him that, whatever it was, that it didn’t have to be the end of the world.”
vi: "I wish we could tell him that no matter what happens, it doesn't necessarily have to be the end of the world."
tr: “It would be nice to tell him this, whatever happened, it didn't have to be the end of the world.”
es: It would have been good to tell him that, whatever it was, it didn't have to be the end of the world.

en: “Yeah, although in the end something kills you.”
vi: "Yes, in the end, something did kill you."
tr: "Yes, although in the end something kills you."
es: —Yes, although in the end whatever it is will kill you.

en: I shrug.
vi: I shrugged.
tr: I shrug my shoulders.
es: I shrug my shoulders.

en: “Yeah, I know.
vi: "Yeah, I know.
tr: "Yes, I know.
es: —Yes, I know.

en: I’m not saying that everything is survivable.
vi: I'm not saying everything can live forever.
tr: I'm not saying everything is bearable.
es: I'm not saying that one can survive everything.

en: Just that everything except the last thing is.”
vi: It's just that, everything except the last thing."
tr: Just that everything except the last thing is bearable."
es: Just that one can survive everything, except the last thing.

en: I dig my hand in again, the dirt here so much blacker than back home.
vi: I dug my hands in again, the soil here was much darker than at home.
tr: I put my hand back into the soil, the soil here is much darker than at home.
es: I sink my hand again. The soil here is much darker than in Orlando.

en: I toss a handful into the pile behind us, and sit back.
vi: I added another handful to the pile of dirt behind me, and sat down.
tr: I throw a handful of soil behind us and sit back down.
es: I throw a handful onto the pile behind us and sit down.

en: I feel on the edge of an idea, and I try to talk my way into it.
vi: I felt like I was on the verge of a thought, and I tried to delve deeper into it.
tr: I feel like I'm on the verge of an idea and try to get into it by talking.
es: An idea is occurring to me, and I try to make my way towards it.

en: I have never spoken this many words in a row to Margo in our long and storied relationship, but here it is, my last play for her.
vi: I've never talked this much at once with Margo, considering our long and storied relationship. But here it was, my final game for her.
tr: In our long and story-filled relationship, I have never said so many words to Margo in succession, but here it is, my last game for her.
es: I have never said so many words in a row to Margo in our long and notorious relationship, but here it goes, my last performance for her.

en: “When I’ve thought about him dying—which admittedly isn’t that much—I always thought of it like you said, that all the strings inside him broke.
vi: "When I think about the fact that he has died–to be honest, not very often–I always think like you said, that all the internal connections inside him have snapped."
tr: "When I thought about his death, let me confess, I didn't think as much as you said, I thought all the strings inside me broke.
es: —When I thought about him dying, which I admit hasn't been many times, I always thought about what you said, that his strings had broken inside him.

en: But there are a thousand ways to look at it: maybe the strings break, or maybe our ships sink, or maybe we’re grass—our roots so interdependent that no one is dead as long as someone is still alive.
vi: "But there are a thousand ways to look at it: maybe the connections snapped, maybe the ship sank, or maybe we are grass–our roots intertwined so closely that as long as someone is alive, no one is truly dead."
tr: But there are thousands of ways to perceive this: Maybe the strings break, maybe our ships sink, or maybe we are grass... Our roots are so dependent on each other that as long as one is still alive, no one is dead.
es: But there are a thousand ways to see it. Maybe the strings break, or maybe our ships sink, or maybe we are grass and our roots are so interdependent that no one is dead as long as someone is alive.

en: We don’t suffer from a shortage of metaphors, is what I mean.
vi: "I mean, we are not short of metaphors."
tr: We are not short of metaphors, that's what I mean.
es: What I mean is that we are not short of metaphors.

en: But you have to be careful which metaphor you choose, because it matters.
vi: "But we have to be careful with the metaphors we choose to use, because it is very important."
tr: But you have to be careful about which metaphor you choose because it's important.
es: But you must be careful with the metaphor you choose, because it is important.

en: If you choose the strings, then you’re imagining a world in which you can become irreparably broken.
vi: "If you choose the snapped connections, you are imagining a world where you can be irreparably severed."
tr: If you choose the strings, then you are imagining a world where they can break irreparably.
es: If you choose the strings, you are imagining a world where you can break irreparably.

en: If you choose the grass, you’re saying that we are all infinitely interconnected, that we can use these root systems not only to understand one another but to become one another.
vi: "If you choose grass, you are implying that we are all indefinitely connected, that we can use those roots not only to understand others but to become another person."
tr: If you choose the grass, we are all extremely mutually dependent on each other You are saying that we are connected, so we can use these root systems not only to understand each other but also to become each other.
es: If you choose the grass, you are saying that we are all infinitely interconnected, that we can use that root system not only to understand each other but to become each other.

en: The metaphors have implications.
vi: "Metaphors carry multiple layers of meaning."
tr: Metaphors have hidden meanings.
es: Metaphors imply things.

en: Do you know what I mean?”
vi: "Do you understand what I mean?"
tr: Do you understand what I mean?”
es: Do you understand what I'm saying?

en: She nods.
vi: She nodded.
tr: He nods in agreement.
es: Margo nods.

en: “I like the strings.
vi: "I like the connecting threads.
tr: “I love ropes.
es: —I like threads —I continue saying—.

en: I always have.
vi: I've always liked them.
tr: I always have.
es: I've always liked them.

en: Because that’s how it feels.
vi: Because they are a way to feel.
tr: Because that's how I feel.
es: Because that's how I feel.

en: But the strings make pain seem more fatal than it is, I think.
vi: But the threads make the pain seem more likely to lead to death than it actually does, I think.
tr: But I think ropes make pain seem more deadly than it is, we are not as fragile as the ropes make us believe.
es: But I think threads make pain seem more fatal than it is.

en: We’re not as frail as the strings would make us believe.
vi: We are not as fragile as the threads make us believe.
tr: But I think ropes make pain seem more deadly than it is, we are not as fragile as the ropes make us believe.
es: We are not as fragile as threads would have us believe.

en: And I like the grass, too.
vi: And I also like grass.
tr: And I love grass too.
es: And I also like grass.

en: The grass got me to you, helped me to imagine you as an actual person.
vi: Grass brings me to you, helps me imagine you as a real person.
tr: Grass brought me to you, helped me imagine you as a real person.
es: The grass has brought me to you, it has helped me imagine you as a real person.

en: But we’re not different sprouts from the same plant.
vi: But we are not different branches on the same tree.
tr: But we are not different sprouts of the same plant.
es: But we are not different sprouts from the same plant.

en: I can’t be you.
vi: I cannot be you.
tr: I cannot be you.
es: I cannot be you.

en: You can’t be me.
vi: You cannot be me.
tr: And you cannot be me.
es: You cannot be me.

en: You can imagine another well—but never quite perfectly, you know?
vi: We can imagine others very accurately—but never relatively perfectly, you understand?
tr: You can imagine someone else in a good way... but it will never be completely perfect, do you understand?
es: You can imagine another... but never perfectly, you know?

en: “Maybe it’s more like you said before, all of us being cracked open.
vi: "Perhaps more like what you once said, we are all cracked open.
tr: “Maybe, as you said before, we are all cracking open.
es: »Maybe it's more like you said before, that we are all cracked.

en: Like, each of us starts out as a watertight vessel.
vi: As if each of us was initially a sealed ship's hull, impervious to water.
tr: It’s as if each of us starts out as a waterproof shell.
es: Each one of us starts off as a sealed vessel.

en: And these things happen—these people leave us, or don’t love us, or don’t get us, or we don’t get them, and we lose and fail and hurt one another.
vi: And then things like this happen—people like this leave us, or don't love us, or don't understand us, or we don't understand them, we experience loss, failure, and we hurt each other.
tr: And something happens... someone leaves us, doesn’t love us, doesn’t understand us, or we don’t understand them and we lose, we fail, and we hurt each other.
es: And things happen. People leave us, or don't love us, or don't understand us, or we don't understand them, and we get lost, we fail, and we hurt each other.

en: And the vessel starts to crack open in places.
vi: Then the hull begins to crack somewhere.
tr: And the shell starts to crack open in some places.
es: And the vessel starts to crack in some places.

en: And I mean, yeah, once the vessel cracks open, the end becomes inevitable.
vi: And there, once the hull has cracked, the outcome is inevitable.
tr: So yes, once the shell cracks, the end becomes inevitable.
es: And, yes, once the vessel cracks, the end is inevitable.

en: Once it starts to rain inside the Osprey, it will never be remodeled.
vi: Once the rain starts getting into the Osprey, there will never be any repair or restoration.
tr: Once rain starts to pour into the Osprey, it will never be repaired.
es: Once the rain starts to get inside the Osprey, it will never be refurbished.

en: But there is all this time between when the cracks start to open up and when we finally fall apart.
vi: But there is still this time in between, when the cracks are just beginning until we completely fall apart.
tr: But there is a lot of time between the moment the cracks start to open and the moment we shatter.
es: But there's all that time from when the cracks start to open until we finally crumble.

en: And it’s only in that time that we can see one another, because we see out of ourselves through our cracks and into others through theirs.
vi: And only during this time can we see each other, because we see ourselves through our own cracks and see others through their cracks.
tr: And only then can we see each other because we see the outside through our own cracks and the inside of others through their cracks.
es: And only in that time can we see each other, because we see what is outside through our cracks, and what is inside can also be seen through them.

en: When did we see each other face-to-face?
vi: When have we ever looked directly at each other, face to face?
tr: When did we ever see each other face to face?
es: When did you and I see each other face to face?

en: Not until you saw into my cracks and I saw into yours.
vi: Only when you look through my cracks and I look through yours.
tr: Not until you saw inside my cracks and I saw inside yours.
es: Not until you saw me through my cracks, and I saw you through yours.

en: Before that, we were just looking at ideas of each other, like looking at your window shade but never seeing inside.
vi: Before that, we only saw ideas of each other, like looking through a window but never seeing inside.
tr: Before that, we were just looking at each other’s ideas, like looking at the blinds on your window without ever seeing inside.
es: Until that moment we only saw ideas of each other, like looking at your blind, but without seeing what was inside.

en: But once the vessel cracks, the light can get in.
vi: But once the cracks have opened, light can come in.
tr: But once the shell cracks, light can come in.
es: But when the vessel breaks, the light can enter.

en: The light can get out.”
vi: Light can shine out."
tr: Light can go out.”
es: And it can exit.

en: She raises her fingers to her lips, as if concentrating, or as if hiding her mouth from me, or as if to feel the words she speaks.
vi: Margo placed her fingers on her lips, looking as if she was concentrating, or as if she was hiding her lips from me, or as if she was feeling the words she wanted to say.
tr: She brings her fingers to her lips, as if she is concentrating or hiding her mouth from me or wanting to feel the words she is about to say.
es: She brings her fingers to her lips, as if she were concentrating, or as if she were hiding her mouth from me, or as if she wanted to feel her words.

en: “You’re pretty something,” she says finally.
vi: "You really are something," Margo finally said.
tr: "There really is something about you," she says at last.
es: —You are special —he finally tells me.

en: She stares at me, my eyes and her eyes and nothing between them.
vi: She looked at me intently, my eyes and her eyes and nothing between them.
tr: She looks at me for a long time, my eyes and her eyes... there is nothing between them.
es: She looks at me. My eyes, her eyes, and nothing between them.

en: I have nothing to gain from kissing her.
vi: I would gain nothing by kissing her.
tr: There is nothing to gain by kissing her.
es: I'm not going to gain anything by kissing her, but I no longer intend to gain anything.

en: But I am no longer looking to gain anything.
vi: But I was no longer looking for things to gain.
tr: But I no longer expect to gain anything.
es: I'm not going to gain anything by kissing her, but I no longer intend to gain anything.

en: “There’s something I have to do,” I say, and she nods very slightly, as if she knows the something, and I kiss her.
vi: "There's something I need to do," I said, and she nodded very slightly, as if she already knew, and I kissed her.
tr: "There is something I have to do," I say, she nods faintly, as if she knows what it is, and I kiss her.
es: —There is something I have to do —I tell him. Nods slightly, as if knowing what that something is. And I kiss her.

en: It ends quite a while later when she says, “You can come to New York.
vi: We parted ways for a long time before Margo finally said, "You could come to New York.
tr: Our kiss ends when Margo speaks after a long time. "You can come to New York.
es: The kiss ends a while later, when she says to me: —You can come to New York.

en: It will be fun.
vi: It would be fun.
tr: It would be fun.
es: It will be fun.

en: It will be like kissing.”
vi: Like kissing."
tr: Like kissing."
es: It will be like kissing each other.

en: And I say, “Kissing is pretty something.”
vi: And I said, "Kissing is really something."
tr: And I say, "There really is something about kissing."
es: —Kissing each other is special —I tell her.

en: And she says, “You’re saying no.”
vi: And she said, "You are refusing."
tr: He also says, "You are saying no."
es: —You're telling me no —he replies.

en: And I say, “Margo, I have a whole life there, and I’m not you, and I—”
vi: I said, "Margo, I have my whole life here, I'm not you, and I–"
tr: “Margo, my whole life is there and I am not you, I...”
es: —Margo, my entire life is there, and I am not you, and…

en: But I can’t say anything because she kisses me again, and it’s in the moment that she kisses me that I know without question that we’re headed in different directions.
vi: But I couldn't say anything more because Margo kissed me again, and the moment she placed her lips on mine, I knew without needing to ask any questions, that we were heading in different directions.
tr: But I can't say anything because she kisses me again and at the moment she kisses me, I absolutely understand that we are heading in different directions.
es: But I can't say anything more, because he kisses me again, and at the moment he kisses me, I know without the slightest doubt that we are on different paths.

en: She stands up and walks over to where we were sleeping, to her backpack.
vi: She stood up and went back to where we had just been sleeping, and grabbed her backpack.
tr: She stands up and walks to where we slept, to the backpack.
es: He gets up and heads to where we were lying to grab his backpack.

en: She pulls out the moleskin notebook, walks back to the grave, and places it in the ground.
vi: Margo took out a black leather-bound notebook, returned to the grave, and placed the notebook into the ground.
tr: She takes out the notebook, walks back to the grave, and places the notebook there.
es: He takes out the notebook, returns to the grave, and leaves the notebook on the ground.

en: “I’ll miss you,” she whispers, and I don’t know if she’s talking to me or to the notebook.
vi: "I'll miss you," Margo whispered. I didn't know if she was talking to me or to the notebook.
tr: "I will miss you," he whispers, I don't know if he's talking to me or the notebook.
es: —I will miss you —she whispers. And I don't know if he is talking to me or to the notebook.

en: Nor do I know to whom I’m talking when I say, “As will I.”
vi: I also didn't know who I was talking to when I said, "Me too."
tr: When I speak, I don't know who I'm talking to either: "Me too."
es: And I also don't know who I'm talking to when I say: —Me too.

en: “Godspeed, Robert Joyner,” I say, and drop a handful of dirt onto the notebook.
vi: "Rest in peace, Mr. Robert Joyner," I said, dropping a handful of soil onto the notebook.
tr: “May God be with you, Robert Joyner,” I say, and throw a handful of soil onto the notebook.
es: Go with God, Robert Joyner. I throw a handful of dirt onto the notebook.

en: “Godspeed, young and heroic Quentin Jacobsen,” she says, tossing in dirt of her own.
vi: "Be at peace, naive and brave Quentin Jacobsen," Margo said, releasing the handful of earth she had just dug up.
tr: “May God be with you, young and brave Quentin Jacobsen,” he says, and then he throws the soil in his hand.
es: —Go with God, young and heroic Quentin Jacobsen —says Margo, also throwing a handful of dirt.

en: Another handful as I say, “Godspeed, fearless Orlandoan Margo Roth Spiegelman.”
vi: Another handful, I said, "Be at peace, Miss Margo Roth Spiegelman of Orlando, never one to back down."
tr: “May God be with you, fearless Margo Roth Spiegelman of Orlando,” I say as I throw another handful of dirt.
es: —Go with God, brave citizen of Orlando Margo Roth Spiegelman —I say, throwing another handful.

en: And another as she says, “Godspeed, magical puppy Myrna Mountweazel.”
vi: And one more handful, Margo said, "Rest in peace, super dog Myrna Mountweazel."
tr: "Oh, 'May God be with you, magical puppy Myma Mountvveazel,' he says as he pours another handful of soil.
es: —Go with God, magical little puppy Myrna Mountweazel —says Margo, throwing another handful.

en: We shove the dirt over the book, tamping down the disturbed soil.
vi: We covered the notebook with soil, leveling it with the dug-up ground.
tr: He pushes the soil onto the notebook, pressing and compacting it.
es: We pushed the earth over the book and tamped down the soil.

en: The grass will grow back soon enough.
vi: The grass will soon grow back.
tr: Soon, the grass will grow.
es: The grass will soon grow back.

en: It will be for us the beautiful uncut hair of graves.
vi: To us, the grass will be the untrimmed hair of the grave.
tr: For us, the graves will have beautiful uncut hair.
es: For us, it will be the loose and beautiful hair of the graves.

en: We hold hands rough with dirt as we walk back to the Agloe General Store.
vi: We held hands, our feet dirty, and walked towards Agloe General Store.
tr: As we walk back to Agloe Market, we clasp our hardened hands together.
es: We return to the Agloe Supermarket holding hands, which are rough from the dirt.

en: I help Margo carry her belongings—an armful of clothes, her toiletries, and the desk chair—to her car.
vi: I helped Margo carry her luggage—a bundle of clothes, personal hygiene items, and an office chair—to her car.
tr: I'm helping Margo carry her belongings to her car... an armful of clothes, toiletries, and chair.
es: I help Margo load her things into the car: clothes, toiletries, and the chair.

en: The preciousness of the moment, which should make it easier to talk, makes it harder.
vi: The preciousness of the moment often makes people speak easily to each other, but now it was just harder to find the words.
tr: 0 the value of the moment, instead of making the conversation easier, makes it even more difficult.
es: The moment is so precious that, instead of facilitating the conversation, it makes it more difficult.

en: We’re standing outside in the parking lot of a single-story motel when the good-byes become unavoidable.
vi: We stood outside in the parking lot of a one-story motel, when we could no longer avoid the goodbyes.
tr: When saying goodbye becomes inevitable, we stop in the parking lot of a single-story motel.
es: We are in front of the parking lot of a one-story motel when the farewell is inevitable.

en: “I’m gonna get a cell, and I’ll call you,” she says.
vi: “I'll buy a cell phone, and I'll call you,” Margo said.
tr: “I will get a cell phone and call you,” he says.
es: —I will get a cell phone and call you —he tells me—.

en: “And email.
vi: “And email too.
tr: “And I will send emails.
es: And I will write you emails.

en: And post mysterious statements on Omnictionary’s Paper Towns talk page.”
vi: And post mysterious comments on the discussion section of the article about Paper Towns in the Everything Encyclopedia.”
tr: And I will send mysterious messages to the talk page of Omnictionary.”
es: And mysterious comments on the Omnictionary's page about the paper towns.

en: I smile.
vi: I smiled.
tr: I'm smiling.
es: I smile.

en: “I’ll email you when we get home,” I say, “and I expect a response.”
vi: "I'll send you an email when we get home," I said, "and I'll be waiting for your reply."
tr: “I will send you an email when we get home,” I say, “and I will be expecting a reply.”
es: —I will write you an email when we get home —I tell her—, and I expect a reply.

en: “You have my word.
vi: "I assure you.
tr: “I promise to send it.
es: —Promised.

en: And I’ll see you.
vi: And I will see you again.
tr: And we will meet.
es: And we will see each other.

en: We’re not done seeing each other.”
vi: We are not done with our meetings here yet."
tr: We are not done seeing each other yet.”
es: We are not going to stop seeing each other.

en: “At the end of the summer, maybe, I can meet you somewhere before school,” I say.
vi: "At the end of summer, maybe, I could meet you somewhere before school starts," I said.
tr: "At the end of summer, before school starts, I can meet you somewhere," I say.
es: —At the end of summer, I might be able to come see you, before classes start —I tell her.

en: “Yeah,” she says.
vi: "Yes," Margo replied.
tr: “Yes,” he says.
es: —Yes —he answers me—.

en: “Yeah, that’s a good idea.”
vi: "Good idea."
tr: “Yes, this is a good idea.”
es: Yes, good idea.

en: I smile and nod.
vi: I smiled and nodded.
tr: Smiling, I nod my head.
es: I smile and nod.

en: She turns away, and I am wondering if she means any of it when I see her shoulders collapse.
vi: She turned away, and I was wondering if Margo really thought so, when I saw her shoulders shaking.
tr: He turns his back and when I see his shoulders shaking, I wonder if any of what he said was true.
es: He turns around and I'm wondering if he was serious when I see him hunch his shoulders.

en: She is crying.
vi: Margo was crying.
tr: He is crying.
es: He's crying.

en: “I’ll see you then.
vi: "I will see you again.
tr: “See you, and by the way, I will write to you,” I say.
es: —See you then.

en: And I’ll write in the meantime,” I say.
vi: In the meantime, I will write to you," I said.
tr: “See you, and by the way, I will write to you,” I say.
es: And in the meantime, I'll write to you —I say.

en: “Yes,” she says without turning around, her voice thick.
vi: "Alright, see you," she said without turning back, her voice lowering.
tr: "Yes," he says without turning around, his voice muffled.
es: —Yes —he answers me without turning, with a hoarse voice—.

en: “I’ll write you, too.”
vi: "I'll write to you too."
tr: "I will write to you too."
es: I will write to you too.

en: It is saying these things that keeps us from falling apart.
vi: It was precisely speaking these things that kept us from falling apart.
tr: The thing that prevents us from falling apart is saying these things.
es: Saying these things prevents us from falling apart.

en: And maybe by imagining these futures we can make them real, and maybe not, but either way we must imagine them.
vi: And perhaps by imagining those futures, we could make them come true. Or maybe not. But in either case, we still had to imagine them.
tr: Maybe we can make these futures come true by imagining them, maybe we can't, but in any case, we must imagine them.
es: And maybe by imagining those futures we can make them real, or maybe not, but in any case, we have to imagine them.

en: The light rushes out and floods in.
vi: Light surged out and flowed in.
tr: Light seeps out and pours in.
es: The light overflows and floods everything.

en: I stand in this parking lot, realizing that I’ve never been this far from home, and here is this girl I love and cannot follow.
vi: I stand in this parking lot, realizing that I have never been this far from home, and here is the girl I love but cannot follow.
tr: Realizing that I have never been this far from home before, I am in this park area and the girl I love and cannot follow is right here.
es: I am in this parking lot thinking that I have never been so far from home, and here is the girl I love and cannot follow.

en: I hope this is the hero’s errand, because not following her is the hardest thing I’ve ever done.
vi: I hope this is a trivial matter for a hero, because not following her is the hardest thing I have ever done.
tr: I hope that what is referred to as the hero's journey ends here because not following her is the most hard thing.
es: I hope this is the hero's mission, because not following her is the hardest thing I have ever done in my life.

en: I keep thinking she will get into the car, but she doesn’t, and she finally turns around to me and I see her soaked eyes.
vi: I kept thinking Margo would get into the car, but no, in the end, Margo turned back, and I saw her eyes, glistening with tears.
tr: I keep thinking that she will get into the car, but she doesn't; finally, when she turns to me, I see her tear-filled eyes.
es: I think he will get into the car, but he doesn't. In the end, he turns towards me and I see his wet eyes.

en: The physical space between us evaporates.
vi: The physical distance between us disappeared.
tr: The physical space between us evaporates.
es: The physical space that separates us vanishes.

en: We play the broken strings of our instruments one last time.
vi: We played the broken strings on our harp once again.
tr: For one last time, we reach for the broken strings.
es: We touch the broken strings of our instruments for the last time.

en: I feel her hands on my back.
vi: I felt Margo's hand on my back.
tr: I feel her hands on my back.
es: I feel her hands on my back.

en: And it is dark as I kiss her, but I have my eyes open and so does Margo.
vi: It had already turned dark when I kissed her, but I opened my eyes and so did Margo.
tr: While kissing her, the air is dark but I keep my eyes open, Margo too, so close that I can see her, even in this night at the parking lot outside Agloe, there are visible signs of that invisible light.
es: And even though it's dark, I don't close my eyes while I kiss her, and neither does Margo.

en: She is close enough to me that I can see her, because even now there is the outward sign of the invisible light, even at night in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe.
vi: She was close enough for me to see her, as there was now an invisible light from within, even in the evening in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe.
tr: While kissing her, the air is dark but I keep my eyes open, Margo too, so close that I can see her, even in this night at the parking lot outside Agloe, there are visible signs of that invisible light.
es: She is so close to me that I can see her, because even now the external sign of invisible light appears, even at night in this parking lot on the outskirts of Agloe.

en: After we kiss, our foreheads touch as we stare at each other.
vi: The kiss ended, we pressed our foreheads together and looked at each other.
tr: After kissing, as we look at each other for a long time, our foreheads touch.
es: After kissing, we look at each other so closely that our foreheads touch.

en: Yes, I can see her almost perfectly in this cracked darkness.
vi: Yes, I could see her almost perfectly in this fractured darkness.
tr: In this darkness with cracks, I can see her almost perfectly.
es: Yes, I see her almost perfectly in this cracked darkness.
